Title: Floating offshore LNG liquefaction facility - A cost effective alternative
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Offshore Technology Conference
Affiliations: Global Marine Development, Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Terry, M.C., Global Marine Development, Inc., United States
Abstract: The demand, and thereby, the price for imported natural gas has accelerated so greatly that it has become prudent for the Industry to reassess reserves that were marginal or considered economically unfeasible by past standards and methods. Such reserves are: (1) fields too far offshore, or (2) in too great a water depth, or (3) too small an estimated reserve to justify the tremendous capital investment of pipelines, onshore liquefaction, storage, and loading terminals. Another such problem area is the associated gas reserves in offshore oil producing wells that must be either flared or re-injected at a significant cost in money and energy production. Global Marine Development Inc. has performed reserves and site oceanographic analyses along with initial engineering and cost estimating for a floating facility to exploit these marginal offshore gas reserves. By constructing the liquefaction plant and intermediate storage facilities on a vessel that is installed near the gas reserve until depleted, the capital investment is not attached to one field and the risk not so critically dependent upon the reserves analysis. Although the main component of the system is the vessel, systems integration of the process cycle with the marine systems, the mooring, the product transfer system, operational safety systems and procedures have been the focal point of the development effort. The economics of the floating approach to the liquefaction of small or otherwise economically unfeasible LNG projects have been so impressive that the technology has been applied to a large baseload project. The end result has shown that a complete facility can be constructed in an industrialized area, installed at the operational site, and started up in as much as one to two years shorter time period than is possible by any other means, at an enormous saving in initial capital investment. The facility at Brunei, with its 2.6 mile loading system, the construction and cost problems experienced by Sonatrack, and the projected schedules of time and costs by Pertamina for the Indonesian projects as well as the Sarawak project gives impetus for the type of approach mentioned above. ' The Kalingas Project was used as the basis for application and comparison in this discussion because we at Global Marine Development Inc. are currently involved in the design and construction of a floating facility that is planned for installation in the Persian Gulf off the coast of Iran. It will be provided gas from the Kalingas structure. For this reason much of the planning of the principal Kalingas Project and cost data were made available to us in our planning. This, in turn, allowed us to more accurately compare our costs and schedules with an ongoing project. © Copyright 1975.
Index Keywords: Cost benefit analysis; Cost effectiveness; Cost engineering; Cost estimating; Digital storage; Floating liquefied natural gas; Gases; Liquefaction; Natural gasoline plants; Offshore gas fields; Offshore gas wells; Offshore oil well production; Offshore oil wells; Offshore pipelines; Proven reserves; Reserves to production ratio; Risk assessment; Capital investment; Design and construction; Energy productions; Intermediate storage; Loading terminals; Operational safety; Systems integration; Transfer systems; Investments

Title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE Northern Plains Section Regional Meeting, NPSR 1975
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE Northern Plains Section Regional Meeting, NPSR 1975
Abstract: The proceedings contain 8 papers. The topics discussed include: anomalous potentials in variable-density aquifers affect growth of gas storage bubbles; an approach to the problem of slow convergence for automatic history matching procedures; construction of underground storage chambers; geological history of the northwest passage; natural gas supply situation (May 1975); potential energy sources; some economic considerations of underground coal gasification; and storage of natural gas in salt caverns.

Title: Liquefied natural gas
Affiliations: Gazocean, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Boudet, R., Gazocean, Paris, France
Abstract: The main role of LNG at the present time is to make it possible at reasonable prices to store and transport across seas natural gas which is itself more and more used as a source of energy for both industrial and domestic uses. Faced with the growing needs and the uneven geographical distribution of resources, the sea transportation of LNG has been developing for more than ten years. After such a period of experience, conclusions can be drawn more especially on the different techniques developed for liquefaction, storage, transportation and distribution. © 1975 Energy Institute.

Authors: Ramakumar R., Allison H.J., Hughes W.L.
Title: The Oklahoma State University wind energy research program.
Authors with affiliations: Ramakumar, R.; Allison, H.J.; Hughes, W.L.
Abstract: Development of small-scale systems for electricity generation and storage, primarily for agricultural use in developing countries is outlined. (I.F.)

Title: Utilization of Braking Energy in Vehicles for Reduction of Fuel Consumption and Exhaust Gases. [NUTZUNG DER BREMSENERGIE IN INDIVIDUALFAHRZEUGEN ZUR VERBRAUCHS- UND ABGASEMISSIONSMINDERUNG.]
Source title: Bundesminist Forsch Technol Forschungsber Technol Forsch Entwickl T 75-38
Authors with affiliations: Hartig, Fritz; Hofmann, Reinhard
Abstract: The possibilities of hybrid drives for brake energy utilization are explained. Based on the principles of driving mechanics as well as of storage and transformation techniques, expenditure for and utility of the brake energy utilization are being compared by means of selected drives and appropriate vehicles. Despite an undeniable reduction of consumption, economical reasons are opposed to the general introduction of this system into series production. On special fields only, such as taxi and bus construction etc. , the regenerative brake may be useful.
Index Keywords: Automobile engines

Title: Energy Storage for wind energy conversion systems.
Abstract: A summary of energy storage systems is given, including electrical storage, flywheels, compressed air and reversible pumped storage systems. (A)

Title: Water for human needs. Vol.1; Energy and food.
Issue: (Proc. 2nd World Congress on Water Resources, New Delhi, India, Dec. 12-16, 1975)
Abstract: This is the Proceedings of a second congress held by the International Water Resources Association. Volume 1 is concerned with water requirement aspects of energy and food. The section on energy includes 21 papers on the role, development, design and operational aspects of hydro-electric power, with examples and discussions drawn from various parts of the world. The section considering food consists of 28 papers discussing aspects of water management and irrigation. Fields covered include irrigation efficiency, crop water requirements, and discussions of various irrigation methods in use. (P.W.) (For Volumes 2, 3, 4, and 5 see entries: 2.0334 CH11; 2.0335 CH11; 2.0336 CH11; 2.0337 CH11)

Title: Non-nuclear energy technologies
Authors with affiliations: Penner, S.S.; Iceman, L.
Abstract: As one alternative source of energy chapter 11 (pp.121-210) reviews the possibility of hydrogen as a fuel. Alternative methods of hydrogen production from water are discussed together with the pipeline transmission and distribution of hydrogen. The problems of gaseoushydrogen transportation through pipeline methods are discussed with reference to perating pressures, compressibility, compressor equipment required pressure losses; economic factors and pipeline material compatibility. The design of compressor best suited for use with such a system is indicated. Modifications to existing natural gas distribution systems for hydrogen are outlined in relation to gas compressibility, heating effects, pipeline material compatibility and problems relating to use of regulators. System requirements for the transmission and distribution of liuid hydrogen along pipelines are outlined, together with the economics of a system. Underground and other storage procedures adopted for storing liquid hydrogen in different countries are indicated.
Index Keywords: distribution; Gas; piping; Pressure regulation; Transportation

Authors: Penner S.S., Icerman L., California Univ.
Title: Non-nuclear energy technologies.
Authors with affiliations: Penner, S.S.; Icerman, L.; California Univ.
Abstract: The history, development and growth of pumped hydraulic storage installations within the U.S.A. for electricity generation is described in chapter 12 of this book. A comparison is made of pure and combined pumped storage systems in respect if their operation, maintenance, life, economics, compatibility with conventional generating plant. Compresed air storage systems can be either constant-volume or constant-pressure storage facilities. Descriptions of the system design and operation of both types of installation are given, together with economic and financial aspects and electricity generation efficiencies.

Title: Problems of prediction and control in tidal energy.
Authors with affiliations: Duff, G.F.D.
Abstract: Control and design problems for turbines and sluice gates are studied for the Bay of Fundy high tide region. Tidal amplitude changes related to resonant length may be induced by barrier construction and influence operating strategies. For optimization finite classical models and continuous parameter numerical models with one dimensional coupled hydrodynamics are considered. The control problem for a double basin triple turbine system is also analysed as it permits economies through internal pumping and storage, which can assist operations at low amplitude tides. (A)

Title: ENERGY CONSERVATION - ELECTRIC FORK LIFT HYDRAULIC SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: HARROM, H.A.
Abstract: IN ORDER TO OBTAIN MAXIMUM WORK FROM AN ELECTRIC FORK LIFT TRUCK, IT IS NECESSARY FROM THE DESIGNER'S POINT OF VIEW TO MAXIMISE SYSTEMS EFFICIENCY.THIS PAPER DISCUSSES VEHICLE HYDRAULIC SYSTEMS AND PARAMETERS AFFECTING DESIGN, REALIZING THAT THE TRUCK IS POWERED BY A BATTERY WITH FINITE ENERGY STORAGE CAPACITY.EFFICIENCY OF HARDWARE THAT HYDRAULICS CONTROL IS SHOWN TO BE AS IMPORTANT AS HYDRAULIC HARDWARE SELECTION AND DESIGN PER SE, AND DUTY CYCLE MUST ALSO SHARE EQUAL CONSIDERATION.(A).

Title: ENERGY FROM THE WIND.
Abstract: SECTIONS COVER ELECTRICITY FROM WIND ENERGY, GRANDPA'S KNOB PROJECT, THE PLUM BROOM EXPERIMENT, STORING WIND ENERGY, THE ECONOMICS OF WIND ENERGY, AND WHAT OF THE FUTURE.
Index Keywords: Aerodynamics; Economics; Electricity; FUTURE; GRANDPA'S KNOB; GRANDPAS KNOB WIND TURBINE; PLUM BROOK; PLUM BROOK GENERATOR; PROSPECTS; Storage; STORING ENERGY; Wind power; WIND POWER PLUM BROOK PROJECT

Title: ENERGY FROM THE WIND - ANNOTATED BIBLIOGRAPHY.
Authors with affiliations: BURKE, B.L.; MERONEY, R.N.
Abstract: A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW OF WIND POWER LITERATURE, INCLUDING SOME 770 REFERENCES SPANNING A TIME PERIOD FROM 1759 TO THE END OF 1974.

Title: THE ECONOMIC ASPECT OF PUMP EFFICIENCY.
Authors with affiliations: ANDERSON, H.H.
Abstract: CENTRIFUGAL PUMP EFFICIENCY RANGES FROM 10PERCENT TO 93PERCENT DEPENDING ON SIZE AND NATURE OF DUTY.THIS PAPER EXAMINES THE BALANCE OF FIRST COST AND WHOLE LIFE COST IN VARIOUS INDUSTRIES.FOR EXAMPLE, IN WATER WORKS, IRRIGATION, ENERGY STORAGE ETC.LARGE PUMPS ON MEDIUM HEADS CAN ATTAIN HIGH EFFICIENCIES WHILST REFINERIES, PROCESS AND CHEMICAL PLANTS INVOLVE A LARGE NUMBER OF SMALL PUMPS WHERE EFFICIENCY IS NECESSARILY LOWER.FURTHERMORE, IN THE LATTER CASE EXCESSIVE INCIDENCE OF MARGINS CAN RESULT IN PUMPS WORKING FAR FROM THEIR BEST EFFICIENCY POINTS.THE EFFECT OF ONE PER CENT EFFICIENCY IMPROVEMENT IS ASSESSED WITH RESPECT TO THE COST PER UNIT OF FINAL PRODUCT WHETHER IT BE PETROL, WATER, SEWAGE, PHARMACEUTICALS, STEEL, PAPER, PLASTICS OR ELECTRICITY.THE RECENT INCREASE IN BASIC FUEL COSTS EMPHASISES THE EFFICIENCY ASPECT WHICH IS PARALLEL IN IMPORTANCE TO MILES PER GALLON.DEPENDING ON BASIC PLANT LIFE, ONE PER CENT PUMP EFFICIENCY IMPROVEMENT IS VERY GENERALLY EQUIVALENT TO THE PRICE OF THE PUMP AND FURTHERMORE, AN APPRECIABLE EFFICIENCY IMPROVEMENT CAN SOMETIMES REDUCE INITIAL COST BY PERMITTING A SMALLER DRIVING UNIT.INITIAL CASH INVESTMENT TO ATTAIN HIGHER EFFICIENCY MUST BE BALANCED AGAINST THE RETURN DURING THE FUTURE LIFE OF THE PUMP IN FUEL SAVING AND THIS STUDY MUST TAKE INTO ACCOUNT POSSIBLE ESCALATING INTEREST RATES.AN APPENDIX DEALS WITH EFFICIENCY LEVELS FOR VARIOUS DUTIES AND WITH STATISTICAL ASPECTS OF QUALITY CONTROL.(AVAILABLE AS BOUND VOLUME (PAPER BACK) FROM PUBLICATION SALES, BHRA FLUID ENGINEERING).
Index Keywords: APPLICATIONS-GENERAL; CAPITAL AND ENERGY COSTS; ECONOMIC ASPECT OF PUMP EFFICIENCY; FUEL COSTS; PUMPS-CENTRIFUGAL; TEST CODES

Authors: HICKS B.B., HYSON P., MOORE C.J.
Title: A STUDY OF EDDY FLUXES OVER A FOREST
Authors with affiliations: HICKS, B.B.; HYSON, P.; MOORE, C.J.
Abstract: EDDY CORRELATION INSTRUMENTS MOUNTED ABOVE A PLANTATION OF PINUS RADIATA NEAR MT.GAMBIER, SOUTH AUSTRALIA, HAVE BEEN OPERATED DURING TWO PERIODS OF INTENSIVE EFFORT, IN MAY AND OCTOBER, 1972.MEASUREMENTS OF THE REYNOLDS STRESS AND OF WIND SPEED GRADIENTS SHOW THAT THE ZERO PLANE FOR MOMENTUM IS LOCATED AT ABOUT D # 0.8H (WHERE H IS THE HEIGHT OF THE TREES), AND THAT THE ROUGHNESS LENGTH OF THE SURFACE IS ABOUT 30PERCENT OF THE DIFFERENCE (H-D).SENSIBLE HEAT FLUXES AND TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS GIVE A DISPLACEMENT LENGTH NOT SIFNIFICANTLY DIFFERENT FROM THAT APPLICABLE IN THE MOMENTUM CASE, BUT THE ROUGHNESS LENGTH FOR SENSIBLE HEAT TRANSFER IS SMALL THAN THAT FOR MOMENTUM, BY ABOUT A FACTOR OF 3.ADVECTIVE EFFECTS ARE FOUND TO BE IMPORTANT, PARTICULARLY WHEN THE FETCH ACROSS THE CANOPY IS LESS THAN ABOUT 0.8 KM (CORRESPONDING IN OUR CASE TO AN EFFECTIVE FETCH/HEIGHT RATIO BETWEEN 100 AND 200).LONG-FETCH CASES ALLOW AN EVALUATION OF THE HEAT STORAGE (S )IN THE CANOPY AND IN THE AIR BELOW THE HEIGHT OF EDDY FLUX MEASUREMENT.THE RATE OF HEAT STORAGE IS FOUND TO BE ABOUT 60P20 W N/SUP -2/ PER DEGREESCH/SUP -1/ OF CANOPY TEMPERATURE CHANGE (FOR A DENSELY PACKED FOREST WITH TREES ABOUT 13 M HIGH), WHICH IS COMPATIBLE WITH MEASUREMENTS OF THE BIOMASS AND ASSUMED SPECIFIC HEATS.THE RESIDUAL HEAT ENERGY AT ABOUT 6 M ABOVE THE EFFECTIVE ZERO PLANE, UNACCOUNTED FOR BY THE VARIOUS MEASURED FLUXES, IS FOUND TO BE RELATED TO THE DIFFERENCE IN NET RADIATION OVER GRASSLAND AND FOREST.DURING DAYTIME, THE FOREST IS FOUND TO LOSE HEAT BY TURBULENCE IN MUCH THE SAME MANNER AS PASTURE, WITH FLUXES OF SIMILAR MAGNITUDE (ALTHOUGH POSSIBLY DIFFERING TO THE EXTENT OF DIFFERENCES IN GROUND FLUX, ALBEDO AND EMISSIVITY, FOR EXAMPLE) AND GIVING SIMILAR BOWEN RATIOS.AT NIGHT, HOWEVER, THE EVAPORATION FROM THE FOREST TENDS TO CONTINUE AS HEAT IS SUPPLIED BY THE COOLING CANOPY.THIS IS A DIRECT CONTRAST TO THE USUAL SITUATION OVER PASTURE, WHERE THE HEAT STORAGE IS NOT OF SUFFICIENT MAGNITUDE TO RESULT IN THIS BEHAVIOUR.(A)
Index Keywords: Advection; CANOPY; EDDIES; ENERGY; FLOW PAST; FLUCTUATIONS; FORESTS; HEAT; HEAT FLUXES; Heat storage; Heat transfer; HEIGHT; INTERACTION; REYNOLDS STRESSES; ROUGH; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENTS; TREES/FORESTS; VELOCITY MEASUREMENTS; VELOCITYGRADIENTS

Authors: Chen D.Y., Owen H.A., Wilson T.G.
Title: Table-aided design of the energy-storage reactor in dc-to-dc converters
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, D.Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC, United States; Owen, H.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC, United States; Wilson, T.G., Department of Electrical Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC, United States
Abstract: A new procedure for the selection of magnetic cores for use in energy-storage dc-to-dc power converters which eliminates the need for an automated computer search algorithm and stored data file is presented. The converter configurations included in the procedure are the three commonly encountered single-winding converters for voltage step-up, for current step-up and for voltage step-up/current step-up, and for the two-winding converter for voltage step-up/current step-up. For each converter configuration, three types of controllers are considered-constant-frequency, constant on-time and constant off-time. Using concepts developed from analyses of these converters by considering the transfer of energy by means of an energy-storage inductor or transformer, a special table of parameters calculated from magnetic core data is constructed and leads to a considerably simplified design procedure. © 1975 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Design; Digital storage; Energy storage; Energy transfer; Magnetic core storage; Magnetic cores; Magnetic storage; Power converters; Winding; Aided designs; Computer search; Constant frequency; Converter configurations; DC-to-DC converters; Dc-to-DC power converters; Simplified design procedures; Voltage step; DC-DC converters

Title: High reliability high voltage power processors
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Hughes Aircraft Company, Culver City, CA  90230, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams, J.W., Hughes Aircraft Company, Culver City, CA  90230, United States
Abstract: Design and performance summaries of several aerospace TWT power processors are presented in this paper to illustrate key design concepts, key features and circuit highlights. Output voltages up to 20 kV and DC power levels up to 1 kW are discussed. The usage of the entire gamut of power processor building blocks are described, including linear and switching-mode regulation and energy-storage, self-saturating and PWM converters. Also described are the component selection and packaging techniques used to obtain ultra-high reliability systems. © 1975 IEEE.
Index Keywords: HVDC power transmission; Building blockes; Component selection; High reliability; High voltage power; Output voltages; Packaging techniques; Power processors; Switching modes; Integrated circuit design

Authors: Sakurai A., Nagaoka Y., Morishita S., Wadachi Y.
Title: Flocculation Treatment of Radioactive Contaminated Sea Water, (II): Operational Performance with Real Wastes
Source title: Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan / Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: Power Reactor & Nucl. Fuel Development Corp., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sakurai, A., Power Reactor & Nucl. Fuel Development Corp., Japan; Nagaoka, Y.; Morishita, S.; Wadachi, Y.
Abstract: Low-level radioactive contaminated sea water containing 137Cs, 60Co and 144Ce, of an amount of 64 m3, brought from the Marine Radioecological Research Station of the National Institute of Radiological Sciences to the Tokai Establishment of the Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, was treated with two-stage flocculation. The first stage of the flocculation was performed to remove 137Cs with copper ferrocyanide floc, and the ensuing second stage was applied to remove 60Co and 144Ce with calcium phosphate floc in alkaline solution. The results obtained revealed that the radioactive contamination was substantially reduced by the first-stage flocculation, while the second stage further lowered it to a level amply meeting expectations. As a result of the two-stage flocculation, the overall decontamination factor was indicated to be approximately 10. The sludge remaining from the flocculation was dewatered to 90% water content under reduced pressure. Then for the purpose of storage, the product was solidified with cement in a steel container, of a volume of 200 l. © 1975, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: cerium 144; cesium 137; cobalt 60; decontamination factor; engineered storage; flocculation; flocculator; radioactive contaminated sea water; sludge; solidified with cement

Title: Spot Welding Used in the Storage Battery as a Energy Source (The 1St Report)
Source title: JOURNAL OF THE JAPAN WELDING SOCIETY
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Institute, Sikoku, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hamasak, M., Government Industrial Research Institute, Sikoku, Japan; Matuoka, S., Government Industrial Research Institute, Sikoku, Japan
Abstract: Spot welding is the most commonly used, because it is the simpliest, the lowest cost and the highest welding speed. On the other hand, the spot welding has the limitation that is demanded relatively heavy current for an extremely, usually, cycle unit. Therefore, the substation transformer or power supply becomes larger with increasing of welding transformer. In the point of this disadvantage it could not be applied to minor enterprises and field shops. In order to dissolve these problems, the battery type spot (electrochemical stored energy spot) welding system has been studied. In this system, the storage battery is connected to the primary of welding transformer and comprises the underlying principle that the electrical energy is stored at a low rate during a night, then discharge it at a high rate as required for welding during a day. This investigation evaluated the effect of the increasing of number of spots on the tensile shear strength in 1.0~3.2 mm thick mild steel. © 1975, JAPAN WELDING SOCIETY. All rights reserved.

Title: Fracture in rock
Authors with affiliations: Friedman, M.
Abstract: Fracture is perhaps the most important topic in rock mechanics today, primarily because it is the dominant mechanism of rock failure at the relatively low pressures and temperatures at shallow depths in the earth's crust and because existing fractures strongly influence the physical and mechanical behavior of the rock mass. Fracture considerations therefore pervade all of man's interests dealing with exploration and production of natural resources, engineering projects under or on the earth's surface, and the prediction, modification, and control of earthquakes. For example, (1) estimates indicate that about 5% of the energy generated in the United States is consumed in fracturing rocks [Lewis, 1966]; (2) in the petroleum industry an understanding of fracture is essential in relation to ‘fracture porosity’ reservoirs, hydraulic fracturing, secondary recovery programs, structural inferences from existing fractures, underground storage of gas, and drilling technology; (3) in certain geothermal projects, fractures serve both as subsurface permeability channels and as surfaces to heat circulating waters; (4) the in situ ‘mining’ of oil shale or of the gasification of coal is primarily a matter of man's ability to fracture the rock mass under controlled conditions; (5) in mining and tunneling operations, fractures influence the stability of the openings as well as the extraction of rock or ore; and (6) recent developments in earthquake research have focused attention on fracture (dilatancy) as the source of a host of premonitory events from which it may someday be possible to predict earthquakes [Nur, 1972; Whitcomb et al., 1973; Scholz et al., 1973]. Accordingly, there is ample mission orientation for even the most basic research designed to gain a better understanding of fracture processes in rock and of the mechanical behavior of rock masses containing fractures. Copyright © 1975 by the American Geophysical Union.

Title: Chemical Storage of Solar Energy and Photochemical Fuel Formation
Affiliations: Casali Institute of Applied Chemistry, Department of Physical Chemistry, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Stein, G., Casali Institute of Applied Chemistry, Department of Physical Chemistry, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: Recent advances in the quantum utilization of solar energy will be surveyed. The efficiency of photovoltaic devices in combination with electrical storage will be compared with photogalvanic and photochemical systems. Photochemical formation of fuel (including hydrogen) in homogeneous and heterogeneous devices will be discussed in detail. Copyright © 1975 WILEY‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim

Title: The mechanics of hopping by kangaroos (Macropodidae)
Affiliations: Department of Pure and Applied Zoology, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Alexander, R.McN., Department of Pure and Applied Zoology, University of Leeds, United Kingdom; Vernon, A., Department of Pure and Applied Zoology, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: Force‐platform records and films of kangaroos and a wallaby hopping have been analysed to obtain data about the energetics of hopping and about the stresses which act in muscles, tendons and the tibia. The quantitative anatomical data required for the analysis have been obtained from X‐radiographs and dissections. It is shown that fluctuations of potential energy and external kinetic energy account for most of the energy cost of hopping; fluctuations of internal kinetic energy are relatively unimportant. Evidence is presented that large savings of energy are effected by elastic storage of energy in the gastrocnemius and plantaris tendons. The elastic mechanism is particularly effective at high speeds and seems to account for the observation of Dawson & Taylor (1973) that oxygen consumption is more or less constant over the whole range of hopping speeds. A mathematical model of hopping is presented. The stresses which occur in hopping are discussed. Force platform records and films have been made of kangaroos and a wallaby hopping. The maximum forces exerted on the ground were about six times body weight. The force exerted on the ground changes direction, throughout the period when the feet are on the ground, so that it is always more or less in line with the centre of mass. Consequently the animal decelerates a little and then accelerates again, during the contact phase. The fluctuations of potential energy which occur in each hop are slightly smaller at high speeds than at low ones. Fluctuations of external kinetic energy increase with speed and account for most of the energy cost of hopping at high speeds. Fluctuations of internal kinetic energy (due to acceleration and deceleration of the limbs) are relatively small. While the feet are on the ground the extensor muscles of the hip do positive work, those of the knee negative work and those of the ankle negative work followed by positive work. The energy cost of hopping is reduced substantially by elastic storage of energy in the Achilles tendon. In the case of a wallaby hopping at moderate speed the calculated saving was 40%. The maximum stresses developed in leg muscles, tendons and the tibia have been calculated and are discussed in relation to the known properties of muscle, tendon and bone. The trunk pitches as the animal hops because the two legs swing forwards and back simultaneously. Appropriate tail movements reduce, but do not eliminate, this effect. A mathematical theory of hopping is presented and used to investigate the merits of different hopping techniques. Dawson & Taylor's (1973) discovery that the rate of oxygen consumption of kangaroos decreases a little, as hopping speed increases, is probably to be explained by the increased role of elastic storage of energy at high speeds. Copyright © 1975, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: The effects of added dietary lipid on the body composition of rams and wethers
Affiliations: Department of Livestock Production, University of New England, Armidale, N.S.W. 2351, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Price, M.A., Department of Livestock Production, University of New England, Armidale, N.S.W. 2351, Australia
Abstract: A 2 x 3 factorial trial designed to investigate the effects of castration and three diets on growth and body composition of 30 male Dorset Horn x (Border Leicester x Merino) lambs is described. The three diets were: (a) a standard ration of equal weights of lucerne chaff and pelleted concentrates; (b) a similar ration to (a) plus 7-5 % by weight of lipid (peanut oil and tallow); (c) a greater ration of (a) calculated to be isocaloric for digestible energy with diet (b). At the beginning of the trial a group of 40 lambs (20 rams, 20 wethers) were shorn and five rams and five wethers were selected at random and slaughtered to establish initial body composition. The remaining 30 lambs, 15 rams and 15 wethers aged about 22 weeks and having mean weights of 330 kg (rams) and 312 kg (wethers), were randomly divided within sex into three groups and allocated to the three diets for 92 days. At the end of this period the lambs were again shorn, and then slaughtered and dressed. During the trial, rams gained significantly (P < 0001) more weight than wethers, and lambs on diet (a) gained significantly (P < 001) less weight than those on (b) and (c). Weight gains on the latter two diets were similar. Diet generally had little effect on body composition, although there was a tendency, within sexes, for lambs on diet (b) to have a greater fat content than those on the other diets. Rams had significantly greater carcass weights (P < 001), head percentage (P < 0001) and various m. longissimus dorsi dimensions than wethers, but significantly less fat in all the locations measured, including a lower percentage of chemically extractible fat in the offals and carcasses. Estimations of the energy stored in the wool-free body during the trial indicated that wethers stored significantly more energy in the form of fat than rams (P < 0001), but that rams stored significantly more non-fat energy than wethers (P < 0001). It is concluded that a maximum growth rate exists for the non-fat body, and that it is higher in rams than wethers. Thus the addition of dietary lipid (which increases energy intake with comparatively small increases in weight or volume of feed), is more likely to promote fat deposition in wethers, which have a lower maximum capacity for non-fat storage, than in rams. © 1975, Cambridge University Press. All rights reserved.

Authors: Servant J.‐M., Meny L., Champigny M.
Title: Energy dispersion quantitative X‐ray microanalysis on a scanning electron microscope
Affiliations: Service de Recherches, Département de Technologie, Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France
Authors with affiliations: Servant, J.‐M., Service de Recherches, Département de Technologie, Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Meny, L., Service de Recherches, Département de Technologie, Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Champigny, M., Service de Recherches, Département de Technologie, Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France
Abstract: In this work quantitative measurements performed by EDX on SEM, abd by WDX on EPMA are compared. The commerical SEM has been improved by the addition of a beam regulation and an anticontamination device. The spectra are detected by a Si(Li) detector (FWHM = 180 eV) and digitalized by an analog‐to ‐digital converter. The spectra obtained are treated by an on‐line minicomputer PDF 11/05 included in a NS 880 system. A teminal byilt‐in magnetic tape cassette functions as a storage device for the computer. The dialogue between the system and the operator and programmation are possible through a keyboard and a visualization screen. The programs used include: spectrun smoothing, background subtaction selected area totalizing and spectrum stripping. The count rate is maintained at the order of 3000 counts per second to avoid pulse pile up and dead time losses. The experimental intensities are then corrected through a ZAF method by the profgram C ø R on an IBM 360. Binary alloys TiA1, FeA1, ZrNi, NbA1 and TiZr have been studied by K and L lines at different values of the excitation voltage. Alloys MgA1, FeMn and TiVCr Presenting overlapping peaks, and a glass, have also been analysed. The errors, advantages and limits of the method are discussed: in a homgeneous bulk material the minimum detectable limit calculated by C(DL)A = 3I B½ CA/IA is of the order of 0.03 wt % with WDX and 0.2 Wt % with EDX for 100 seconds counting time. It could be improved by increasing the counting time and by using better electronics. The precision of the result is comparable to that obtained by WDX. With EDX on SEM the rapid and simultaneous quentitative micro analysis of all the elements of 11 < Z ≤ 92 can be performed with good precision. This method is very interesting for thin targets and dispersion of precipitates. Copyright © 1975 Heyden & Son Limited

Authors: Birch M.L., Hearn R.A., Walker D.M.
Title: The use of on-line programmable calculators in nuclear power plant laboratories
Affiliations: Duke Power Company Charlotte, North Carolina, United States; Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, Georgia; Applied Physical Technology, Atlanta, Georgia
Authors with affiliations: Birch, M.L., Duke Power Company Charlotte, North Carolina, United States; Hearn, R.A., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, Georgia; Walker, D.M., Applied Physical Technology, Atlanta, Georgia
Abstract: On-line programmable calculator systems and programs have been developed to meet health physics and radiochemistry needs at a three-unit PWR nuclear plant. The system provides automatic energy and efficiency calibration, and automatic quantitative radionuclide analysis for liquid and gaseous reactor effluent releases, environmental samples, and whole body counting data. Programmable calculator systems are also in use at other power reactor facilities for personnel dosimetry record keeping, TLD information processing, and storage of data for scheduled AEC reports. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: Extrapolation of the isabelle design to 400 × 400 GeV
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States; University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Massachusetts 01002, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chasman, R., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States; Gluckstern, R.L., University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Massachusetts 01002, United States
Abstract: Consideration of a national program for the development of new high energy facilities during the next ten years suggests that the most appropriate energy for proton storage rings may be higher than the 200 × 200 GeV of the present ISABELLE design. It has been indicated that 300 × 300 GeV or 400 × 400 GeV may provide a more reasonable step to maximize the scientific potential of the next major proton storage ring facility. A preliminary analysis of the design consequences of changing the ISABELLE energy to 300 × 300 GeV and 400 × 400 GeV is given, keeping the luminosity, maximum field and most of the original design parameters unchanged. It is concluded that the ISABELLE concept can be extrapolated to 400 × 400 GeV without any unmanageable technical problems and that even higher energies seem to be feasible. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Collins T.L., Edwards D.A., Ingebretsen J., Johnson D.E., Ohnuma S., Ruggiero A.G., Teng L.C.
Title: Progress report on the popae design study
Affiliations: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, Illinois, United States
Authors with affiliations: Collins, T.L., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, Illinois, United States; Edwards, D.A., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, Illinois, United States; Ingebretsen, J., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, Illinois, United States; Johnson, D.E., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, Illinois, United States; Ohnuma, S., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, Illinois, United States; Ruggiero, A.G., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, Illinois, United States; Teng, L.C., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, Illinois, United States
Abstract: POPAE (Protons on Protons and Electrons) is a storage ring facility at the Fermi lab on a scale suitable to permit the collision of 1000 GeV protons with 1000 GeV protons and with electrons of an energy compatible with that scale. In this paper, we summarize our work thus far on the lattice and layout of the proton storage rings. Though the 1000 GeV physical scale is maintained, the design is developed in a 400 GeV context. The proton rings form a racetrack, the two long straight sections of which are each about 1 km in length. Each long straight section contains a number of matched lattice insertions, as well as uncommitted space for additional development. Depending on the assumptions made concerning the beam-beam limit (as yet unknown experimentally), maximum luminosities-are calculated to be in the range from 1033 to 1034cn-2 sec-1. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Brown K.L., Avery R.T., Peterson J.M.
Title: The pep injection system
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center Stanford University, Stanford, California 94306, United States; Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, K.L., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center Stanford University, Stanford, California 94306, United States; Avery, R.T., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California 94720, United States; Peterson, J.M., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California 94720, United States
Abstract: A system to transport 10-to-15-GeV electron and positron beams from the Stanford Linear Accelerator and to inject them into the PEP storage ring under a wide variety of lattice configurations has been designed. Optically, the transport line consists of three 360° phase-shift sections of FCDO lattice, with bending magnets interspersed in such a way as to provide achromaticity, convenience in energy and emittance definition, and independent tuning of the various optical parameters for matching into the ring. The last 360 of phase shift has 88 milliradians of bend in a vertical plane and deposits the beam at the injection septum via a Lambertson magnet. Injection is accomplished by launching the beam with several centimeters of radial betatron amplitude in a fast bump provided by a triad of pulsed kicker magnets. Radiation damping reduces the collective amplitude quickly enough to allow injection at a high repetition rate. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: Contributions of the accelerator fraternity to the solution of energy problems
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory Upton, New York 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blewett, J.P., Brookhaven National Laboratory Upton, New York 11973, United States
Abstract: A brief summary is presented of the present situation in the field of energy production and consumption. Particular attention is given to areas where accelerator builders are particularly active. This will include fusion, solar energy, and energy storage and transmission. A few leaders in these fields who have been active in building or using particle accelerators will be identified. In conclusion a few problems will be mentioned which could be assisted toward solution by the talents of the accelerator fraternity. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: High efficiency, CW, high power klystrons for storage ring applications
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Konrad, G.T., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305, United States
Abstract: The 125 kW CW klystrons to be described in the first part of this paper were specifically designed for energy upgrading of the electron-positron storage ring, SPEAR II, at SLAC. Four tubes are required with an efficiency greater than 50 percent. The operating frequency is 358.54 MHz. The gain is approximately 50 dB, the operating voltage is 41 kV and the microperveance is 0. 7. The klystron must be stable when working into an accelerator cavity VSWR as high as 2:1 at any phase angle. The calculated and experimental data to be presented include saturation and phase characteristics. A maximum efficiency of 57 percent was obtained and the highest output power was 160 kW CW at 42.5 kV. The second part of this paper deals with the design of a higher power version of this tube. The RF power is 500 kW CW at an efficiency exceeding 70 percent. The operating voltage and current are 62 kV and 11.5 A, respectively. The higher efficiency is obtained by inserting an additional cavity to make use of second harmonic bunching. Eighteen such klystrons are to be used in the proposed PEP storage ring. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Baer A.D., Gaxiola R., Golde A., Johnson F., Salsburg B., Winick H., Hansen W.W., Baldwin M., Dean N., Harris J., Hoyt E., Humphrey B., Jurow J., Melen R., Miljan J., Warren G.
Title: Design and performance of the stanford synchrotron radiation project (SSRP)
Affiliations: Michelson Laboratory at China Lake, California, United States; Laboratories of Physics, United States; Dept. of Physics at Montana State University, Bozeman, Montana, United States; SLAC Stanford University Stanford, California 94305, United States; Fresno State University, Fresno, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baer, A.D., Michelson Laboratory at China Lake, California, United States; Gaxiola, R., Laboratories of Physics, United States; Golde, A., Laboratories of Physics, United States; Johnson, F., Laboratories of Physics, United States; Salsburg, B., Laboratories of Physics, United States; Winick, H., Laboratories of Physics, United States; Hansen, W.W., Laboratories of Physics, United States; Baldwin, M., Dept. of Physics at Montana State University, Bozeman, Montana, United States; Dean, N., SLAC Stanford University Stanford, California 94305, United States; Harris, J., SLAC Stanford University Stanford, California 94305, United States; Hoyt, E., SLAC Stanford University Stanford, California 94305, United States; Humphrey, B., SLAC Stanford University Stanford, California 94305, United States; Jurow, J., SLAC Stanford University Stanford, California 94305, United States; Melen, R., SLAC Stanford University Stanford, California 94305, United States; Miljan, J., Fresno State University, Fresno, California, United States; Warren, G., SLAC Stanford University Stanford, California 94305, United States
Abstract: The Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Project (SSRP) is now in full operation as a national facility utilizing the intense ultraviolet and x-radiation from the storage ring SPEAB at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC). The experimenter-operated facility is designed to maximize access to, and utilization of the radiation by 5 or more simultaneous users, within the limits of parasitic operation on a high energy colliding beam storage ring, A novel experimenter-controlled personnel protection system permits independent access to each of 5 experimental areas. A vacuum monitoring and control system protects the storage ring vacuum from contamination, rising pressure, or catastrophic failure. The design and operation characteristics of these control systems and of the beam position monitoring and control system, vacuum system and thin beryllium windows are presented. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Bostic D., Cummings U., Dean N., Jeong B., Jurow J.
Title: Vacuum system for the stanford-lbl storage ring (PEP)
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94306, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bostic, D., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94306, United States; Cummings, U., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94306, United States; Dean, N., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94306, United States; Jeong, B., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94306, United States; Jurow, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94306, United States
Abstract: The vacuum system for PEP will be similar in design, construction and operation to the system currently in operation at SPEAR. There will, of course, be quantitative differences since the closed path of PEP will be 10 times longer than the SPEAR path. Some qualitative differences will also arise since the radiated synchrotron power for PEP will be about 13 times greater than for SPEAR giving rise to an increased linear power density incident on the chamber wall. Other differences arise from the higher energy spectrum of the synchrotron radiation. The SPEAR vacuum system has been in operation since April 1972 and has proven satisfactory in design, construction and operation. The chamber has been subject to synchrotron radiation for approximately 300 ampere-hours and the beam lifetimes are now more than several hours. The details of the PEP design and the SPEAR operating experience will be further discussed in this paper. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: H+ Ion Transport and Energy Transduction in Chloroplasts
Source title: Current Topics in Membranes and Transport
Affiliations: Department of Biological Sciences, Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dilley, R.A., Department of Biological Sciences, Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, United States; Giaquinta, R.T., Department of Biological Sciences, Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, United States
Abstract: This chapter discusses with H+ ion transport and energy transduction in chloroplasts. Energy conversion by a series of reactions is carried out in the chloroplast, mitochondria, and bacterial membrane systems. Electron transfer agents are spatially arranged in the membrane to vectorially transfer protons, leading to a proton-motive force in the proton electrochemical potential gradient. The proton gradient is hypothesized to be dissipated through a reversible ATPase. The chapter discusses the possible ways for energy storage and exchange that may occur during changes in macromolecular polyelectrolyte conformation. Conformational changes, indicating possible approaches that may suitably worked out; provide some quantitative ways to treat energy conversion in polyelectrolyte systems. The chemical hypothesis attempts to relate electron transfer potential directly to group transfer potential via “high energy” forms of the electron carriers, particularly, the b cytochromes and cytochrome a3 gives a clear discussion of the energetic relationship between the respiratory chain and the ATP synthesizing mechanism of the chemical hypothesis. Polymers can undergo reversible conformational changes in an amorphous or liquid state, or during a transition from the liquid to the crystalline phase. Measuring entropy changes in a complex system can be approached in two ways, one utilizing the temperature dependence of rate constants and the other from knowledge of the statistical probability of polymer configurations. Entropy changes are not the only factor involved in free-energy changes of a polyelectrolyte system interacting with its surroundings. The electrostatic free energy of a polyelectrolyte molecule changes with the degree of deformation or stretch. © 1975, Academic Press, Inc.

Title: Results of A 160 × 106 device-hour reliability assessment and failure analysis of TTL SSI integrated circuits, part 1 test results and electrical failure analysis
Affiliations: Industrial Research Institute for Electronics HIKI, Budapest, Hungary; Tungsram Works Ltd, Budapest, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Kemény, A.P., Industrial Research Institute for Electronics HIKI, Budapest, Hungary; Kalmár, G., Tungsram Works Ltd, Budapest, Hungary
Abstract: Continuing the accelerated storage, d.c. and switching-service operating life tests of plastic-encapsulated TTL SSI digital ICs e.g. NAND gates, expanders and flipflops till 5-25 × 103 hr dealt with previously, [45] and starting some new experiments as well, it is shown that: (a) the failure rate extrapolated to usual operating conditions at 55°C lies between some 10-9 × 10-7/hr irrespectively of circuit complexity; (b) the temperature activation energy of surface- and contact- (bonding and metallization) failure mechanisms amounts to approx. 0·7-1·0 eV not depending from stress mode but (c) these degradation processes as bonding plague, metallization fissure and Si-SiO2 interface inversion (leakage) prevail only above 125° chip temperature and after some 1000 test hr giving rise to a distinct "wearout" period whilst (d) an amazingly low activation energy of approx. 0·4 eV was found in the "early failures" period, suspectedly due to differing failure mechanisms not explained so far in their nature, giving an authentic explanation of the badly inconsistent findings in literature. (e) Among various stress modes the "Vin = Vout active region" d.c. operating stress can be considered as the most effective one to develop latent failure processes during the shortest time, giving a relative failure rate of approx. 5-10 as compared to a storage test at the same chip temperature, whilst high-frequency parallel-excited and "closed-loop" switching methods with heavy capacitive load give a relative f.r. about 3-5. A thorough analysis of most frequent failure causes especially related to thermocompression bond plague and metallization migration as well as Al-Si reactions is given, supported by optical and SEM inspection (Part II). Also some inherent contradictions and misbeliefs of accelerated vs usual tests are treated as well as the role of measurement errors due to the spread in chip temperature at operational tests, the latter discussed on the basis of both the "standard deviation" and "worst case" methods. © 1975.
Index Keywords: LOGIC CIRCUITS, TRANSISTOR TRANSISTOR - Reliability; Integrated circuit testing

Authors: Ophus E.M., Fagerland G., Gullvåg B.M.
Title: A Fine Structural Study and Energy‐dispersive X‐ray Spectrometrical Analysis of the Metals Present in Ovarian and Other Tissues of Normal and Lead‐poisoned Quail (Coturnix coturnix japonica)
Affiliations: Dept. of Physics, NLHT, University of Trondheim, Norway; Dept. of Botany, NLHT, University of Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Ophus, E.M., Dept. of Physics, NLHT, University of Trondheim, Norway; Fagerland, G., Dept. of Botany, NLHT, University of Trondheim, Norway; Gullvåg, B.M., Dept. of Botany, NLHT, University of Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: Abstract The fine structure was investigated of body tissues from Japanese quails which had received lead acetate added to their diet. A double fixation using glutaraldehyde and postfixation in osmic acid was compared with a fixation in glutaraldehyde alone. Because of the lack of contrast obtained in the specimens from the latter fixation, the presence of metal residues within the tissues were readily observable under the electron microscope. The various metal residues found in storage bodies in ovarian tissues from lead‐poisoned quails were analyzed by means of energy‐dispersive X‐ray spectrometrical analysis. Out of a total of eight electron‐dense, metal‐containing inclusions which were analyzed, two contained lead. Other elements found in the inclusions were chlorine, phosphorus, iron and calcium, the latter element not being present in detectable amounts in those inclusions which also contained lead. Some correlation was found between the morphology and the elemental composition of the metal residues. 1975 The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences

Authors: Schwitters R.F., Boyarski A.M., Breidenbach M., Bulos F., Feldman G.J., Hanson G., Hartill D.L., Jean-Marie B., Larsen R.R., Lüke D., Lüth V., Lynch H.L., Morehouse C.C., Paterson J.M., Perl M.L., Pun T.P., Rapidis P., Richter B., Tanenbaum W., Vannucci F., Pierre F.M., Abrams G.S., Chinowsky W., Friedberg C.E., Goldhaber G., Kadyk J.A., Litke A.M., Lulu B.A., Sadoulet B., Trilling G.H., Whitaker J.S., Winkelmann F.C., Wiss J.E.
