Authors: Conn III D.O., Hall D.P., Wardell M.H., Madonna L.A.
Title: The automotive system - a complex coupling of matter and energy networks
Affiliations: E.I. duPont deNemours and Co., Inc., Chambers Works, Deepwater, N.J. U.S.A.; Philadelphia Navy Yard, Philadelphia, PA, United States; RCA, Lancaster, PA, United States; Widener College, Center of Engineering, Chester, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Conn III, D.O., E.I. duPont deNemours and Co., Inc., Chambers Works, Deepwater, N.J. U.S.A.; Hall, D.P., Philadelphia Navy Yard, Philadelphia, PA, United States; Wardell, M.H., RCA, Lancaster, PA, United States; Madonna, L.A., Widener College, Center of Engineering, Chester, PA, United States
Abstract: Linear equations are shown with schematic diagrams which together describe the automotive dynamic model. However, the principal intent of the paper is not to study the dynamics of automotive operations. The schematic diagrams of each sub-system are presented to indicate the possible points of energy storage and dissipation and how they relate to the continuity of energy. From the sub-system diagrams it is now possible to generate energy and matter balances for the automotive system. The final energie matrix expression (eqn 49), which relates to all components of the system, is developed. © 1974.

Title: Energy storage (I): Using electricity more efficiently
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, A.L.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Exact sum rules for the decay constant of the neutral pion
Affiliations: Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Bombay-5, India
Authors with affiliations: Roy, P., Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Bombay-5, India
Abstract: Two new sum rules are obtained from fairly general assumptions. They relate the 0 decay constant to appropriate energy integrals of the differences between the total hadronic production cross sections of two real photons (i) of equal and opposite helicities and (ii) of parallel and perpendicular linear polarizations. The sum rules are derived by both dispersion-theoretic and light-plane methods. The experimental verification of these sum rules will be possible in the near future by studying the reaction ee(ee)ee "anything hadronic" with polarized colliding beams in storage rings. Theoretical and experimental aspects of these questions are discussed. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Title: Multiperipheral multifireball model and the inclusive cross section
Affiliations: 51-19 97 Street, Corona, NY 11368; Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720
Authors with affiliations: Chen, C.K., 51-19 97 Street, Corona, NY 11368, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720
Abstract: A multiperipheral multifireball model with a rising total cross section in a certain energy region is described, and the single-fireball contribution to the single-particle inclusive cross section in the pionization region is studied. The total cross section in this model rises like lns near the single-fireball threshold, changes to a ln(lns) behavior until it reaches a maximum at an extremely high energy, and eventually falls to zero. The magnitude of the possible rise is proportional to the triple-Pomeron coupling. For the single-particle inclusive cross section in the pionization region, the contribution from the term proportional to a Pomeron-Reggeon-Reggeon coupling is shown to be as important as the term proportional to the triple-Pomeron coupling. The contribution from the Pomeron-Reggeon-Reggeon term is estimated by extrapolating the required couplings from the scattering data in the intermediate energy region, and it contributes to a rise of about 16 mb. The rise of the inclusive cross section due to the triple-Pomeron term is about 7 mb when the rise of the total cross section is assumed to be 4 mb at CERN Intersecting Storage Rings energy. The over-all rise of the inclusive cross section in this model is thus about 23 mb. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Title: Is the cross section for e+e-→Hadrons time dependent in colliding beam machines?
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; National Research Council of Canada; Theory Division, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Goldman, T., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States, National Research Council of Canada; Vinciarelli, P., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States, Theory Division, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: If e++e-→Φ→hadrons, where Φ is a scalar, radiative beam polarization in storage rings will induce an apparent time dependence of the cross section during an experimental run. This should provide a critical test for models which rely on such a scalar mechanism to enhance the cross section in the present energy range. A model of this kind is presented which identifies Φ with a composite Higgs field in gauge theories. We check for consistency with other processes and note that there may be an important relation to the shoulder in the dimuon mass distribution in pp→μ+μ-X. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Hurych Z., Davis D., Buczek D., Wood C., Lapeyre G.J., Baer A.D.
Title: Photoemission studies of crystalline and amorphous Sb2Se3
Affiliations: Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States; Physics Department, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59715, United States; Advanced Research Projects Agency, Department of Defense and Was Monitored by the Army Research Office, Durham; Air Force Office of Scientific Research, Office of Aerospace Research, USAF
Authors with affiliations: Hurych, Z., Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States; Davis, D., Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States; Buczek, D., Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States; Wood, C., Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States, Advanced Research Projects Agency, Department of Defense and Was Monitored by the Army Research Office, Durham; Lapeyre, G.J., Physics Department, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59715, United States, Air Force Office of Scientific Research, Office of Aerospace Research, USAF; Baer, A.D., Physics Department, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59715, United States
Abstract: The photoemission energy distribution curves (EDC's) of crystalline and amorphous Sb2Se3 were measured in the photon energy range h ν=7 to 35 eV using polarized radiation from a synchrotron storage ring. The polarization dependence of the EDC's is much stronger than that of the reflectance spectra. The EDC's show several regions of high density of states in both the valence and conduction bands, with the structure strongly smeared-out in amorphous Sb2Se3. The region of the upper 2 eV of the valence band with six electrons per Sb2Se3 molecule attributed primarily to the selenium lone p pairs, is clearly separated from the remaining part of the EDC's in crystalline Sb2Se3. The optical transitions in crystalline Sb2Se3 occur with matrix elements strongly dependent on the orientation of the electrical vector of the polarized radiation as a result of crystal-field effects. Model densities of states are constructed for both crystalline and amorphous Sb2Se3. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Gustafson H.R., Jones L.W., Longo M.J., Cork B.
Title: Measurement of the p-p total cross section at 200 and 300 GeV/c
Affiliations: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48104; Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720
Authors with affiliations: Gustafson, H.R., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48104; Jones, L.W., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48104; Longo, M.J., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48104; Cork, B., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720
Abstract: We have measured total cross sections for p-p scattering with the results σT=40.42±0.27 mb at 200 GeV/c and 40.40 ± 0.28 mb at 300 GeV/c. Our 300-GeV/c result is significantly higher than published data from the CERN intersecting storage rings. Our data, taken together with the Serpukhov data, indicate that the cross section rises ≅ 2 mb between 60 and 250 GeV. The variation of the cross section with energy may be more complicated than the a+blnsα behavior commonly assumed for Elab50 GeV. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Title: Two-pion correlations in the diffractive excitation model
Affiliations: Physics Department, Westfield College, University of London, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kasman, J., Physics Department, Westfield College, University of London, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The diffractive excitation model (DEM) is formulated in terms of rapidity, and used to calculate the inclusive rapidity distributions p p→π-X and p p→π-π-X. Using simplified kinematics, analytic calculations are made for these distributions and the related multiplicity moments. The two-pion correlations in the isotropic-decay model are found to be in agreement with experiment at low energies, but rise too rapidly with energy, lying an order of magnitude above Intersecting-Storage-Rings data. A modified DEM, with longitudinal decay of the diffractive cluster, accounts for the size and weak energy dependence of correlations in the diffractive part of the inelastic cross section. This model is found suitable for use as the diffractive component in a two-component model. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Title: Chloride transport in Anacystis nidulans
Affiliations: Department of Botany, Imperial College, Prince Consort Road, London, SW 7 2 BB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dewar, M.A., Department of Botany, Imperial College, Prince Consort Road, London, SW 7 2 BB, United Kingdom; Barber, J., Department of Botany, Imperial College, Prince Consort Road, London, SW 7 2 BB, United Kingdom
Abstract: Anacystis nidulans will take up and accumulate chloride ions. When the external concentration was 0.2 mM Cl- the level in the cells was 2.8 mM Cl- and under these conditions the flux across the cell surface was in the region of 10-13equiv Cl-·sec-1·cm-2. It is suggested that this Cl- influx is active and operates against an electrochemical potential gradient estimated to be 117 mV or 2.68 kcal/mole. The uptake of 36Cl was inhibited by low temperatures and there was a net loss of Cl- from the cells with the level decreasing towards the equilibrium value as estimated from K+ distribution. Although the active influx of Cl- was often stimulated by light this was not always the case. Dark storage treatment and regulation of the chlorophyll a/phycocyanin ratios as well as total pigment content of the cells did not clarify the conditions which brought about light stimulation. Moreover, the metabolic inhibitors CCCP and CMU and also the use of anaerobic conditions did not clearly indicate the relationship between the influx mechanism and light-dark metabolism and no firm conclusions could be made about the nature of the energy source. The variation in the degree of light stimulation probably reflects the fact that in this procaryotic organism the photosynthetic and respiratory units are located on the same membrane systems and are in very close proximity to the probable site of the Cl- pump, the plasmalemma. © 1974 Springer-Verlag.

Title: A computer model of biomass dynamics and food competition with implications for its use in fishery management
Source title: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada; Division of Fisheries, Wildlife and Outdoor Recreation, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hackney, P.A., Department of Zoology, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada, Division of Fisheries, Wildlife and Outdoor Recreation, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States; Minns, C.K., Department of Zoology, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada
Abstract: A model useful for managing interacting fish species, based on concepts of food competition, is developed and tested. The model consists of differential equations. One, in the Pearl-Verhulst idiom, specifies organisms which can serve only as food resources for consumers of higher trophic status. A ‘storage’ equation describes ingestion and assimilation of food by a consumer. Another equation derived with the storage equation describes growth and attrition (i.e., metabolic and mortality costs) in terms of energy. Further, consumers may prey upon each other in addition to the resources and the equations are shown to be adequate for describing food webs. The model is essentially one of energy flow and deals with biomass, instead of numerical, dynamics. Coded in a computer language (PL/I), the model simulates competition and clarifies aspects of yield and harvest strategies in systems of interacting populations. The model is illustrated with hypothetical populations which have variable turnover rates and the Lake-Trout-Burbot system in Lake Opeongo, Ontario. © 1974 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Barbiellini G., Orito S., Tsuru T., Visentin R., Ceradini F., Conversi M., D'Angelo S., Ferrer M.L., Paoluzi L., Santonico R.
Title: Muon pair production by photon-photon interactions in e+e- storage rings
Affiliations: Laboratori Nazionali del Comitato Nazionale Per l'Energia Nucleare, Frascati, Rome, Italy; Istituto di Fisica, Università di Roma, Sezione di Roma dell'Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Barbiellini, G., Laboratori Nazionali del Comitato Nazionale Per l'Energia Nucleare, Frascati, Rome, Italy; Orito, S., Laboratori Nazionali del Comitato Nazionale Per l'Energia Nucleare, Frascati, Rome, Italy; Tsuru, T., Laboratori Nazionali del Comitato Nazionale Per l'Energia Nucleare, Frascati, Rome, Italy; Visentin, R., Laboratori Nazionali del Comitato Nazionale Per l'Energia Nucleare, Frascati, Rome, Italy; Ceradini, F., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Roma, Sezione di Roma dell'Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Rome, Italy; Conversi, M., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Roma, Sezione di Roma dell'Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Rome, Italy; D'Angelo, S., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Roma, Sezione di Roma dell'Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Rome, Italy; Ferrer, M.L., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Roma, Sezione di Roma dell'Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Rome, Italy; Paoluzi, L., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Roma, Sezione di Roma dell'Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Rome, Italy; Santonico, R., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Roma, Sezione di Roma dell'Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Rome, Italy
Abstract: The photon-photon interaction has been investigated by e+ and e- collisions at about 2.7-GeV total energy. Evidence based on 34 well-identified events has been obtained for the process e+e-e+e-+-, hitherto unobserved. Such a process is found to occur in agreement with theoretical predictions based on the equivalent-photon approximation. Results on 74 events from the process e+e-e+e-e+e- are also reported. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Ratner L.G., Ellis R.J., Vannini G., Babcock B.A., Krisch A.D., Roberts J.B.
Title: Measurement of p-p inclusive cross sections at very high energy
Affiliations: Accelerator Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439; Department of Physics, University of Bologna, 40126 Bologna, Italy; Randall Laboratory of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48104; N. P. Division, CERN, 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Department of Physics, University of California, San Diego, CA 92037
Authors with affiliations: Ratner, L.G., Accelerator Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439; Ellis, R.J., Department of Physics, University of Bologna, 40126 Bologna, Italy, N. P. Division, CERN, 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Vannini, G., Department of Physics, University of Bologna, 40126 Bologna, Italy; Babcock, B.A., Randall Laboratory of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48104, Department of Physics, University of California, San Diego, CA 92037; Krisch, A.D., Randall Laboratory of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48104; Roberts, J.B., Randall Laboratory of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48104
Abstract: We measured the differential inelastic cross section Ed3σdP3 for particles produced in very-high-energy proton-proton collisions at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings. We studied the inclusive reaction p+p→x + anything, where x was a π+, K+, or proton. The momenta of the two colliding beams varied from 15.3 to 26.5 GeVc. This was equivalent to a single beam of 500 to 1500 GeVc hitting a target. We measured the dependence of Ed3σdP3 on the transverse and longitudinal momenta of the outgoing particles, P and P. We detected these particles with a spectrometer containing magnets and scintillation and Cerenkov counters. The first two magnets steered particles with the correct P and P down the axis of the spectrometer. The third magnet deflected the particles vertically for momentum analysis. A coincidence of the five scintillation counters indicated an event and the erenkov counters tagged it as a pion, kaon, or proton. The luminosity was measured by the Van der Meer method. We found that when Ed3σdP3 was plotted against X=PPmax, it was energy-independent from 12 to 1500 GeV, especially for π+ data. This supports a type of scaling suggested by Feynman and Yang et al. At small X, the pion cross section has a flat maximum, while the proton cross section decreases slightly. When plotted against P2, the pion and proton cross sections both behave as at lower energies: ∼exp(-4.0P2). The pion cross section has a distinct forward peak exp(-10P2) which is absent in the proton case. The K+π+ ratio is about 10%, with rather poor statistics. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Chadha S., Lam C.S., Leung Y.C.
Title: Proton-proton collisions in the hydrodynamic theory
Affiliations: Department of Physics, McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada; Department of Physics, Southeastern Massachusetts University, North Dartmouth, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chadha, S., Department of Physics, McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada; Lam, C.S., Department of Physics, McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada; Leung, Y.C., Department of Physics, McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada, Department of Physics, Southeastern Massachusetts University, North Dartmouth, MA, United States
Abstract: Inspired by some earlier successes of Landau's hydrodynamic theory in explaining the data on high-energy multiparticle production in proton-proton collisions, we investigate exact formulas for the pion inclusive distribution in (1) the hydrodynamic theory, and (2) a statistical variant of this theory in which the thermal motion of the emitted particles is taken into account. All theoretical predictions of the exact spectra are without any free parameters. The results are (1) the exact spectra at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (FNAL) and CERN Intersecting Storage Rings energies are substantially broader than those obtained from the formula derived by Landau, (2) at s=52.8 GeV the exact hydrodynamic theory gives a good description of the experimental data up to a center-of-mass rapidity of approximately 3, and (3) only Landau's original formula for the spectrum gives a satisfactory description of the FNAL data at s565 GeV2. We also obtain a formula for the average multiplicity without any adjustable parameter, and find that it gives an excellent description of the data above s100 GeV2. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Fierens P., Verhaegen A., Verhaegen J.P.
Title: Etude par thermoluminescence de l'hydration de l'aliminate tricalcique
Affiliations: Faculté des Sciences, Université de Mons, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Fierens, P., Faculté des Sciences, Université de Mons, Belgium; Verhaegen, A., Faculté des Sciences, Université de Mons, Belgium; Verhaegen, J.P., Faculté des Sciences, Université de Mons, Belgium
Abstract: Thermoluminescence shows that the hydration of tricalcium aluminate is deeply influenced by structural defects of the solid. Hydration reaction excites centers of the solid detected by thermoluminescence; this energy storage is related to trapped electrons. Hydration of tricalcium aluminate in the presence of gypsum is not influenced by traps but thermoluminescence allows to corroborate the well-known mechanism of this reaction. © 1974.

Authors: DEWEY C., ELDER F.T., OTIS D.R.
Title: ACCUMULATOR CHARGED HYDROSTATIC DRIVE FOR CARS SAVES ENERGY.
Authors with affiliations: DEWEY, C.; ELDER, F.T.; OTIS, D.R.
Abstract: URBAN VEHICLES EQUIPPED WITH HYDROSTATIC DRIVES CAN BE DESIGNED WITH ACCUMULATORS IN THE DRIVE SYSTEM TO REDUCE FUEL CONSUMPTION IN DRIVING PATTERNS THAT REQUIRE FREQUENT STARTS-AND-STOPS AT LOW TOP DRIVING SPEEDS.THE ABILITY OF AN ACCUMULATOR TO STORE ENERGY PROVIDES POTENTIAL POWER SAVINGS BECAUSE OF TWO FACTORS: ENERGY NORMALLY WASTED DURING BRAKING CAN BE STORED THROUGH 'REGENERATIVE BRAKING' BY USING THE SYSTEM'S HYDRAULIC DRIVE MOTORS AS PUMPS, AND BY USING THIS STORED ENERGY TO MEET ACCELERATION REQUIREMENTS, THE VEHICLE CAN BE EQUIPPED WITH A SMALLER PRIME MOVER ONLY LARGE ENOUGH TO MEET STEADY STATE POWER DEMANDS.ALSO, THE ENGINE CAN BE MADE TO OPERATE AT NEAR MINIMUM FUEL CONSUMPTION OVER A BROAD POWER SPAN.THE ARTICLE INCLUDES HYDRAULIC SYSTEM DESIGN, DESIGN AND OPERATING CRITERIA, VEHICLE SYSTEM DESIGN, COMPUTER SIMULATION DRIVING REQUIREMENTS AND TEST RESULTS.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATION REQUIREMENTS; ACCUMULATORS-HYDRAULIC; Automobiles; CIRCUIT DESING; Computer simulation; Energy conservation; Energy storage; Fuel consumption; LAND TRANSPORT; OILHYDRAULICS; REGENERATIVE BRAKING SYSTEMS; TRANSMISSIONS-HYDRAULIC; URBAN VEHICLES

Title: LIPID STORAGE IN THE PRE‐IMAGO AND YOUNG ADULT PLUSIA GAMMA
Affiliations: Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: MACAULAY, E.D.M., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: Changes in live weight, dry weight and fat content of larvae, pupae and adults of P. gamma were assessed. Fat increased during larval life and decreased during the pupal stage. On emergence 11% of the dry weight of adult moths was due to fat. This amount is sufficient to provide energy for a flight of about 20 hours by a large moth. On average a moth flew for 3 hours without feeding. STOCKAGE DE LIPIDES DANS LE PRÉ‐IMAGO ET DANS LE JEUNE ADULTE DE PLUSIA GAMMA On a estimé les variations du poids frais, du poids sec et la teneur en lipides des larves, pupes et adultes de P. gamma. Les lipides s'accroissent durant la vie larvaire et diminuent durant le stade nymphal. Au moment de l'émergence, 11% du poids sec des imagos est due aux graisses. Cette quantiTÉ est suffisante pour assurer l'énergie nécessaire à une durée de vol d'environ 20 heures pour un papillon de grande taille. En moyenne un papillon vole pendant 3 heures sans s'alimenter. 1974 The Netherlands Entomological Society

Authors: Marliss E.B., Cuendet G., Balant L.
Title: The metabolic response of lean and obese mice to prolonged fasting
Affiliations: Dept. Med., Inst. Biochim. Clin., Univ. Geneve, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Marliss, E.B., Dept. Med., Inst. Biochim. Clin., Univ. Geneve, Switzerland; Cuendet, G., Dept. Med., Inst. Biochim. Clin., Univ. Geneve, Switzerland; Balant, L., Dept. Med., Inst. Biochim. Clin., Univ. Geneve, Switzerland
Abstract: Man, obese or lean, is capable of surviving prolonged periods of total caloric deprivation. This is accomplished by the mobilization of the most expendable and efficient form of energy storage, fat. Such a response, accompanied by the progressive adaptation of the central nervous system, as well as the rest of the body, to consume the products of fat so mobilized, permits the conservation of vital protein stores. The mechanisms of such adaptations are incompletely understood, partly because the study of metabolism of individual tissues is restricted in man. Hence, animal models for the fasting adaptation have been sought. The lean mouse has insufficient fat stores to permit prolonged survival. The obob mouse, by contrast, has abundant fat stores and is able to both mobilize fat and conserve protein. Many aspects of the response of such obese mice are analogous to those of man, though the precise mechanism, whereby curtailment of protein mobilization occurs, may be different. Whether the intimate mechanism is identical or not, the ability of this strain of mouse to adapt renders it a useful model for the study of metabolism in prolonged fasting. (21 references)
Index Keywords: protein; amino acid; glycerol; insulin; ketone body; lipid; urea; adaptation; adipose tissue; caloric restriction; leanness; lipolysis; methodology; mouse; obesity; theoretical study; adipose tissue; animal; article; blood; body weight; diet restriction; disease model; gene; glucose blood level; glycogen liver level; homozygote; human; immunology; liver; metabolism; mouse strain; obesity; species difference; starvation; time; urine; Adipose Tissue; Amino Acids; Animal; Blood Glucose; Body Weight; Disease Models, Animal; Fasting; Genes; Glycerol; Homozygote; Human; Insulin; Ketone Bodies; Lipids; Liver; Liver Glycogen; Mice; Mice, Inbred C57BL; Obesity; Species Specificity; Starvation; Thinness; Time Factors; Urea

Authors: Atkinson J.D., Brown L.M., Stobbs W.M.
Title: The work-hardening of copper-silica: IV. The Bauschinger effect and plastic relaxation
Affiliations: Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Atkinson, J.D., Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Brown, L.M., Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Stobbs, W.M., Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: Bauschinger data for dispersion-strengthened single crystals are given, and correlated with data on the dislocation microstructure and the softening effect which is prominent at room temperature in copper. The data are analysed in terms of theories presented in earlier papers, and the following conclusions have been reached: (i) the Bauschinger effect, suitably defined, can be quantitatively accounted for by the mean internal stress level in the copper matrix; (ii) the internal stress behaves as a function of strain and temperature in accord with the earlier theories, except that plastic relaxation requires a temperature-dependent initiation stress in alloys containing small particles; (iii) the softening process is the process of plastic relaxation, and is characterized by an activation energy of 0·9 eV and an activation volume of 1·5 b3; (iv) a new interpretation is given for the dislocation microstructures observed in the softened state; (v) the work-hardening in the unrelaxed state can be separated into two components, one related to energy storage and the other to heat production. Constitutive equations are given which are accurate to 10%. © 1974 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: COPPER AND ALLOYS

Authors: Geißelbrecht G., Haerten R., Karpil L., Seiffert A., Sun R.K., Kresse H.
Title: An Implantable Driving System for Left Ventricular Assist Bloods pumps [Ein inkorporierbares Antriebssystem für Blutpumpen zur Entlastung des linken Herzens]
Affiliations: Bereich Medizinische Technik der Siemens, AG., Erlangen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Geißelbrecht, G., Bereich Medizinische Technik der Siemens, AG., Erlangen, Germany; Haerten, R., Bereich Medizinische Technik der Siemens, AG., Erlangen, Germany; Karpil, L., Bereich Medizinische Technik der Siemens, AG., Erlangen, Germany; Seiffert, A., Bereich Medizinische Technik der Siemens, AG., Erlangen, Germany; Sun, R.K., Bereich Medizinische Technik der Siemens, AG., Erlangen, Germany; Kresse, H., Bereich Medizinische Technik der Siemens, AG., Erlangen, Germany
Abstract: A driving system for blood pumps is described which ccmpriscs an implantable electrohydraulic driving unit, an implantable transformer with rectifier unit and an extracorporeal device for the energy supply and control. The implantable driving unit consists of a motor-driven centrifugal pump and a hydraulic energy storage. The centrifugal pump is operated periodically. During the working phase the pump conveys the driving fluid from the storage to the blood pump. At the same time a spring in the storage is put under tension. During the suction phase the centrifugal pump remains inactive. The fluid is sucked out of the blood pump into the hydraulic storage by the power of the spring. For energy transmission through the intact skin („Transcutor“) two different types of transformers are described. For technical reasons, and to avoid possible physiological stimulation a transmission frequency of 20 kHz to 50 kHz is selected. The energy on the primary side is provided by an impulse generator with a push-pull amplifier. The driving unit is operated either at a preset frequency or triggered by ECG-signal with preset phase delay. The driving system described was developed to test the components in animal experiments and is suitable for taking over partially the work of the heart. A report on the results obtained with the system in laboratory and in vivo experiments will follow. © 1974 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: article; assisted circulation; bioenergy; hemodynamics; instrumentation; artificial heart; assisted circulation; blood pump; extracorporeal circulation; heart left ventricle; implantation; power supply; Assisted Circulation; Bioelectric Energy Sources; Hemodynamics

Title: The Story of the American Type Culture Collection—Its History and Development(1899–1973)
Affiliations: American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, Maryland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clark, W.A., American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, Maryland, United States; Geary, D.H., American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, Maryland, United States
Abstract: This chapter discusses the history and development of the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC), which was bred and nurtured by the scientific community and plays a versatile role. The history of the ATCC is the story of individuals working tirelessly, giving their time, energy, and expertise because they believed in the basic role the collection should play in advancing the science of microbiology. Today, this private nonprofit organization houses the largest collection of diverse microorganisms and related materials in the world. On December 1899, bacteriologists from all over the United States convened in New Haven, Connecticut, to found the Society of American Bacteriologists. The ATCC in 1960 became subdivided into individual collections. No actual physical division was possible, however, because of lack of laboratory space. Office space was rented in nearby buildings, and an abandoned fire house next door was used for storage. The ATCC requested funds from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and the National Science Foundation (NSF) to construct a permanent laboratory building. © 1974 Academic Press Inc.

Authors: Butz L.W., Beckman W.A., Duffie J.A.
Title: Simulation of a solar heating and cooling system
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States

Abstract: This paper presents thermal and economic analyses of a solar heated and air conditioned house in the Albuquerque climate. The system includes the following components: water heating collector, a water storage unit, a service hot water facility, a lithium bromide-water air conditioner (with cooling tower), an auxiliary energy source, and associated controls. The analysis of the thermal performance indicates the dependence of output on collector area (considered as the primary design variable) and shows, for example, the manner in which annual system efficiency decreases as collector area increases. Based on the computed thermal performance, cost estimates are made which show variations in annual cost as functions of collector area and costs of collector and fuel. © 1974.

Authors: Coultas T.A., Burke R.J., Krakowski R.A.

Abstract: Tritium and other radioactive effluents from this conceptual fusion power plant are quantified and discussed. Further technological requirements for the eventual construction and operation of the plant are identified. Development needs for the energy storage, gas blanket, first wall/blanket and plasma confinement systems are described.

Abstract: Threshold conditions for bulk and surface parasitic oscillations, which may limit energy storage in large aperture Nd:glass disk lasers, have been developed as a function of material parameters. An expression describing the energy storage distribution within a disk was used to determine the mode that will be most limiting for a particular disk design. Additional modes that may be limiting in special cases were identified and their effects evaluated. These results are useful in developing disk laser designs that minimize parasitic effects. © 1974 Optical Society of America.

Title: Effects of low temperature storage upon subsequent energy metabolism of rabbit embryos
Affiliations: Department of Animal Science, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, G.B., Department of Animal Science, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850, United States; Foote, R.H., Department of Animal Science, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850, United States
Abstract: The oxidation of pyruvate by two-cell rabbit embryos occurred at a very low rate at 10 °C, but increased 10-15 times upon rewarming to 37 °C. Pyruvate utilization of these embryos increased with continued development parallel to embryos not cooled to 10 °C, but incubated directly at 37 °C. Storage at 10 °C did not affect the amount of glucose subsequently oxidized at 37 °C, nor the shift from the pentose shunt to glycolysis and the Krebs cycle that normally occurs between the morula and blastocyst stage. Thus, the temporary inhibition of carbohydrate metabolism induced through temperature reduction did not impair the subsequent ability of the embryos to metabolize pyruvate and glucose normally. © 1974.

Title: Environmental levels of radioactivity at Atomic Energy Commission installations. II. Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory, January-December 1972
Abstract: Details of environmental monitoring activities carried out at the Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory (comprising radioactive materials laboratories, critical assembly buildings, decontamination facilities, radioactive waste storage and processing facilities, and nuclear fuel storage and assembly buildings), the Kesselring site (comprising two operating pressurized water nuclear power plants, a fuel service building and waste treatment operations), and the Windsor site (comprising one pressurized water nuclear power plant and waste treatment operations) are presented. Monitoring activities evaluating water contamination, sediment content, exhaust air, perimeter radiation and estimates of potential radiation dose to the public are described and discussed, and some of the results of past analyses are tabulated.

Title: Processing and Release o Ribosomal RNA from Isolated Nuclei Analysis of the ATP‐Dependence and Cytosol‐Dependence
Affiliations: Department of Physiological Chemistry, Ohio State University, College of Medicine, Columbus, Ohio, 43210, United States

Abstract: The release of ribosomal subunits from isolated liver nuclei is stimulated by macromolecules in the cytosol, the concentration‐dependence curve being sigmoidal in character. These factors appear to be proteins which adsorb to DEAE‐cellulose at pH 8.0, precipitate between 20 and 60% saturation with ammonium sulfate and are partially denatured during a short incubation at 50 °C, or during prolonged storage at ‐15 °C. Pre‐incubation of the nuclei at 30 °C for 10 min prior to the addition of ATP neither resulted in release of RNA, nor affected the subsequent rate of release when the energy source was added. The degree of processing of the 45‐S ribosomal precursor RNA was also directly or indirectly dependent on the presence in the incubation medium of ATP and cytoplasmic macromolecules. Authors: Speth J.G., Tamplin A.R., Cochran T.B.
Title: Plutonium recycle: The fateful step
Affiliations: Natural Resources Def. Counc., Washington, D.C., United States
Authors with affiliations: Speth, J.G., Natural Resources Def. Counc., Washington, D.C., United States; Tamplin, A.R., Natural Resources Def. Counc., Washington, D.C., United States; Cochran, T.B., Natural Resources Def. Counc., Washington, D.C., United States
Abstract: The Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) decision to authorize the nuclear power industry to proceed to use plutonium as fuel in commercial nuclear reactors in the U.S. is evaluated in the light of the potential ramifications of a large civilian plutonium industry and the subsequently increased risks posed by nuclear power. The extreme toxicity of plutonium is discussed with regard to the problems that will be encountered in its use, transport and handling. Particular attention is given to the hazards of plutonium theft and the difficulties of finding adequate means of disposal or storage. The shortcomings of the present AEC safeguards for the prevention of nuclear theft are described, as well as the threat to civil liberties posed by the necessarily large expansion of police powers that would be required to provide adequate safeguards. Several alternatives to plutonium recycling are examined.
Index Keywords: environmental health

Authors: Santerre R.F., Nicolosi R.J., Smith S.C.
Title: Respiratory control in preatherosclerotic susceptible and resistant pigeon aortas
Affiliations: Biomolecular Hygiene Laboratories, Department of Animal Sciences, Department of Zoology, Durham, New Hampshire 03824, United States
Authors with affiliations: Santerre, R.F., Biomolecular Hygiene Laboratories, Department of Animal Sciences, Department of Zoology, Durham, New Hampshire 03824, United States; Nicolosi, R.J., Biomolecular Hygiene Laboratories, Department of Animal Sciences, Department of Zoology, Durham, New Hampshire 03824, United States; Smith, S.C., Biomolecular Hygiene Laboratories, Department of Animal Sciences, Department of Zoology, Durham, New Hampshire 03824, United States
Abstract: Respiratory control ratios in muscular cushions from the celiac bifureation of pigeon aortas were determined by manometric techniques. Comparisons were made between atherosclerosis-susceptible White Carneau and atherosclerosis-resistant Show Raced pigeons in day-old squabs and 3-6 mo-old birds. In White Carneau squabs, respiratory control ratios are high but by 3-6 mo have dropped to relatively low levels. In contrast to this, in the Show Racer respiratory control ratios are low initially and increase with maturation. These findings are discussed in terms of the relationship between oxidative energy production, lipid accumulation, hypoxic stress, and atherosclerotic involvement. It is suggested that tighter coupling of oxidative phosphorylation in 3-6 mo-old Show Racers may enhance the ability of this breed to withstand stresses encountered in the celiac axis of the aorta. © 1974.

Authors: Pittet P., Gygax P.H., Jéquier E.
Title: Thermic effect of glucose and amino acids in man studied by direct and indirect calorimetry
Affiliations: Department of Clinical Physiology, Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, 1011 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Pittet, P., Department of Clinical Physiology, Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, 1011 Lausanne, Switzerland; Gygax, P.H., Department of Clinical Physiology, Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, 1011 Lausanne, Switzerland; Jéquier, E., Department of Clinical Physiology, Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, 1011 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: 1. In order to reinvestigate the classical concept of specific dynamic action of food, the thermic effect of ingested glucose (50 g) or essential amino acids (50 g) or both was measured in seven healthy male subjects dressed in shorts, by using both direct and indirect calorimetry simultaneously. Experiments were performed under conditions of thermal comfort at 28°. 2. Energy ‘balance’ (heat production minus heat losses) was negative during the control period (mean heat deficit: −16.0 ± 0.8 kJ/m2 per h. 3. Metabolic rate increased 13.6 ± 1.8% after the glucose load, 17.2 ± 1.4% after amino acids, and 17.3 ± 2.9% after both glucose and amino acids: thus there was no additive thermic effect when both nutrients were given together. 4. In contrast to the metabolic rate, heat losses were not significantly altered after nutrient ingestion; consequently, the energy ‘balance’ became rapidly positive. 5. These results show that: (a) the food-induced thermogenesis, for a moderate energy intake, is less dependent on the nature of the nutrients than was classically admitted; (b) this increased heat production mainly induces changes in heat storage rather than in heat losses during the first hours following ingestion of a meal. © 1974, The Nutrition Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Ground water pollution from subsurface excavations. Part V. Other types of wells
Abstract: A great deal of ground water pollution results from subsurface excavations, including water wells. Any time a hole is constructed which provides a possible avenue to bypass the surface filtering system, the chance for pollution is increased. Because the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is vitally interested in water quality it has recently released a book entitled, 'Ground Water Pollution from Subsurface Excavations'. In order to help the water well industry understand this problem fully, the EPA report is being reproduced in a series of 12 articles in the Water Well Journal. This article is the fifth in the series and discusses the technical and regulatory aspects of petroleum industry wells, wells used in solution mining, geothermal energy wells, wells for injection of sewage effluent and desalination plant brines, radioactive waste disposal wells, gas storage wells, water wells, and dry holes and abandoned wells.
Index Keywords: environmental health

Title: Hydrolysis and epimerization kinetics of pilocarpine in aqueous solution
Affiliations: Department of Pharmaceutical Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, University of California at San Francisco, San Francisco, California, 94143, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nunes, M.A., Department of Pharmaceutical Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, University of California at San Francisco, San Francisco, California, 94143, United States; Brochmann‐Hanssen, E., Department of Pharmaceutical Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, University of California at San Francisco, San Francisco, California, 94143, United States
Abstract: The kinetics of the hydroxide‐ion‐catalyzed hydrolysis and epimerization of pilocarpine in aqueous solution were investigated utilizing pH‐stat titrimetry and NMR spectroscopy. The mechanism of epimerization involves formation of a carbanion stabilized by resonance with the enolate hybrid. Both hydrolysis and epimerization follow pseudo‐first‐order kinetics, and the appropriate rate constants and energies of activation were calculated. Epimerization was found to occur to a greater extent than previously assumed and must be considered as a major pathway of degradation and inactivation of pilocarpine. The rate of hydroxide‐ion‐catalyzed epimerization increases more rapidly with temperature than does the rate of hydrolysis, a fact that should be considered if ophthalmic solutions of pilocarpine are sterilized by heat. It is suggested that isopilocarpine may not be a genuine jaborandi alkaloid but an artifact produced by epimerization of pilocarpine during drying, storage, and extraction of the plant material. Title: Lethality and DNA breakage from 32p and 33p decay in bacteriophage t4
Affiliations: Division of Biological and Medical Research, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois, 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ley, R.D., Division of Biological and Medical Research, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois, 60439, United States; Krisch, R.E., Division of Biological and Medical Research, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois, 60439, United States
Abstract: To examine the importance of nuclear recoil in biological damage from 32P decay, we have compared the production of double-strand breaks (DSB) in the DNA of coliphage T4 by 32P and 33P. 33P has the same decay scheme as 32P, but a much lower nuclear recoil energy (1·7 eV versus 20 eV). When labelled phage are stored at - 196°C in a glycerol-casamino-acid storage medium, the lethal efficiency per decay is 0·058 for 32P and 0·022 for 33P. The efficiency of induction of DSB's determined by neutral sedimentation of extracted DNA, is 0·057 for 32P and only 0·014 for 33P. These results indicate that the great bulk of 32P lethalities in this phage at - 196°C are due to DSB's resulting from nuclear recoil. Killing by either isotope is increased when storage is at 4°C; and the presence of 2-aminoethylisothiouronium (AET) gives partial protection against killing at 4°C. However, the induction of DSB's by 32P decay is little affected by these variables or by storage as extracted DNA versus intact phage, all as predicted if DSB's result primarily from nuclear recoil. © 1974 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.

Title: Apparent Efficiency and Storage of Elastic Energy in Human Muscles during Exercise
Affiliations: Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Asmussen, E., Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark; Bonde‐Petersen, F., Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: 3 subjects ran on the treadmill (10 km/h) against varying horizontal impeding forces. One subject was further studied during the same kind of walking and bicycling on the treadmill, and during work consisting in lowering and lifting the body by flexing and extending the legs from a standing or sitting position at varying frequencies, with or without rebound in the deepest position. Workpower (W kcal/min), and the corresponding steady state metabolic rate (E kcal/min, Douglas bag method) were measured. Apparent efficiency (N) was calculated as Δẁ/ΔÈ× 100 %. During load running N was 53.8, 37.6 and 41.2 %, respectively, in the 3 subjects. In the subject more extensively studied N was: running 53.8, walking 32.3, bicycling 25.1, knee‐flexions (deep or half) with rebound 39.4 or 41.0, without rebound 26.1 or 21.9 %. These variations in N % were explained in accordance with the possibilities for re‐using the energy, absorbed and stored in the muscles as elastic energy during a phase of negative exercise, in a subsequent phase of positive exercise. The condition of this is that the positive phase follows immediately after the negative. A calculation showed that during running 35–53 % of the energy absorbed during the negative phase was re‐used. Corresponding figures for walking and rebounding knee‐extensions were 23 % and 34 %, respectively, while in bicycling and knee‐extensions without rebound all of the negative work degenerated into heat. © 1974 Scandinavian Physiological Society

Title: Storage of Elastic Energy in Skeletal Muscles in Man
Affiliations: Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Asmussen, E., Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark; Bonde‐Petersen, F., Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: The question, if muscles can absorb and temporarily store mechanical energy in the form of elastic energy for later re‐use, was studied by having subjects perform maximal vertical jumps on a registering force‐platform. The jumps were performed 1) from a semi‐squatting position, 2) after a natural counter‐movement from a standing position, or 3) in continuation of jumps down from heights of 0.23, 0.40, or 0.69 m. The heights of the jumps were calculated from the registered flight times. The maximum energy level, Eneg, of the jumpers prior to the upward movement in the jump, was considered to be zero in condition 1. In condition 2 it was calculated from the force‐time record of the force‐platform; and in condition 3 it was calculated from the height of the downward jump and the weight of the subject. The maximum energy level after take‐off, Ep0s, was calculated from the height of the jump and the jumper's weight. It was found that the height of the jump and Epos increased with increasing amounts of Eneg, up to a certain level (jumping down from 0.40 m). The gains in Epos over that in condition 1, were expressed as a percentage of Eneg and found to be 22.9 % in condition 2, and 13.2, 10.5, and 3.3 % in the three situations of condition 3. It is suggested that the elastic energy is stored in the active muscles, and it is demonstrated that the muscles of the legs are activated in the downward jumps before contact with the platform is established. © 1974 Scandinavian Physiological Society

Abstract: The theory that current supply of readily used energy is the primary control in feeding is embodied in a computer model of energy flows from the gut and to or from storage as fat. Authors: Nadel E.R., Holmer I., Bergh U., Astrand P.O., Stolwijk J.A.
Title: Energy exchanges of swimming man
Affiliations: Dept. Physiol., Gymnastik Idrottshogsk., Nat. Board Occup. Safety Hlth, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Nadel, E.R., Dept. Physiol., Gymnastik Idrottshogsk., Nat. Board Occup. Safety Hlth, Stockholm, Sweden; Holmer, I., Dept. Physiol., Gymnastik Idrottshogsk., Nat. Board Occup. Safety Hlth, Stockholm, Sweden; Bergh, U., Dept. Physiol., Gymnastik Idrottshogsk., Nat. Board Occup. Safety Hlth, Stockholm, Sweden; Astrand, P.O.; Stolwijk, J.A.
Abstract: Three male swimmers underwent 10 min resting and 20 min swimming (breaststroke) exposures in a swimming flume. Water temperatures in separate exposure were 18, 26, and 33°C. At each water temperature the subjects rested and swam at water velocities of 0.50, 0.75, and 0.95 m.s-1, which were designed to produce around 40, 70, and 100% of maximal aerobic power. Measurements were made of esophageal temperature [T(es)], four skin temperatures, water temperature, heat flow from five local skin surfaces (Hatfield Turner discs), and oxygen uptake (VO2). Calculations were made of mean area weighted skin temperature [T(s)] and heat flow, metabolic rate, and heat storage. Internal body temperature changes after 20 min of swimming were related to water temperature, swimming intensity and body composition. VO2 was proportional to swimming speed during submaximal efforts in any water temperature, but the increase in VO2 per increment in swimming speed became greater as the swimmer approached his maximal effort. VO2 was also greater in 18°C than in 26°C water at any submaximal swimming speed and likewise greater in 26°C than in 33°C water. Increased cost of swimming in cold water was largely attributed to shivering. The convective heat transfer coefficient was calculated from heat flow and skin and water temperature data and was found to be 230 W.m-2.°C-1 at rest in still water, 460 W.m-2.°C-1 at rest in moving water, and 580 W.m-2.°C-1 while swimming, regardless of swimming speed. Core-to-skin conductances were primarily related to internal temperature, although there appeared to be a minor effect of T(s) modifying this relation.

Title: I. Hanford atomic products operation, January to December 1970
Abstract: The primary mission at the Hanford site of the Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) has been the production of plutonium. Activities have included nuclear fuel fabrication, plutonium production and test reactor operation, chemical separations of irradiated fuels, laboratory support and research, waste storage and disposal, and plant support operations. In recent years, privately owned facilities located within the Hanford site boundaries have included a power generating station, an office building, and a radioactive waste burial site. The purpose of this annual report is to present an evaluation of the combined offsite effects of the radioactive effluents released to uncontrolled areas by all Hanford contractors during 1970.

Authors: Bojsen J., Moller U., Lippert J.
Title: Telemetry of radionuclide tracers by implantable thermoluminescent dosimeters on rats
Affiliations: Finsen Lab., Finsen Inst., Copenhagen
Authors with affiliations: Bojsen, J., Finsen Lab., Finsen Inst., Copenhagen; Moller, U., Finsen Lab., Finsen Inst., Copenhagen; Lippert, J., Finsen Lab., Finsen Inst., Copenhagen
Abstract: This report deals with the problem of the continuous detection of radionuclide tracers on unrestrained experimental animals. A new implantable storage telemetry transducer is presented which both detects and stores the radiated energy from the radionuclide disintegrations. A method was developed for the continuous detection of the 32P uptake in DMBA induced breast tumors in rats. As the 32P uptake is dependent on the metabolism of the tumor through the day, the measurements had to be performed on unrestrained rats. The method is based on 2 types of measuring equipment: 2 thermoluminescent dosimeters (CaSO4:Dy), one for the tumor and one for the normal tissue, are fixed in a polyethylene catheter, which is introduced through an implanted catheter (total weight: 1.2 g). The dosimeters can be replaced at will. Phantom measurements show an uncertainty of ±2%; an implanted radiotelemetric temperature transmitter (±0.05°C; weight: 4.5 g) measures continuously the circadian temperature rhythm, which expresses the physiological condition of the animal. The possibility of in vivo measurements with β emitters like 35S and 14C is discussed.

Title: The Platelet Response to Hypotonic Shock. Its Value as an Indicator of Platelet Viability After Storage
Affiliations: Division of Hematologic Research, The Memorial Hospital, Pawtucket, Rhode Island, United States; Brown University, Division of Biological and Medical Sciences, Providence, Rhode Island, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, B.K., Division of Hematologic Research, The Memorial Hospital, Pawtucket, Rhode Island, United States, Brown University, Division of Biological and Medical Sciences, Providence, Rhode Island, United States; Baldini, M.G., Division of Hematologic Research, The Memorial Hospital, Pawtucket, Rhode Island, United States, Brown University, Division of Biological and Medical Sciences, Providence, Rhode Island, United States
Abstract: The nature of the platelet response to osmotic shock and its relationship to platelet viability were studied. Light absorbancy changes of human platelet concentrates exposed to hypotonic shock were measured in a spectrophotometer: a sudden drop of light absorbancy was followed by a reversal of light absorbancy towards normal (reversal reaction). It was confirmed that the reversal reaction is a complex phenomenon dependent on the integrity of biochemical and enzymatic functions of the platelets. It was suppressed by glycolytic inhibitors and by SH‐blocking agents. Ouabain had no immediate effect, but with prolonged incubation it depressed the reaction. Suspension of the platelets in a protein‐free medium caused a rapid loss of the reversal reaction. Disappearance of the marginal bundle of microtubules by exposure to colchicine did not change the reaction leading to the hypothesis that microfibrils rather than the microtubules may have been responsible for the reversal reaction. The conclusion was derived that the reversal reaction is due to cell volume contraction for which integrity of the platelet contractile protein and energy availability are essential. Platelet storage at 4 C or at 22 C caused a progressive depression of the reversal reaction which was more severe in platelets preserved at 4 C than in those preserved at 22 C, and paralleled the loss of the platelet capacity to survive in vivo. Cryo‐protective agents (DMSO, DMAC and glycerol) partially inhibited the reversal reaction. Freezing with these agents caused a more severe depression of the reaction. The least depression was observed with 5 per cent DMSO. The results demonstrated that the reversal reaction is a valid and accurate in vitro indicator of in vivo platelet viability when the results to be compared are limited to a single method of storage. Usefulness of the reversal reaction is reduced when results obtained with different methods of storage are compared. 1974 AABB

Title: Waste management - licensing and criteria
Affiliations: US Atom. Energy Comm., Direct. Licens., Washington, D.C. 20545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smiley, S.H., US Atom. Energy Comm., Direct. Licens., Washington, D.C. 20545, United States
Abstract: Waste management is a topic of great importance to industry and the general public, and one that receives a great deal of attention within the regulatory organization. The regulated fuel cycle includes uranium milling, UF6 conversion, fuel fabrication, chemical reprocessing of spent reactor fuel, transportation of nuclear materials, and waste disposal. Management of radioactive waste generated in the nuclear fuel cycle is of particular interest now. A number of policy decisions must be made in the near future and then implemented as regulatory requirements. These decisions must receive public acceptance for safety and protection of environmental values. The main issues pertain to management of high level waste, management of plutonium bearing waste (including the fuel cladding hulls from reprocessed fuel), stabilization and long term control of mill tailings, and the application of the 'as low as practicable' concept of fuel cycle effluents in light of the current status of technology. Two important studies are presently being carried out by the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission. The first involves the assessment of the environmental effects of utilizing plutonium fuel in light water reactors; the second is an environmental analysis of the nuclear fuel cycle associated with high temperature gas cooled reactor operations. Waste management is significantly represented and evaluated in each of these studies.

Authors: Winn C.B., Johnson G.R., Corder T.E.
Title: SIMSHAC-a simulation program for solar heating and cooling of buildings
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado 80521, United States
Authors with affiliations: Winn, C.B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado 80521, United States; Johnson, G.R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado 80521, United States; Corder, T.E., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado 80521, United States
Abstract: A dynamic simulation model for use in analyzing the performance of specific designs of solar-heated-and- cooled buildings has been developed. The name of the program is SIMSHAC, an acronym for SImulation Model for Solar-Heated-And-Cooled buildings. To use the design program, one has merely to specify the components (that is, each subsystem; for example, collectors, storage units, splitting and mixing valves, house heating and cooling loads, auxiliary heating, auxiliary cooling, heat exchanger, etc.), and the manner in which they are connected and all initial conditions. Program SIMSHAC then writes the program for the specific system to be analyzed. Each subsystem is described by a set of time-dependent differential equations or, possibly, algebraic equations. System state variables include tempera ture, mass flow rate, and enthalpy. The model can handle three types of incident solar radiation data models. These are (1) deterministic (e.g., an algebraic-equation sun model), (2) random simulation (e.g., a model based upon cloud-cover statistics), and (3) actual tabulated input information based upon collected solar data for a specific site. The model has been used for the analysis of five different types of buildings in five locations within the United States. The types include single-family residences, small businesses, three-story apartments, schools, and mobile homes. The locations considered are Atlanta, Georgia; Madison, Wisconsin; Wilmington, Delaware; Mobile, Alabama; and Santa Maria, California. The program has also been used to simulate the solar- heated-and-cooled experimental laboratory presently being built by the National Science Foundation on the campus at Colorado State University. © 1974, Sage Publications. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING; HEATING - Solar; COMPUTER SIMULATION; SOLAR ENERGY; building industry; computer analysis; energy; environmental health; model; money; simulator

Title: Compact high-voltage accelerators of charged particles in space experiments
Affiliations: Institute for Pure and Applied Mechanics, USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Ponomarenko, A.G., Institute for Pure and Applied Mechanics, USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Soloukhin, R.I., Institute for Pure and Applied Mechanics, USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Some general problems of design and application of compact devices for the generation of pulse electric fields at a megavolt range in space experiments are discussed. The prospect of various applications of powerful electron beams for active diagnostics of upper layers of atmosphere, radiation belts and the earth's magnetic field is also reviewed. The proposed development of powerful impulsive devices is dictated by limitations of energy resources in spacecraft together with a need to get a good signal-to-noise ratio for reliable data recording. Compact devices which directly transform electric energy of a low-voltage source (solar batteries, chemical elements, nuclear reactor, etc.), into the energy of a megavolt charge particle beam of high impulsive power appear as reliable means for satisfying these requirements. In this paper, the basic practical schemes of energy transformation procedures are considered and the optimal operation parameters of high-voltage storage and transformer systems are discussed. Proper application of combined high-voltage insulation techniques result in the development of experimental models of heavy-current electron beam accelerators capable of generating beams of 300-500 kV, 3-5 kA, with a pulse duration of 15 × 10-9 sec at a frequency of 10 Hz. Typical applications of electron beam accelerators including the generator of electron-beam-controlled discharge laser beams are also described. © 1974.
Index Keywords: EARTH ATMOSPHERE; ELECTRON BEAMS; ACCELERATORS

Title: Field Performance of Steam and Hot Water Electric Boilers
Affiliations: Edwin L. Wiegand Division of the Emerson Electric Company, Pittsburgh, Pa. 15208, United States; L. G. Spielvogel, Inc., Consulting Engineers, Wyncote Pa. 19095, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wallace, W.D.; Spielvogel, L.G., L. G. Spielvogel, Inc., Consulting Engineers, Wyncote Pa. 19095, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses observations on electric steam and hot-water boilers. The increased popularity of both steam and hot water generation by electricity is readily apparent. The advantages of this type of heat generation lend themselves to many current applications in the heating, ventilating, and air conditioning field. Sizes of boilers have been increasing through the years, with no apparent end in sight due to the accelerated development of the electrode boiler, which will be covered in detail in the second part of the paper. As compared to the resistance type of boiler, this latter design permits economical projection into much larger boiler sizes. Electric boiler installation is relatively simple since there is no concern with chimneys or fuel storage. Often the boiler room can be eliminated and the mechanical equipment room serve as the required space. Electric boiler operation can be automated to the point where an operator is virtually unnecessary with the many control options available today. Integration of the boiler into heat recovery and solar energy systems has also accelerated the growth of this product. As might be expected, due to the simplicity of boiler construction and accessories, electric boiler maintenance is at a minimum. However, certain areas of additional control must be exercised since unique problems can develop with electric steam and hot water generation. The paper is illustrated with pictures of actual installations and case histories covering the gamut of specification, installation, and successful operation. The future of the electric boiler and its application to contemporary ideas of high-voltage ac is covered together with the misapplications and possible drawbacks of electric steam and hot water generation. © 1974 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: BOILERS

Authors: Ramakumar R., Allison H.J., Hughes W.L.
Title: Prospects for tapping solar energy on a large scale
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74074, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ramakumar, R., School of Electrical Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74074, United States; Allison, H.J., School of Electrical Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74074, United States; Hughes, W.L., School of Electrical Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74074, United States
Abstract: As a result of the energy conversion and storage research underway at Oklahoma State University since 1961, several components needed to engineer a continuous-duty energy system operating on replenishable solar energy have been developed to the prototype stage and are being tested. This paper presents and discusses these components and how they fit together in the solar energy systems envisioned for the long-term and immediate future. A simplified economic analysis of solar energy systems is presented, and the calculated generation costs are compared with those of conventional fuel burning systems for different fuel costs, load factors and interest rates. One result of this study is that wind energy systems, costing $125 to $150 per installed kW and pumping power directly into a.c. mains for 20 per cent of the time using the field-modulated generating systems developed at OSU, are competitive with conventional systems costing $250 to $350 per installed kW operating at a load factor of 80 per cent and fuel cost of $0·50 per MBtu. More such comparisons are included in the text of the paper. © 1974.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY

Title: An AC Drive Electric Vehicle
Affiliations: Linear Alpha, Inc., Skokie Ill., United States
Authors with affiliations: Wakefield, E.H., Linear Alpha, Inc., Skokie Ill., United States
Abstract: This paper indicates the market for a van-type electric vehicle, provides the physical description, and presents the electrical principle of operation of a frequency modulated and pulsewidth modulated power system applied to a 27-kW three-phase squirrel-cage induction motor. This ac drive system, which represents the third generation in design, has been placed in a Dodge B-300 high production van of 2700 kg gross vehicle weight. The electrical energy is stored in 24 6-V 220-Ah batteries providing 144 V. Design speeds of the electronics for the vehicle are up to 90 km/h. Computer developed power factor and efficiency curves are given for the motor for the entire range of operating speeds. Electrical charge in the batteries may be replaced either by quick interchange of batteries or through utilization of a 12-kg on-board charger with an electrical demand of 6 kW from a 220-V single-phase main. Finally, the paper discusses the economics of the ac drive Linear Van. Copyright © 1974 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: Recording Facility with Magnetic-Tape Cartridge Unit and Central Data Evaluator. [REGISTRIEREINRICHTUNG MIT MAGNETBANDKASSETT ENSPEICHER UND ZENTRALER DATENAUSWERTEEINRICHTUNG.]
Authors with affiliations: Gottstein, Herbert
Abstract: The author describes a recording facility with magnetic-tape cartridge unit and the associated data evaluator with magnetic-tape cartridge reader. Simple documentation by recorder diagrams, modern tape recordings of the analog and digital measured values, and evaluation of the data by a cartridge reader with connection facilities for X-Y recorders, digital printers and data processing equipment combine ideally to form a reasonably-priced equipment combination. The facility holds promise of successful application in industry, environmental control or the monitoring of energy consumption.
Index Keywords: Data storage, Magnetic

Title: A study of digitally recorded transitions in thin magnetic films
Affiliations: University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minn. 55455, United States; 3M Comapny, 3M Center, St. Paul, Minn. 55101, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dressler, D.D., University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minn. 55455, United States, 3M Comapny, 3M Center, St. Paul, Minn. 55101, United States; Judy, J.H., University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minn. 55455, United States
Abstract: Digital recordings were placed on thin magnetic films which covered a range of coercivities and thicknesses. The details of the resulting transitions between bits were observed by transmission electron microscopy and found to be defined by cross-tie walls in a saw-tooth like structure (STS). This is unlike the magnetization distributions assumed by most recording theories. The theories of several other researchers, based on their observations of STS could not explain the results observed in this work. This is due to theoretical energy expressions based on magnetization distributions somewhat different from those observed here. The STS tip angle was found to be proportional to Hc-0.5. The STS amplitude was proportional to film thickness times Hc-1.5. Attempts at formulating a theory to explain these results were not successful. Title: Transition currents, power loss and effective resistance in small superconducting coils
Affiliations: Bell Northern Research, Ottawa, Canada; University of Waterloo, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kugler, J., Bell Northern Research, Ottawa, Canada; Ramshaw, R.S., University of Waterloo, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: In the experimental part of the work, various small superconducting coils made of hard superconducting materials are energized by linearly increasing currents at rates of change ranging from zero to several thousand amperes per second causing maximum magnetic fields up to several thousand kiloamperes per meter. The energy changes cause the superconducting coils to go to a normal state when the current reaches a “dynamic” transition value. The transition currents are experimentally measured. Further, energy and power dissipated in the superconducting coils are calculated thus enabling the effective resistance of the superconducting coil material to be determined. The knowledge of the effective resistance can contribute to the prediction of the efficiency of energy transferl from superconducting storage coils. Affiliations: IBM Research Center, Yorktown Heights, N. Y. 10598, United States

Y. 10598, United States; Powers, J.V., IBM Research Center, Yorktown Heights, N. Y. 10598, United States
Abstract: In GdCoMo amorphous film bubble devices the drive field required for device operation has been found to be linearly dependent on the saturation magnetization of the bubble material over the range from 350 to 1200G. The devices studied were 8000 bit storage chips employing electron-beam-fabricated T-bars, Y-bars, and chevrons of 1μm linewidth. The bubble domain diameter and film thickness were approximately 2μm in all devices. The linear increase in drive field with 4πMsis found to be related with the energy required to move a bubble from one permalloy pattern to another across a gap. On the other hand, the field required to overcome coercivity in the movement of a bubble without leaving a single permalloy T-bar is found to be independent of variations in 4πMsof the bubble material. Title: Role of composting in waste utilization
Affiliations: Environm. Managem. Program, UCLA Sch. Publ. Hlth., Los Angeles, Calif., United States
Authors with affiliations: Senn, C.L., Environm. Managem. Program, UCLA Sch. Publ. Hlth., Los Angeles, Calif., United States
Abstract: The current U.S. policy of promoting and practicing resource recovery and high cattle good and fertilizer prices are focusing attention on utilization rather than disposal of organic wastes. This article discusses the role of composting as a basic part of the new programs which are necessary to accomplish both the national conservation and pollution control objectives. It is felt that composting is destined to be rediscovered as an efficient, economical, environmentally acceptable method of processing human and animal wastes. The process enables raising cattle in enclosed, non water polluting housing and feeding facilities. It enables production of an attractive soil amendment. However, in the current period of recycling, energy recovery, and utilization rather than disposal, composting can be a key element in preparing wastes for efficient storage, handling, transportation and utilization as a feed, a source of energy and a soil amendment.The current national policy of promoting and practicing resource recovery and high cattle food and fertilizer prices is discussed and composting is destined to be ″rediscovered″ as an efficient, economical, environmentally acceptable method of processing human and animal wastes.
Index Keywords: Waste disposal; Refuse disposal; environmental health

Title: High density image storage holograms by a random phase sampling method
Affiliations: Cent. Res. Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tsunoda, Y., Cent. Res. Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Takeda, Y., Cent. Res. Lab., Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The random phase sampling method that has been proposed to make high-quality and high-storage density holograms capable of storing image information is described and discussed from the aspect of the quantitative characteristics of its reconstructed image. The method enables the uniform distribution of light energy over the hologram area made on the exact Fourier transformed plane. The details of the characteristics of the method are investigated, especially with respect to the luminance tone linearity, the signal-to-noise ratio, and the resolution to give good agreement with the results of a calculation.The random phase sampling method that has been proposed to make high quality and high storage density holograms capable of storing image information is described and discussed from the aspect of the quantitative characteristics of its reconstructed image. The method enables the uniform distribution of light energy over the hologram area made on the exact Fourier transformed plane. The details of the characteristics of the method are investigated, especially with respect to the luminance tone linearity, the signal to noise ratio, and the resolution to give good agreement with the results of a calculation. In the experiment, reconstructed images with high quality were obtained from holograms of 2 mm diam, which were made by 106 sampling and random phase shifting. By using the random phase sampling method, an image retrieval model system storing 20 kinds of information was developed. This system holds promise of being used in various practical applications such as a holographic ultramicrofilm system or a holographic videopackage system.

Title: Flight qualified pulsed electric thruster for satellite control
Affiliations: MIT Lincoln Laboratory, Space Communications Division, Lexinyton, MA, United States; Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, CTR Division, Los Alamos, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vondra, R.J., MIT Lincoln Laboratory, Space Communications Division, Lexinyton, MA, United States; Thomasse, K.I., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, CTR Division, Los Alamos, NM, United States
Abstract: A solid fuel pulsed plasma thruster (PPT) has been designed, built, and flight qualified for the LES-8/9 program (due to be launched in March 1975). The satellite attitude control system will contain six PPTs for orbit acquisition, east-west stationkeeping, three-axis attitude control, and station changes. Each thruster has fuel for 7320N-S (1645 Ib-sec) total impulse and at 25 w generates 300 µN (67 µlb) thrust at 1000 sec specific impulse. Two prototype thrusters have passed flight qualification shock and vibration tests and operational lifetime ( > 34 million discharges or 10,460 N-sec). Important thruster components are discussed such as the design, fabrication, and testing of an 11 joule/kg (5 joule Ib) energy storage capacitor which has an extrapolated life of 100 billion discharges in thruster operation. Capacitor reliability at 41 joule/kg (18.8 joule/lb) was also tested and the results are given here. The spark plug design and its effect on thruster performance is examined. The plug causes a "periodic" variation in thrust and specific impulse. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1974, All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Electric and advanced space propulsion

Title: Electronic Tuning of Stable Transferred Electron Oscillators
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Leeds, Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dean, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Leeds, Leeds, United Kingdom; Howes, M.J., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Leeds, Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: The problem of electronic tuning of microwave oscillator structures characterized by high energy storage and hence low noise is considered. The evolution of a wide-band varactor tuned J-band oscillator is described, and analytical criteria are presented which determine the position of the varactor diode and the theoretical maximum tuning range available including varactor loss. Experimental results confirm the validity of the circuit model used for the proposed oscillator structures. Copyright © 1974 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
