Title: Chemical and nutritive changes in herring meal during storage at different temperatures with and without antioxidant treatment
Source title: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture
Affiliations: Department of Poultry Science, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada
Authors with affiliations: El‐Lakany, S., Department of Poultry Science, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada; March, B.E., Department of Poultry Science, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada
Abstract: Herring meals prepared with and without the addition of 0.025% of 1,2‐dihydro‐6‐ethoxy‐2,2,4‐trimethylquinoline (EQ) were stored for ten months at ‐20 ºC and 21 ºC. Storage changes in the biologically determined energy and protein values of the meals were monitored and related to changes in the chemical characteristics of the meal. Antioxidant treatment stabilised the meal lipid against oxidative changes resulting in loss of solubility, decline in iodine value and formation of peroxides and malonaldehyde. The effect of storage temperature on the course of oxidation depended upon whether the meal was treated with EQ. Lipid in meals without EQ tended to show greater change early in the storage period at ‐20 ºC. Antioxidant‐treated meals showed protection of the protein against changes leading to reduced digestibility and lysine availability. Either antioxidant treatment or storage at ‐20 ºC protected the biological availability of the energy‐supplying nutrients present in the meal. Copyright © 1974 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd

Title: Photocatalytic hydrogen production: A solar energy conversion alternative?
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tri-State College, Angola, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paleocrassas, S.N., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tri-State College, Angola, IN, United States
Abstract: Since the beginning of earth, ultra-violet rays from the sun have been splitting water molecules in the upper reaches of the atmosphere, producing hydrogen and oxygen. At the same time, photosynthesis has been sustaining life on earth by utilizing the longer wavelengths of sunlight to split carbon and water molecules forming carbohydrates and oxygen. Attempts are being made to imitate these processes for the purpose of harnessing solar energy for man's use. This paper presents a state-of-the-art review of photolysis of water by sunlight with consequent energy storage in the molecular bonds of hydrogen and oxygen. The photocatalytic solar energy conversion methods reviewed are classified according to the photosensitizer type. That includes catalysts such as compound salts, compound semi-conductor crystals and photosynthetic dyes. An assessment of these methods concludes that photolysis of water as a solar energy conversion process does not seem feasible at present or for the immediate future. On the other hand, efficiency estimates indicate that with research emphasis this unconventional energy conversion method may prove to be a long-term alternative in harnessing solar energy for man's use. © 1974.
Index Keywords: CATALYSTS; SOLAR RADIATION; ENERGY CONVERSION; PHOTOCATALYTIC HYDROGEN PRODUCTION; PHOTOLYSIS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Holographic Storage in Quadratic PLZT Ceramics

Abstract: Photoinduced changes in refractive index in a quadratic electrooptic PLZT ceramic were observed. Thick‐phase holograms were recorded with high diffraction efficiency (η∼ 0.10 to 0.50). The dependencies of the diffraction efficiency on the density of light energy and applied field were determined. The observed amplification effect is explained in terms of photoinduced electrical field components and the quadratic electrooptic properties of the ceramic. Copyright © 1974, Wiley Blackwell. Title: Alternate fuels for transportation. Part 2: hydrogen for the automobile
Affiliations: Los Alamos Sci. Lab., Univ. California, Los Alamos, N.M., United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart, W.F., Los Alamos Sci. Lab., Univ. California, Los Alamos, N.M., United States; Edeskuty, F.J., Los Alamos Sci. Lab., Univ. California, Los Alamos, N.M., United States
Abstract: Hydrogen may be an excellent replacement for the world's dwindling automotive gasoline supply. It offers an unlimited pollution-free closed-cycle system when produced by the electrolysis of water and burned with O//2. Conventional internal-combustion engines have been operated on hydrogen fuel with almost no pollution and with increased engine efficiency. An even greater reduction of pollution and a higher engine efficiency can be provided by an engine designed specifically for hydrogen fuel.Increasing demands for energy combined with a limited hydrocarbon fuel supply and an increasing demand for reduced pollution have resulted in the energy crisis. The use of hydrogen as a fuel plays a prominent role in many of the proposed solutions to these problems. H2 may be an excellent replacement for the world's dwindling automotive gasoline supply. It offers an unlimited pollution free closed cycle system when produced by the electrolysis of water and burned with O2. Conventional internal combustion engines have been operated on hydrogen fuel with almost no pollution and with increased engine efficiency. An even greater reduction of pollution and a higher engine efficiency can be provided by an engine designed specifically for hydrogen fuel. However, some problems are still being encountered with the storage and refilling of H2 fuel tanks, and developing an overall H2 production and distribution system.

Title: Trapping, emission and generation in MNOS memory devices
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, University of Toronto, Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wei, L.S., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Toronto, Toronto, Canada; Simmons, J.G., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Toronto, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: This study is concerned with trapping phenomena occuring at the semiconductor-oxide interface and in the nitride layer of variable-threshold metal-nitride-oxide-semiconductor (MNOS) memory devices. The technique consits of biasing the device in such a manner as to charge or discharge either the interface traps or the nitride traps, or both sets of traps simultaneously. The device is then cooled to low temperature with the bias still applied, and at the low temperature the biasing condition is changed, in order to induce the device into a non-steady mode that is quasi-stable at the low temperature. The temperature of the device is then raised at a constant rate, and the resulting current vs temperature (I-T) characteristics is found to be rich in structure. By means of a series of systematic experiments the various portions of the I-T characteristic are identified with emission of electrons from interface states and the nitride traps, and surface generation. From this data the energy distribution of interface states is determied. It is shown that the memory charge in the nitride is distributed throughout the nitride, and temporary memory charge and semi-permanent memory charge are distinguished. © 1974.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Title: Vacuum Insulation for Cryocables and Its Resistance to Discharges
Affiliations: Francis Bitter National Magnet Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass. 02139, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass., United States
Authors with affiliations: Graneau, P., Francis Bitter National Magnet Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass. 02139, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass., United States
Abstract: A test length of a liquid-nitrogen-cooled vacuum-insulated coaxial cable for use in underground power transmission has been studied with respect to its high-voltage insulation properties. The critical element in the cable is the spacer between the conductors, since electrical discharges in the system are easily initiated across this spacer. Previous experiments with voltage sources capable of supplying low currents indicated insignificant discharge damage to the spacer as long as inorganic materials were used. The new results given in this paper show that insulator damage may still be small for discharges with peak current amplitudes up to 40 kA. The discharge current was supplied by an energy storage capacitor bank for a large number of tests with the same spacer. In addition to current measurements, photographic records of the discharges are presented, and an assessment of the damage to the insulator and conductors is given. Authors with affiliations: Staebler, D.L., RCA Laboratories, Princeton, NJ, 08540, United States; Phillips, W., RCA Laboratories, Princeton, NJ, 08540, United States
Abstract: High erase sensitivity is observed in heavily reduced crystals of Fe-doped LiNbO3. Only 12 mJ/cm2 of incident 4880-Å radiation erases a hologram, nearly 3 orders of magnitude less energy than previously required. However, the maximum diffraction efficiency that can be reached in these crystals is substantially reduced. These results are shown to be consistent with an extremely low density of Fe3+ ions. The crystals are resistant to optical scattering effects usually observed in Fe-doped LiNbO3. © 1974 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Gutierrez G., Hincapie F., Duffie J.A., Beckman W.A.
Title: Simulation of forced circulation water heaters; effects of auxiliary energy supply, load type and storage capacity
Affiliations: The Solar Energy Laboratory, The University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States

Abstract: A hybrid computer was used to simulate forced circulation solar water heater systems using stratified storage. A single month of hourly meteorological data was used to examine the effects of three types of auxiliary heating systems and three different sized tanks. Various time distributions and magnitudes of the load were studied. Results are shown in terms of the ratio of auxiliary energy requirements to total load and indicate best methods for adding auxiliary energy to maximize solar energy gain. © 1974.

Authors: Das G.C., Platakis N.S., Bever M.B.
Title: A thermodynamic and kinetic investigation of amorphous (1-x)As2Se3 · xSb2Se3 alloys
Affiliations: Department of Metallurgy and Materials Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Das, G.C., Department of Metallurgy and Materials Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Platakis, N.S., Department of Metallurgy and Materials Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Bever, M.B., Department of Metallurgy and Materials Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Abstract: The heats of formation of amorphous (1-x)As2Se3 · xSb2Se3 (x = 0 to 0.4) referred to crystalline As2Se3 and Sb2Se3 were measured by liquid metal solution calorimetry. The values of heats of formation of amorphous (1-x)As2Se3 · xSb2Se3 decreased from 1.39 ± 0.03 kcal · (g-at)-1 at x = 0 to 1.27 ± 0.04 kcal · (g-at)-1 at x = 0.4. The glass transition temperature and the temperatures of the maximum rates of crystallization and fusion were measured by differential scanning calorimetry. The glass transition temperature increased and the temperatures of the maximum rates of crystallization and fusion decreased with increasing Sb2Se3 content. The relaxation process in amorphous (1-x)As2Se3 · xSb2Se (x = 0.3) was investigated by measuring changes in microhardness, small-angle X-ray scattering and heat capacity with time of annealing at several temperatures ranging from room temperature to 413 K. With increasing annealing time the microhardness, the height and the temperature of the glass transition peak increased whereas the intensity of small-angle X-ray scattering decreased. These changes reflect relaxation towards a more stable structure of smaller molecular mobility. The changes in the enthalpy with annealing time and the activation energy spectra for relaxation were derived from the heat capacity data. The effects of temperature and time of annealing on the various properties are explained in terms of structural changes and relaxation kinetics. © 1974.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL; GLASS - X-Ray Analysis; ARSENIC SELENIUM ANTIMONY ALLOYS

Authors: Field R., Struzeski Jr E.J., Masters H.E., Tafuri A.N.
Title: Water pollution and associated effects from street salting
Authors with affiliations: Field, R.; Struzeski Jr, E.J.; Masters, H.E.; Tafuri, A.N.
Abstract: This paper comprises a state-of-the-art review of highway deicing practices and associated environmental effects, and offers a critical summary of the available information on methods, equipment, and materials used for snow and ice removal; chlorides found in rainfall and municipal sewage during the winter; salt runoff from streets and highways; deicing compounds found in surface streams, public water supplies, ground water, farm ponds, and lakes; special nutritious or toxic additives incorporated into deicing agents; vehicular corrosion and deterioration of highway structures and pavements attributable to salting; and effects of deicing compounds on roadside soils, vegetation, and trees.The bare pavement policy has resulted in a great increase in the use of deicing salts. They are more efficient and economical than abrasives. However, there is excessive application leading to environmental problems. Besides chemical melting, various methods for deicing exist. Some of these are stationary and mobile thermal melting units, alternate deicing compounds, snow adhesion reducing pavements, electromagnetic energy for ice shattering, and drainage systems designed to capture snowmelt for treatment of control. Salt storage facilities often become a major contributing source of local groundwater and surface water salt contamination. Coverage of salt piles is becoming chloride prevalent. High chloride concentration levels have been found in roadway runoff. The special additives in deicing salts may create more severe pollutional problems than the chloride salts.
Index Keywords: ROADS AND STREETS - Snow and Ice Control; WATER RESOURCES - Underground; DEICING; WATER QUALITY; Water pollution; environmental health

Title: Life tests of SSI integrated circuits
Affiliations: Industrial Research Institute for Electronics HIKI, Budapest, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Kemény, A.P., Industrial Research Institute for Electronics HIKI, Budapest, Hungary
Abstract: Some results as well as a new and simple method of digital IC life testing are dealt with here referring to the beginning of a large-scale test programme which started 2 yr ago. As the first step, bipolar SSI digital IC-s of the TTL, DTL and RTL series have been considered comprising about 60 million device-hr, life-tested by various long-run stress methods as temperature storage, d.c.-and switching-service operational tests to gain a fair picture on main failure mechanisms, the nature and shift tendencies of parameter distributions as well as on the activation energy of degradation processes-besides the estimation of characteristic failure rates in various stress forms-to facilitate the use of accelerated methods and to rendering possible the optimal choice among testing methods for future reliability assessment work. It has been shown that temperature activation energies of approx. 1·0 eV-essentially the same as at discrete planar transistors-are resulted if "side" effects of experiments are carefully avoided. © 1974.
Index Keywords: INTEGRATED CIRCUIT TESTING; radioisotope; integrated circuit; operational amplifier

Authors: Lutz M.A., Hofmann G.A., Lutz M.A., Hofmann G.A.
Title: The Gamitron - A High Power Crossed-Field Switch Tube for HVDC Interruption
Affiliations: Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lutz, M.A., Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States, Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States; Hofmann, G.A., Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States, Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States; Lutz, M.A., Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States, Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States; Hofmann, G.A., Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States, Hughes Research Laboratories, 3011 Malibu Canyon Road, Malibu, California 90265, United States
Abstract: A high power crossed-field discharge device has been developed for use as a high voltage direct current interrupter. This device operates at low pressure (0.05 Torr), conducting current at a fixed voltage (~500 V) only in the presence of a weak magnetic field (~100 G) which is substantially perpendicular to the electric field between the electrodes. When the magnetic field is removed, ionization ceases and current interruption results. Physical phenomena occurring in this device have been investigated, including the glow-to-arc transition, gas cleanup, and high voltage breakdown. Based on the results of these investigations, switch tubes have been developed and successfully tested at the 2 kA, 100 kV level, with recovery rates in excess of 2 kV/μs. The availability of such devices will make possible many applications including HVDC circuit breakers, ac current limiters, and practical inductive energy storage. Copyright © 1974 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: GAMITRON; ELECTRON TUBES, GAS DISCHARGE

Title: Thermoluminescence of electron‐irradiated CaF2
Affiliations: Materials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Rao, D.R., Materials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Abstract: Storage of excitation energy in CaF2 crystals, irradiated by low energy electrons, is found to be very much less as compared to that obtained by X‐ray irradiation; the TL (thermoluminescence) yield is, in general, very poor for all the temperatures of excitation between 300 and 500 °K. While the crystal, excited by electrons at RT, shows a complex distribution of glow maxima in the temperature region between 300 and 700 °K, it does not seem to show any TL for excitation at about 500 °K or above; in the latter case the crystal becomes densely coloured and shows α and β absorption bands. The comparatively low intense glow peaks occuring below 500 °K may be associated with the trapping states related with the trace impurities. Absence of TL in the coloured crystal has been explained by assuming that, during the process of excitation at or above 450 °K. trapped holes diffuse away from the affected layer and facilitate the formation of α and ß absorption bands. Copyright © 1974 WILEY‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
Index Keywords: LUMINESCENCE; PHYSICS - Solid State; CRYSTALS

Title: Progress in the Superconductor Energy Storage. [LES PROGRES DU STOCKAGE D'ENERGIE SUPRACONDUCTEUR.]
Authors with affiliations: Salvy, C.
Abstract: The author examines progress concerning superconductive coils for energy storage and connected supraconductive switches in relation to the development of supraconductive materials. He describes examples of coils and switches for the supply of high-power impulses developed in the Marcoussis laboratories: 600 kJ coil in highly stablized niobium-titanium conductor, and 200 kJ coil in intrinsically stable niobium-titanium conductor, thinly copper-plated, switch with low heat inertia made from bismuth lead tapes.
Index Keywords: Superconducting magnets

Title: Stress, stability and vibration of complex, branched shells of revolution
Affiliations: Lockheed Palo Alto Research Laboratory, Palo Alto, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bushnell, D., Lockheed Palo Alto Research Laboratory, Palo Alto, CA, United States
Abstract: A comprehensive computer program, designated BOSOR4, for analysis of the stress, stability and vibration of segmented, ring-stiffened, branched shells of revolution and prismatic shells and panels is described. The program performs large-deflection axisymmetric stress analysis, small-deflection nonsymmetric stress analysis, modal vibration analysis with axisymmetric nonlinear prestress included, and buckling analysis with axisymmetric or nonsymmetric prestress. One of the main advantages of the code is the provision for realistic engineering details such as eccentric load paths, internal supports, arbitrary branching conditions, and a 'library' of wall constructions. The program is based on the finite-difference energy method which is very rapidly convergent with increasing numbers of mesh points. The organization of the program is briefly described with flow of calculations charted for each of the types of analysis. Overlay charts and core storage requirements are given for the CDC 6600, IBM 370/165, and UNTVAC 1108 versions of BOSOR4. A large number of cases is included to demonstrate the scope and practicality of the program period. © 1974.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING; STRESSES

Title: Mechanical and Battery-Stored Energy Systems for Meeting Uninterruptible and Buffered Electric Power Needs
Affiliations: Brinco Limited, Montreal P.Q., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Comeau, G.E.
Abstract: Mechanical or battery-stored energy systems are used when an uninterruptible or buffered power system is required. Seven different types of systems available are described and compared. © 1974 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS; UNINTERRUPTIBLE POWER SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE

Title: High-Energy Amplifiers for the LASL Glass-Laser System
Affiliations: University of California, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, N. Mex. 87544, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mace, P.N., University of California, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, N. Mex. 87544, United States; Tanner, R.L., University of California, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, N. Mex. 87544, United States
Abstract: Rod amplifiers of 51-mm diameter and disk amplifiers with diameters of 51 and 86 mm were designed and some units have been built for use in a four-beam high-energy glass laser at the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory (LASL). The design goals and measured characteristics of these amplifiers are discussed. Data on self-focusing damage in both rods and disks are presented. Important characteristics of capacitor-bank design, flashlamp construction, and laser glass are discussed. Completion of the four-beam system is scheduled for early 1974. © 1974, IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC LAMPS, DISCHARGE; GLASS; LASER BEAMS - Effects; LASERS, SOLID STATE; GLASS LASERS; LIGHT

Title: Energy Supply by Wave Generator. [ENERGIEVERSORGUNG DURCH WELLENGENERATOR.]
Authors with affiliations: Kayser, Harald
Abstract: The possibility of using wave energy for the supply of power to meteorological and oceanographic measuring instruments located on buoys and thus replace storage batteries or diesel-generator sets now in use is outlined. The design of a hydroelectric wave generator is presented briefly.
Index Keywords: Buoys; Power generation

Title: DETERMINATION OF OPTIMAL DIAMETER OF PRESSURE GALLERIES AND SHAFTS FROM HYDRO-ELECTRIC STORAGE POWER STATIONS.
Source title: REV. ROUM. SCI. TECH.- SER. MECH. APPL.
Authors with affiliations: DIACON, A.
Abstract: BOTH THE ANNUAL INVESTMENTS AND COSTS IN A PRESSURE GALLERY OR SHAFT AND THE THERMAL POWER STATION INVESTMENTS AND COSTS FROM ENERGY POINT OF VIEW ARE PRESENTED, STARTING FROM THE ECONOMIC CRITERION OF THE MINIMAL ANNUAL THEORETIC COSTS.THE INVESTMENT FOR A PRESSURE GALLERY IS ANALYZED FOR TWO CALCULUS HYPO-THESES OF SELF - SUPPORTING SHEET DIMENSION AS WELL AS FOR THE HYPOTHESIS OF THE CONNECTION BETWEEN THE SHEET AND CONCRETE AND ROCK LINING (S/SUB 2/ EQUALS 2).THE PRESSURE GALLERIES AND SHAFTS FROM HYDROELECTRIC PUMPING STORAGE POWER STATIONS ARE MORE FREQUENT FROM THE ENERGY SAVING MINUTES S POINT OF VIEW.THE PUMPING COST PRICE MUST BE CONSIDERED AT EXPENDITURE CALCULUS.(A.).
Index Keywords: ANALYSIS-MATHEMATICAL; Costs; Economics; POWER STATIONS-HYDROELECTRIC; PUMPED STORAGE

Title: WIND-POWER SUPPLY FOR THE DECIMETER RANGE DIRECTIONAL RADIO SITE AT SCHONEBERG (EIFEL) AND THE EXPERIENCE GAINED.
Authors with affiliations: ROSSELER, G.
Abstract: THE SCHONEBERG DIRECTIONAL RADIO STATION IS LOCATED FAR FROM PUBLIC POWER LINES ON A HILLTOP WHERE THE AVERAGE WIND VELOCITY IS 5.6 M/SEC.THE STATION, AS FIRST DESIGNED, REQUIRED 26 KWH/DAY OF DC POWER.IT USES TWO ALIGAIER WIND POWER SYSTEMS, DR.HITTER TYPE WE/G 6, WITH A NOMINAL OUTPUT OF 6 KW AT 9 M/SEC AND 1 KW AT 4.2 M/SEC WIND VELOCITY AMOUNTED ON TWO 10-M HIGH TUBULAR POLES.THE DC GENERATORS ARE DIFFERENTIALLY COMPOUNDED, SHUNT-WOUND.LEAD STORAGE BATTERIES OF 110 CELLS AND 216 AH ARE USED TO STABILIZE THE OUTPUT AND STORE THE ENERGY.A DIESEL GENERATOR SYSTEM IS AVAILABLE AS AN EMERGENCY SYSTEM.TESTS SHOW THAT MORE THAN 90PER CENT OF THE POWER REQUIRED FOR THE INITIAL UNMODIFIED COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM COULD PROBABLY HAVE BEEN SUPPLIED BY THE WIND POWER SYSTEM.THE RESULTS WERE COMPLETELY POSITIVE.WIND POWER STATIONS ARE ECONOMICALLY ADVANTAGEOUS WHERE IT IS VERY EXPENSIVE TO CONNECT TO THE PUBLIC POWER SYSTEM, WHERE ADEQUATE WIND IS AVAILABLE AND ESPECIALLY WHEN ONLY A MODERATE AMOUNT OF POWER IS REQUIRED.(MICROFICHE)
Index Keywords: Aerodynamics; Costs; DIRECTIONAL RADIO STATION; Economics; TEST RESULTS; Wind power

Title: Potential for wind generated power in Texas.
Authors with affiliations: Nelson, V.; Gilmore, E.
Abstract: The region of highest wind energy potential in the USA is located predominantly in the Panhandle of Texas. Other areas of Texas have an above average wind energy potential. The average power obtainable from the wind in Texas was estimated to be 250,000 megawatts, which corresponds to about 2 x 10SUB1SUB2 kwh annually. General information on wind energy and a summary of current information on wind energy conversion systems are included. The data from 15 National Weather Service stations in Texas (1959-1972) and 7 neighbouring stations (1964-1973) are analysed for average energy by month and year, wind speed histograms, velocity and power duration curves, and probability of calm periods. Contour maps for energy at 23 ft. height and 300 ft. (estimated) and probability contours for wind speeds are plotted for Texas. Estimations of power, possible uses and number of units to be built, estimations of costs, and storage are discussed for wind energy conversion systems in Texas. (A)

Title: Energy a continuing bibliography with indexes, May 1974.
Abstract: The publication lists 232 reports, journal articles and other documents concerned with the following topics: regional, national and international energy systems; research and development on fuels and other sources of energy; energy conversion, transport, transmission, distribution and storage, with special emphasis on the use of hydrogen and of solar energy. Also included are methods of locating or using new energy resources. The documents were all announced between January 1974 and March 1974 in 'Scientific and Technical Aerospace Reports' or in 'International Aerospace Abstracts'. (from paper)

Title: DIRECTIONAL WAVE SPECTRA; SOME APPLICATIONS AND STORAGE.
Source title: PROC. INT. SYMP. ON OCEAN WAVE MEASUREMENT AND ANALYSIS, WAVES '74, (AM. SOC. CIV. ENG., NEW ORLEANS, LOUISIANA)
Authors with affiliations: DEAN, R.G.
Abstract: DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION, PRIMARILY ON THE CONTINENTAL SHELF, CONTINUE TO REQUIRE AN INCREASED CAPABILITY TO RELIABLY REPRESENT PERTINENT WAVE CHARACTERISTICS, INCLUDING WAVE DIRECTION.CAPABILITIES EXIST TO MEASURE AND HINDCAST DIRECTIONAL SPECTRA; HOWEVER, IN SOME CASES, THE NECESSARY DETAIL IN THE DIRECTIONAL SPECTRA HAS NOT BEEN ESTABLISHED OR IN SOME DESIGN AREAS, THE MERITS OF USING THE DIRECTIONAL SPECTRUM HAVE NOT BEEN ADEQUATELY RECOGNIZED.THIS PAPER CONSIDERS SEVERAL ASPECTS OF WAVE MEASUREMENT AND APPLICATION, WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON WAVE DIRECTION.TWO PARTICULAR PROBLEMS ARE CONSIDERED TO ILLUSTRATE THE ADEQUACY OF VARIOUS MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS FOR SPECIFIC NEEDS AND THE USE OF WAVE SPECTRA IN DESIGN.FIRST, THE EFFECT OF A DIRECTIONAL WINDOW ON THE ACCURACY OF CALCULATED LITTORAL DRIFT IS EXAMINED AND THIS ERROR IS FOUND TO BE SMALL (# 10 PER CENT) IF THE 'RAW' DIRECTIONAL WINDOW IS USED AND, BY AN ARTIFICE, IT IS POSSIBLE TO ELIMINATE THIS ERROR COMPLETELY.SECONDLY, THE EFFECT OF EMPLOYING A DIRECTIONAL SPECTRUM TO CALCULATE THE TOTAL INERTIA FORCES ON A TWO-PILE STRUCTURE IS INVESTIGATED.IT IS FOUND THAT FOR THE PREDOMINANT WAVE DIRECTION PERPENDICULAR TO A LINE JOINING THE CENTRES OF THE TWO POLING, THE DIRECTIONAL SPECTRUM RESULTS IN CONSIDERABLY SMALLER FORCES FOR THE HIGHER FREQUENCIES.THIS COULD BE OF IMPORTANCE FOR COMPLIANT STRUCTURES IN DEEPER WATER WHICH MAY HAVE NATURAL PERIODS IN THE HIGH FREQUENCY PORTION OF THE WIND-GENERATED WAVE SPECTRUM.FINALLY, A PROCEDURE FOR COMPACTLY STORING DIRECTIONAL WAVE DATA IS SUGGESTED.AS AN EXAMPLE, 110 NUMBERS ARE REQUIRED TO STORE THE DIRECTIONAL SPECTRUM IN ONE PERCENT ENERGY PACKETS.(A)
Index Keywords: DIRECTION; Offshore structures; WAVE SPECTRA

Title: OPTIMIZATION OF THE BASIC CHARACTERISTICS OF PUMPED-STORAGE PLANTS
Authors with affiliations: PARIS, L.; SALVADERI, L.

Index Keywords: BASIC CHARACTERISTICS; COMPARISON WITH THERMAL GENERATING SYSTEM; COMPUTER SIMULATION; ENERGY TRANSFER SERVICE; OPTIMISATION; POWER SERVICE; POWER STATIONS-HYDROELECTRIC; PUMPED STORAGE

Title: FACTORS CONTROLLING CHANGES TO AN OPEN COAST BEACH.
Source title: PROC. 14TH. ASCE COASTAL ENGNG. CONF. (COPENHAGEN, DENMARK).
Authors with affiliations: SEELIG, W.N.; SORENSEN, R.M.
Abstract: A STUDY OF HISTORICAL INFORMATION AND FIELD MEASUREMENTS IN SARGENT BEACH, TEXAS, REVEAL THAT THE SHORELINE IS RETREATING WITH HISTORIC RATES INCREASING FROM MINUS 10 FEET PER YEAR IN THE LATE 1800'S TO MINUS 31 FEET PER YEAR %MINUS 9.8 M/YEAR< IN THE EARLY 1970'S.THE CAUSE OF THIS EROSION IS THE LACK OF AN ADEQUATE SAND SUPPLY TO THE BEACH ZONE.THIS SAND DEFICIENCY IS DUE TO: A< REDUCED UPDRIFT SAND INPUT TO THE COAST BY THE BRAZOS RIVER BEGINNING IN 1945 AND CAUSED BY DECREASED SEDIMENT TRANSPORT CAPABILITY OF THE RIVER, B< INCREASED SAND STORAGE IN THE BRAZOS DELTA ENCOURAGED BY JETTIES AND VEGETATION, AND C< POSSIBLE OFFSHORE LOSSES OF SAND DUE TO HURRICANE WAVE ENERGY FOCUSING ON THE BRAZOS DELTA IN CONJUNCTION WITH RIVER JETTING DURING PEAK RIVER FLOWS.%A<
Index Keywords: BEACH RETREAT; Beaches; COASTAL MORPHOLOGY; SAND STARVATION; Sediment transport

Title: Energy Storage: developing advanced technologies.
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, A.L.
Abstract: This paper presents a brief review of the different ideas which have been proposed as viable means to store energy. These ideas include superconducting magnetic storage plants, flywheels, hydrogen conversion and thermal storage. Other methods which are only just emerging are mentioned, and these include steam storage, and coal gasifiers from which gas can be stored at high pressure. (F.C.S.)

Title: Exploratory evaluation of compressed air storage peak-power systems
Affiliations: United Aircraft Research Laboratories, East Hartford, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Giramonti, A.J., United Aircraft Research Laboratories, East Hartford, CT, United States; Lessard, R.D., United Aircraft Research Laboratories, East Hartford, CT, United States
Abstract: Preliminary analytical studies have been performed to evaluate the commercial viability of compressed air storage peak-power systems. The systems considered consist of (a) a modified gas turbine in which the compressor and turbine sections would be uncoupled, and (b) underground caverns to store the compressed air. These systems are energy storage devices which would be operated in a manner similar to pumped water storage systems. Off-peak nuclear power would be used to run the electric generator in reverse as a motor to drive the compressor which would fill the air storage cavern. During subsequent peak loads the air would be withdrawn from storage, mixed with fuel, burned, and expanded through the turbine to generate power. The results of these preliminary studies indicate that air storage systems should be technically, economically, and environmentally feasible, and justify more detailed evaluation of this novel power system concept. © 1974 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR - Storage; GAS TURBINE POWER PLANTS

Abstract: Methods for storing energy, including pumped hydroelectric storage, compressed air storage, and storage batteries are discussed. (I.F.)

Title: Applications of waste processing systems for pressurized water reactors
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garber, I., Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States; Kearton, W., Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States
Abstract: This paper provides an introduction in the application of Waste Processing Systems in the Westinghouse Pressurized Water Reactor plants. These systems employ the techniques of waste product concentration, long term storage, recycling and radiation monitoring in order to implement the basic philosophy governing radioactive releases established by national and international guidelines. In the United States, the limits of radioactive release are established by the Code of Federal Regulations of the Atomic Energy Commission. Copyright © 1974 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: The prediction of organ viability. II. Testing an hypothesis
Affiliations: Department of Surgery, Western Infirmary, Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Calman, K.C., Department of Surgery, Western Infirmary, Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom
Abstract: A general hypothesis has been proposed which suggests that the primary defect in the ischemically damaged organ is the inability of the cell to maintain adequate levels of adenine nucleotides. Evidence has been presented which substantiates this hypothesis; the addition of potential energy-generating compounds to a perfusion medium increases the survival of organs after storage; the energy content of organs after storage varies in relation to the type of perfusion medium used. © 1974.

Authors: Lemonnier D., de Gasquet P., Griglio S., Naon R., Reynouard F., Trémolières J.
Title: Effect of dietary vitamin B level on fat storage, adipose tissue cellularity and energy expenditure in rats and mice fed a high-fat diet
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Nutrition Humaine de l’institut Scientifique et Technique de l’Alimentation CNAM, Unité de Recherches Diététiques Ul, INSERM, Hôpital Bichat, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Lemonnier, D., Laboratoire de Nutrition Humaine de l’institut Scientifique et Technique de l’Alimentation CNAM, Unité de Recherches Diététiques Ul, INSERM, Hôpital Bichat, Paris, France; de Gasquet, P., Laboratoire de Nutrition Humaine de l’institut Scientifique et Technique de l’Alimentation CNAM, Unité de Recherches Diététiques Ul, INSERM, Hôpital Bichat, Paris, France; Griglio, S., Laboratoire de Nutrition Humaine de l’institut Scientifique et Technique de l’Alimentation CNAM, Unité de Recherches Diététiques Ul, INSERM, Hôpital Bichat, Paris, France; Naon, R., Laboratoire de Nutrition Humaine de l’institut Scientifique et Technique de l’Alimentation CNAM, Unité de Recherches Diététiques Ul, INSERM, Hôpital Bichat, Paris, France; Reynouard, F., Laboratoire de Nutrition Humaine de l’institut Scientifique et Technique de l’Alimentation CNAM, Unité de Recherches Diététiques Ul, INSERM, Hôpital Bichat, Paris, France; Trémolières, J., Laboratoire de Nutrition Humaine de l’institut Scientifique et Technique de l’Alimentation CNAM, Unité de Recherches Diététiques Ul, INSERM, Hôpital Bichat, Paris, France
Abstract: Obesity was produced in mice and rats with high-fat diets containing various vitamin B levels (thiamin, riboflavin, pyridoxinc, Ca-pantothenate, and niacin). Enlargement of fat depots, when compared with control animals fed a low fat diet, is a function of increasing quantities of these vitamins. The variations of fat storage proceeded by increasing the fat cell number in the perirenal adipose tissue of the rat. There was no difference in the resting energy expenditure of rats fed on the diets tested regardless of whether the obesity was nutritionally induced or not. © 1974 by S. Karger AG, Basel.
Author Keywords: Adipose tissue cellularity; B vitamins; Energy expenditure; High-fat diet; Obesity
