Authors: Buvet R., Le Port L., Stoetzel F.
Title: Pre-enzymic origin of metabolic redox processes and of the energy storage processes
Affiliations: Lab. Énergétique Biochimique, Université Paris Val de Marne, Créteil, 94000, France
Authors with affiliations: Buvet, R., Lab. Énergétique Biochimique, Université Paris Val de Marne, Créteil, 94000, France; Le Port, L., Lab. Énergétique Biochimique, Université Paris Val de Marne, Créteil, 94000, France; Stoetzel, F., Lab. Énergétique Biochimique, Université Paris Val de Marne, Créteil, 94000, France
Abstract: A treatment of the energetic conditions which regulate the non-equilibrium occurrence of metabolic redox processes associated with degradations of carbon chains or formations of condensed bonds shows that such processes are conditioned by the nature of the substrates and not by the preexistence of enzymic catalysts or cellular ultrastructures. An experimental program has been initiated to spectrophotometrically, electrochemically and chemically detect which redox components appear during model, studies of chemical evolution, operating from simple mixtures of CH4, NH3, H2 and water and from the same mixtures with added phosphorus or sulfur derivatives and metal cations. © 1974 D. Reidel Publishing Company.
Index Keywords: energy; model; oxidation reduction reaction; Biogenesis; Electrochemistry; Electron Transport; Evolution; Kinetics; Metabolism; Models, Biological; Models, Chemical; Oxidation-Reduction; Ultraviolet Rays

Title: Lethal and genetic effects of radiophosphorus decay in bacteriophages SP82g and t7
Affiliations: Division of Biological and Medical Research, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krisch, R.E., Division of Biological and Medical Research, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, 60439, United States
Abstract: Lethal and genetic effects from the decay of incorporated 32P and 33P were compared in bacteriophages SP82G (B. subtilis) and T7 (E. coli) stored at -196°C or 4°C during decay. Both phages are substantially less sensitive to the lethal effects of 33P than to 32P. Because 33P has a much lower nuclear-recoil energy, the results suggest that nuclear recoil is an important cause of 32P lethality for each phage. Lethal 32P decays in SP82G at either storage temperature appear to correspond to double-strand breaks in DNA. Marker suicide experiments with temperature-sensitive mutants of SP82G indicate two distinct types of lethal lesion resulting from 32P decays: one causes differential interruption of genetic transfer into the infected cell; the second causes interference with the transfer or expression of all genetic markers equally. Similar radiophosphorus experiments with amber mutants of T7 indicate the occurrence of the same two types of genetic lesion. The existence of the first type provides additional indirect evidence that T7, like SP82G, injects its genome in a unique linear sequence, always starting at the left end of the genetic map. © 1974 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.
Index Keywords: phosphorus 32; radioisotope; bacillus subtilis; bacteriophage; escherichia coli; gene expression; genetics; in vitro study; methodology; phosphorus 33; phosphorus 37; radiation death; radioisotope decay; temperature; theoretical study; viral genetics; Bacillus subtilis; Bacteriophages; Coliphages; Comparative Study; DNA Viruses; DNA, Viral; Mutation; Phosphorus Radioisotopes; Radiation Effects; Radiation Genetics; Recombination, Genetic; Temperature

Title: Short-Time Direct-Current Supply Independent on the Mains for Protective Devices in Transformer Stations. [NETZUNABHAENGIGE KURZZEIT-GLEICHSTROMVERSORGUNG FUER SCHUTZEINRICHTUNGEN IN UMSPANNWERKEN.]
Authors with affiliations: Hillig, Wolfgang; Dornath, Heinz
Abstract: A kinetic energy storage device developed for supplying protective, control, supervising and regulating devices in transformer stations is designed to eliminate storage batteries so far used in small and medium-size transformer stations. This short-time direct-current supply independent of the mains makes it possible to feed protective devices without restricting operation in the case of trouble. Criteria of design and technical data of the device are described, as are its fields of application and trial and operating experiences obtained with it.
Index Keywords: Electric substations, Transformer

Title: Recent Results of Investigating the Stability of Crude-Petroleum Storage Caverns. [NEUERE FORSCHUNGSERGEBNISSE ZUR STANDFESTIGKEIT VON ROHOELSPEICHERN.]
Authors with affiliations: Dreyer, Wolfgang
Abstract: Mechanization of mining-, and automation of leaching operations permit an economical excavation of storage caverns in salt deposits. This can be accomplished faster and more easily also by nuclear explosion. In either case, the caverns have a spherical shape that is optimal from the stability viewpoint. Under the assumption of hydrostatic conditions, characteristic for a virgin rock, stresses and deformations have been calculated for a spherical cavern and the blasting, energy and costs are discussed. In a similar manner, the stress distribution around a cylindrical excavation (a mine shaft) have been determined. Paper suggests refraining from erecting buildings, etc. , over or in the vicinity of, underground caverns.
Index Keywords: Petroleum, Crude; Rock mechanics; Salt deposits; STORAGE CAVERNS; Fuels

Title: Improved control of radioactive wastes
Affiliations: US Atomic Energy Comm., Bethesda, Md., United States
Authors with affiliations: Stubblefield, F.E., US Atomic Energy Comm., Bethesda, Md., United States; Jackson, E.B., US Atomic Energy Comm., Bethesda, Md., United States
Abstract: The Hanford plant of the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission at Richland, Wash., is actively pursuing a course design for an improved posture in regard to control of radioactive waste. This is an interim step in some yet to be determined, long range disposal scheme. The old procedure had been to bury waste as received, with no provisions for retrievability. The improved procedure involves the following: segregate transuranic contaminated waste from other radioactive waste; segregate combustible and noncombustible transuranic waste; package the transuranic contaminated waste in retrievable type packages, and store in soil such that retrieval of contamination free packages can be accomplished for at least 20 yr after initial storage; implement volume reduction measures at the generation facility; implement improved land utilization; and consolidate sites where practical, thus releasing land areas from contamination restrictions. In this paper a typical burial operation for non transuranic solid waste is illustrated together with a prototype V trench for storage of transuranic waste.
Index Keywords: environmental health

Title: Coping with nuclear wastes
Authors with affiliations: Davis, J.C.
Abstract: In a effort to minimize future health hazards and reduce the present need for surveillance of storage and disposal sites, the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) has undertaken several projects in the last year in order to develop techniques for reducing volume and for packaging radioactive wastes. An important reason behind the AEC's efforts is the expected rise in nuclear generating capacity to help stem the energy gap and the need to free itself from the chore of surveying the many sites scattered throughout the U.S. where wastes are stored or disposed. Projects for the development of bedded salt plants (where the wastes are stored in cannisters in underground salt deposits), computer monitoring of radioactivity, solidification of wastes, acid digestion of routine waste products, and the use of radioactive wastes for the sterilization of sewage sludge are described and discussed.
Index Keywords: environmental health

Title: Energy metabolism and repair of U.V.-Damage in saccharomyces II. Calorimetric measurements of the glucose metabolism of U.V.-sensitive mutants
Affiliations: Zentralinstitut für Biochemie und Biophysik der Freien Universität Berlin, 1, 33, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schaarschmidt, B., Zentralinstitut für Biochemie und Biophysik der Freien Universität Berlin, 1, 33, Berlin, Germany; Lamprecht, I., Zentralinstitut für Biochemie und Biophysik der Freien Universität Berlin, 1, 33, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Enhancement ratios of the surviving fraction after U.V.-irradiation and subsequent liquid-holding period were compared with microcalorimetrically-obtained data on the glucose storage in Saccharomyces mutants carrying the genes rs1, rs2, rs3-2 and in the wild-type. The survival rates were found to be proportional to intracellular glycogen reservoirs. For diploid cells the enhancement ratios of survival after recovery in buffer supplemented by glucose were related to the cellular rate of catabolic activity of glucose. The influence of glucose, due to its high free energy, is limited by the repair systems in the strains used. Unirradiated and irradiated resting cells show no differences in microcalorimetric behaviour. This indicates a high U.V.-resistance of the glucose metabolism to doses which reduce survival to less than 1 per cent. © 1974 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.
Index Keywords: glucose; glycogen; energy transfer; in vitro study; metabolism; methodology; mutant; radiation injury; radiosensitivity; radiotherapy; saccharomyces; saccharomyces cerevisiae; theoretical study; ultraviolet radiation; Calorimetry; Cell Survival; DNA Repair; Glucose; Mutation; Radiation Effects; Saccharomyces; Ultraviolet Rays

Title: The surface cleanliness of 316 L + N stainless steel studied by SIMS and AES
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Mathewson, A.G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Some cleaning methods for 316 L + N stainless steel including solvent cleaning, high temperature treatment in vacuo and gas discharge cleaning have been studied by SIMS and AES with a view to providing a clean vacuum chamber surface with low gas desorption under ion bombardment. After solvent cleaning the main surface contaminant was found to be C and its associated compounds. Laboratory investigations on small samples of stainless steel showed that clean surfaces could be obtained by heating in vacuo to 800°C followed by exposure to air and by argon or argon/10% oxygen discharge cleaning. Due to a cross contamination within the vacuum system, the 800°C treated chamber gave positive desorption coefficients under ion bombardment. The pure argon discharge cleaned chambers proved stable giving negative desorption coefficients up to 2200 eV ion energy even after several weeks storage between discharge treatment and installation. No results have yet been obtained on the stability of an argon/10% oxygen discharge cleaned vacuum chamber. © 1974.

Authors: Eastman D.E., Grobman W.D., Freeouf J.L., Erbudak M.
Title: Photoemission spectroscopy using synchrotron radiation. I. Overviews of valence-band structure for Ge, GaAs, GaP, InSb, ZnSe, CdTe, and Agl
Affiliations: IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Division of Engineering and Applied Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eastman, D.E., IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Grobman, W.D., IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Freeouf, J.L., IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States, Division of Engineering and Applied Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States; Erbudak, M., Division of Engineering and Applied Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Abstract: We determine bandwidths and critical-point positions with respect to the valence-band edge for the valence bands of several extensively studied semiconductors (with an accuracy of about 0.3 eV) by using photoemission densities of states derived from photoemission spectra obtained in the 24-78-eV photon energy range. These photoemission spectra were obtained using synchrotron radiation from an electron storage ring; a double-pass, electrostatic, electron energy analyzer; and samples cleaved and measured in situ in ultrahigh vacuum. We give a detailed description of the data-reduction techniques by which electronic state densities and certain valence-band feature positions are determined from photoemission spectra. This description includes a discussion of the effect of various phenomena such as optical-transition-probability variations and Auger-emission peaks. Tables are presented which compare our valence-band-position values with the results of both empirical calculations fit to optical data as well as ab initio calculations. We find systematic and significant differences between experiment and calculations fit only to optical data, these differences increasing with crystal ionicity, while ab initio calculations generally give a better fit to experiment. © 1974 The American Physical Society.

Title: Integral cross sections for ion-molecule reactions. I. The guided beam technique
Affiliations: Fakultät für Physik der Universität Freiburg i Br., Germany
Authors with affiliations: Teloy, E., Fakultät für Physik der Universität Freiburg i Br., Germany; Gerlich, D., Fakultät für Physik der Universität Freiburg i Br., Germany
Abstract: A technique is described, that allows the measurement of integral cross sections for ion-molecule reactions and electron-transfer processes in the energy range from typically 0.1 to 20 eV (lab). Basically similar to the tandem mass spectrometer method, it uses inhomogeneous oscillatory electric fields for the storage and guidance of the primary ions and for the collection of the secondary ions. By these means a reduction of the number of excited ions in the primary beam and a good definition of the kinetic energy are obtained, together with a collection and detection probability for the secondary ions, that approaches unity for all scattering angles in a broad energy band. Tire ion beam intensity (105 to 107 ions per second) is only weakly dependent on the kinetic energy down to typically 0.15 eV (lab). The distribution of the collision energies is mainly determined by the thermal motion of the reactant gas in the scattering chamber (T ≈ 300 K). Measurements are reported for the reactions Ar+ + D2 → ArD+ + D and Ne+ + CO → C+ Ne+O. © 1974.

Title: Ion induced gas desorption problems in the ISR
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Calder, R.S., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Not least among the many stringent conditions which must be satisfied to achieve the proper operation of the Intersecting Storage Rings at CERN are those pertaining to its 2 km of ultrahigh vacuum. Apart from the direct influence of the residual gas molecules through nuclear and Coulomb scattering on the stored beam lifetimes (of the order of days during which the stored protons should travel the astronomical distance of some light days!) there are also indirect processes which additionally involve adsorption/desorption phenomena on the vacuum chamber wall. The beam of high energy protons creates low energy secondary ions in the residual gas. These ions, generated in the space charge potential of 1 kV (10 A)-1 of proton beam, are accelerated by this potential onto the stainless steel vacuum chamber wall where a variety of adsorption/desorption phenomena may be stimulated. Desorbed molecules are fed back into the residual gas resulting in the possibility of creating an unstable run-away pressure increase which can finally destroy the stored beam. This danger depends on the local parameters of the vacuum system, and most critically, on the state of the vacuum chamber surface. The paper summarises recent observations in this field and describes the results of investigations aimed at producing cleaner surfaces in vacuum chambers. These investigations, which have included high temperature bakeouts, ion bombardment scrubbing by glow discharge, oxidation, etc, will show that under favourable conditions, net negative desorption coefficients can be obtained which turn the Intersecting Storage Rings into a large ion pump. Results, supported and compared with measurements using Auger and Sims surface analysis, are presented mainly from the empirical point of view with the emphasis on practical implications for machines where the surfaces of the vacuum system are subjected to ion bombardment. © 1974.

Title: The effect of pig slurry applied to a soil surface on the composition of the soil atmosphere
Source title: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture
Affiliations: Department of Agriculture, Agricultural and Food Chemistry Research Division Northern Ireland, Ireland; Department of Agriculture, Freshwater Biological Investigation Unit, Greenmount Road, Muckamore, Antrim, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stevens, R.J., Department of Agriculture, Agricultural and Food Chemistry Research Division Northern Ireland, Ireland, Department of Agriculture, Freshwater Biological Investigation Unit, Greenmount Road, Muckamore, Antrim, United Kingdom; Cornforth, I.S., Department of Agriculture, Agricultural and Food Chemistry Research Division Northern Ireland, Ireland
Abstract: Intensive livestock production and labour‐saving methods of husbandry require the storage and subsequent disposal of large volumes of slurry on land. The effect of pig slurry, applied to a soil surface, on the composition of the soil atmosphere was investigated using laboratory soil columns. When the effect of slurry was compared with equivalent amounts of glucose, results showed that while both energy sources increased microbial activity, slurry also sealed soil pores, slowing gaseous diffusion rates and delaying the return of the composition of the soil atmosphere to that approaching air. Repeated slurry applications completely sealed the soil surface and oxygen in the soil atmosphere was rapidly depleted. Ethylene, capable of harmfully affecting root‐growth, was produced in the anaerobic soil. The fine solids fraction (less than 250 μm particle diameter) of slurry was most effective at blocking soil pores to gaseous diffusion. Copyright © 1974 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd

Title: Constant current regulator for fast recharging of high voltage energy storage capacitors
Affiliations: Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Findley, R.W., Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Russ, J.S., Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Abstract: A circuit to linearize the charging curve of a capacitive load discharged by a spark gap or thyratron is reported. Use in spark chamber experiments is described. © 1973.

Title: Erratum: Quadrupolar Analysis of Storage and Release of Elastic Energy in the Earth (Naturephys. Sci.(1973) 243 (122))
Authors with affiliations: Pines, D.; Shaham, J.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: High-density image-storage holograms by sampling and random phase shifter method
Affiliations: Central Research Laboratory, Hitachi, Ltd., 1-280, Higashikoigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tsunoda, Y., Central Research Laboratory, Hitachi, Ltd., 1-280, Higashikoigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, Japan; Takeda, Y., Central Research Laboratory, Hitachi, Ltd., 1-280, Higashikoigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: As a new method of making high-quality and high-storage-density holograms capable of storing such image information as pictures and portraits, combination of the sampling method and random phase shifter method is proposed. This method reduces the concentrations of information light energy on the hologram plane which are located evenly in the just Fourier-transformed plane. As an experimental result, the light waves passing through 106 sampling points on a frame information with random phases were focused into a spot to make a hologram of 2.0-mm diameter. The reconstructed image from the hologram showed high quality without speckle and high efficiency. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.

Title: High-pressure iodine photodissociation laser
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aldridge, F.T., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: An iodine photodissociation laser has been operated at 600 Torr by adding inert gas to the laser medium. The inert gas does not quench the inversion. Pressure broadening of the 1.315-μ emission line with an inert gas is a simple and effective method of increasing the energy storage capacity of the laser for short-pulse amplification. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Inherent nonlinearity of Victoreen R-meters
Affiliations: New York Univ., NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Orton, C.G., New York Univ., NY, United States; Seibert, J.B., New York Univ., NY, United States
Abstract: It is often assumed that if the electrometer voltage response of a Victoreen R-meter is linear, then the radiation response will also be linear. It is demonstrated that, due to stem ionization, this assumption is not justified for high energy radiations. The Victoreen R-meter employs a polystyrene dielectric in the chamber stem for charge storage. During irradiation the conductivity of this insulator increases and a leakage current is induced which gives rise to the 'stem effect'. These leakage currents decrease with decrease in collecting voltage, and because the collecting voltage across the Victoreen chamber decreases during exposure, this leads to a nonlinear exposure response.

Title: Relevance of cosmic ray data above 1012 eV to models of high energy interactions
Source title: Journal of Physics A: General Physics
Affiliations: Univ. Durham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wdowczyk, J., Univ. Durham, United Kingdom; Wolfendale, A.W., Univ. Durham, United Kingdom
Abstract: Recent experiments on proton-proton collisions with the intersecting storage ring facility have shown a number of features which may be explained by the high energy 'scaling' model of Feynman. The authors have examined cosmic ray data in some detail to 1018 eV and find that they do not support the model being valid, at least without serious modification, to these much higher energies.

Title: The use of storage rings in high energy physics
Affiliations: Univ. Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gibson, W.M., Univ. Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: Some of the general considerations governing the usefulness and the practicability of storage rings, in which circulating beams of elementary particles are maintained for periods long in relation to the time for a single revolution in orbit are presented. Single storage rings for experiments on free particles are discussed in one section, which is followed by a chapter on colliding beam storage rings. The storage ring is presented as a device allowing investigation of processes which are inaccessible with the conventional arrangement of beam and stationary target. The latter part of the report is concerned with intersecting storage rings for proton-proton collisions, with particular emphasis on their use for obtaining high energies in the centre of mass system. The major part of this section is devoted to the CERN intersecting storage rings and the experimental work based on them, with a discussion of results obtained in the first twenty months of operation.

Title: Luminosity optimisation for storage rings with low-β sections and small crossing angles
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Keil, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The luminosity of storage rings with intersections having small values of the amplitude function and the crossing angle is optimised imposing upper limits on the line density in the two beams and on the linear beam-beam tune shift. It is found that the luminosity is proportional to the energy of the stored particles. It depends on the beam-beam tune shift, the amplitude function the length of the crossing region, the beam emittance and the line density more weakly than one might expect from simple-minded formulae. In 300 GeV proton storage rings a luminosity above 1033 cm-2 s-1 should be possible. © 1973.

Authors: Romeo N., Dallaturca A., Braglia R., Sberveglieri G.
Title: Charge storage in ZnIn2S4 single crystals
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisica, Consiglio Nazionale Ricerche, Gruppo Nazionale Struttura Materia, Parma, Italy; Istituto Ricerche G. Donegani, Montedison, Novara, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Romeo, N., Istituto di Fisica, Consiglio Nazionale Ricerche, Gruppo Nazionale Struttura Materia, Parma, Italy; Dallaturca, A., Istituto di Fisica, Consiglio Nazionale Ricerche, Gruppo Nazionale Struttura Materia, Parma, Italy; Braglia, R., Istituto Ricerche G. Donegani, Montedison, Novara, Italy; Sberveglieri, G., Istituto Ricerche G. Donegani, Montedison, Novara, Italy
Abstract: We observe that, when ZnIn2S4 monocrystals at a temperature below 170°K are illuminated by light of the gap energy, the dark resistance, after illumination, is lowered by about nine orders of magnitude. This high-conductivity state persists until the crystals are either (a) warmed to room temperature, (b) exposed to light of a definite energy less than the gap width, or (c) placed in an electric field. We propose a level 1.76 eV above the valence band, with a repulsive barrier of 0.11 eV, which an electron must penetrate to enter this level and recombine. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.

Title: New NSF/RANN program on energy
Abstract: The RANN (Research Applied to National Needs) program of the National Science Foundation (U.S.) is making technological progress in many areas. Advanced Energy Research and Technology (AERT), the newest division in the program is presently investigating energy producing technology that may have practical use in the mid 1980s. This article briefly discusses their research into solar energy, geothermal energy, energy storage in batteries, superconducting cables, and advanced coal research.
Index Keywords: environmental health

Title: Industry awaits solutions to problems of high level radioactive waste management
Authors with affiliations: Strauss, S.D.
Abstract: Nuclear fission products formed during reactor operation eventually interfere with the chain reaction, rendering further operation uneconomical. This ″nuclear ash″ must be extracted so the unexpended uranium remaining in the fuel can be used. About once a year, a fraction of a reactor loading - some 30 tons - is removed for reprocessing. This involves a complex chemical operation, which separates out the fission products. The fuel material is leached from the metal with hot acid, and uranium and plutonium are recovered from the solution. Essentially all the fission products are removed by a nitric acid solution; this then constitutes a ″high-level″ waste, emitting intense amounts of radioactivity and a considerable amount of heat. Methods for disposing of the high-level wastes and plutonium are discussed. Past practice has been to store the waste stream underground in steel tanks embedded in thick concrete walls. Under consideration are a reference canister design for waste storage and stable geologic formations such as salt beds for disposal. Also under study is the possibility of transmutation of radioactive nuclides by nuclear bombardment into other forms that are more stable, hence less hazardous. Alternatively, products could be formed that have shorter half-lives, meaning that they undergo radioactive decay in a shorter period of time. To meet interim needs a design study has been undertaken to develop plans for a surface or near-surface facility which will accommodate sealed waste-bearing canisters shipped from chemical reprocessing plants. Retrievable surface storage is the official term for this approach. The facility will be designed so that radioactive wastes can be safely isolated for centuries, if necessary. However, they could be moved for geologic storage (or other form of permanent disposal) when feasible, reducing the burden of continued surveillance and control.Long term disposal of high level radioactive wastes remains one of the unresolved aspects of the nuclear fuel cycle. Responsibility for processing of spent nuclear fuel falls within the realm of private industry, but resolution by the Atomic Energy Commission of a number of vital questions is the key to viability of new commercial plants. This paper describes several privately owned facilities which are being designed to handle this aspect of the nuclear fuel cycle, and discusses present problems with regard to packaging spent fuel for disposal, storage facilities, and removal of decay heat.
Index Keywords: RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Waste Disposal; Nuclear fuels; environmental health

Title: 'New' platelet diseases and their biochemical aspects
Affiliations: Lab. Blood Coagulat., Med. Res. Dept., Acad. Ziekenh. St Rafael, Univ. Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: De Gaetano, G., Lab. Blood Coagulat., Med. Res. Dept., Acad. Ziekenh. St Rafael, Univ. Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Platelets possess many enzymatic activities which allow them to metabolize sugars, lipids, proteins and nucleotides. The presently available knowledge of the energy metabolism of platelets and of the role of adenine nucleotides in platelet function is briefly summarized. Platelet adenine nucleotides are compartmentalized: one nucleotide pool participates in basic platelet metabolism and is retained by the cell during the 'release reaction' (metabolically active pool); another pool does not participate in metabolism and is extruded from the cell during the 'release reaction' (metabolically inactive pool or storage pool). The process by which platelet nucleotides (mainly ADP and ATP) are extruded from the platelets ('release reaction') was tentatively divided into 4 phases: induction, transmission, specific energy production and extrusion. A defect in any one or more stages in this sequence could account for an impairment of platelet aggregation. The data available in the literature (51 patients with prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, and one or more abnormal platelet aggregation tests) were analyzed. These 'new' platelet diseases seem to be different from 'old' congenital disorders such as Glanzmann's thrombasthenia and von Willebrand's disease.
Index Keywords: adenine nucleotide derivative; adenosine diphosphate; adenosine triphosphate; bleeding tendency; blood clotting; glanzmann disease; review; thrombocyte; thrombocyte aggregation; thrombocyte release reaction; thrombocytopathy; von willebrand disease; Adenine Nucleotides; Adenosine Diphosphate; Blood Cell Count; Blood Coagulation Disorders; Blood Coagulation Tests; Blood Platelet Disorders; Blood Platelets; Blood Proteins; Carbohydrates; Collagen; Energy Metabolism; Epinephrine; Human; Lipids; Platelet Adhesiveness; Thrombin; Thrombocythemia, Hemorrhagic

Title: Energetic cost of locomotion in kangaroos
Affiliations: Museum of Comparative Zoology, Biological Laboratories, Harvard University, Cambridge; School of Zoology, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Dawson, T.J., Museum of Comparative Zoology, Biological Laboratories, Harvard University, Cambridge, School of Zoology, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia; Taylor, C.R., School of Zoology, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia
Abstract: THE hopping of kangaroos is reminiscent of a bouncing ball or the action of a pogo stick. This suggests a significant storage and recovery of energy in elastic elements. One might surmise that the kangaroo's first hop would require a large amount of energy whereas subsequent hops could rely extensively on elastic rebound. If this were the case, then the kangaroo's unusual saltatory mode of locomotion should be an energetically inexpensive way to move. © 1973 Nature Publishing Group.
Index Keywords: animal; energy transfer; locomotion; oxygen consumption; running; theoretical study

Title: The gas supply situation in the united states
Source title: Journal of the Air Pollution Control Association
Affiliations: Planning and Development Division, Bureau of Natural Gas, Federal Power Commission, 825 North Capitol St., N.E, Washington, DC, 20426, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zareski, G.K., Planning and Development Division, Bureau of Natural Gas, Federal Power Commission, 825 North Capitol St., N.E, Washington, DC, 20426, United States
Abstract: The body of information presented in this paper is directed to those individuals who require information on the present natural gas supply and demand relationship and the prospects for future changes, including individuals concerned with air quality control and the use of natural gas for combating air pollution. If natural gas could continue to capture large shares of the energy market, as in the past when supply was not a growth inhibiting factor, annual demand for gas is projected to increase to 34.5 and 46.4 trillion cubic feet in 1980 and 1990, respectively. Annual production levels which could be supported by presently proven reserves and anticipated future reserve additions are estimated to peak in the mid-1970’s and decline to about 18 trillion cubic feet in 1990. When viewed from the perspective of anticipated indigenous supply deficiencies, the acquisition of supplemental sources of gas becomes of paramount importance. Pipeline imports, the only substantive supplemental source presently available, could almost double by 1980 and be about 2 trillion cubic feet annually in 1990. Available volumes of gas from Alaska could be 0.7 trillion cubic feet in 1980 and could increase to 2.3 trillion cubic feet annually by 1990. Actual initial deliveries of gas are inextricably related to construction of an oil pipeline from Prudhoe Bay. Construction delays postpone initial delivery dates for gas as well as oil. Advancements in cryogenic transportation and storage technologies have made the heretofore largely untapped supplies of gas from several countries with limited internal markets available to the United States as LNG. Annual LNG imports could be about 0.3 trillion cubic feet in 1975 and perhaps 2 and 4 trillion cubic feet by 1980 and 1990, respectively. Pipeline quality gas from coal presents the prospect for a supplemental source of gaseous fuel independent of foreign sources and free from balance of payments problems. The first pipeline quality gas from coal may be expected by 1976, and by 1980 perhaps 0.3 trillion cubic feet could be provided annually from this source; in 1990, 3.3 trillion cubic feet might be available. An additional, but presently unqualified, source of synthetic gas will be the conversion of liquid hydrocarbons. In the aggregate, supplemental gas supplies are anticipated to total about 4.6 and 11.5 trillion cubic feet annually by 1980 and 1990, respectively. While demand for gas is anticipated to increase, domestic conventional gas production is projected to peak in the mid-1970’s and decrease somewhat thereafter. As a consequence, a continuing gas supply-demand imbalance is anticipated. © 1973 Air & Waste Management Association.
Index Keywords: environmental health

Title: Inactivation of A2/Hong Kong influenza virus by heat and by freeze thawing. Comparison of untreated and gamma irradiated preparations
Affiliations: Inst. Hyg., Univ. Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: De Flora, S., Inst. Hyg., Univ. Genoa, Italy; Badolati, G., Inst. Hyg., Univ. Genoa, Italy
Abstract: The stability of untreated and of γ irradiated A2/Aichi/2/68 influenza virus was checked during 2 yr storage at temperatures ranging from -80° to +37°C and after heating to +56°C. Hemagglutinin and neuraminidase activities were not impaired by exposure to 3x106 rad of cobalt 60 γ rays, whereas infectivity was completely abolished. At -80°C no decrease in infectivity of the untreated virus nor of surface antigen activity of either the untreated or the irradiated preparations was detectable. From -20° to +37°C the inactivation of both preparations followed first order kinetics, the velocity constants (k) showing very low values, particularly for hemagglutinin activity. At +56°C, inactivation of all virus properties took place in two stages, each following first order kinetics. The inactivation constants of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase properties of untreated and irradiated preparations were overlapping when samples were stored frozen (-80° and -20°C). A significantly increasing rate of inactivation was observed for irradiated virus antigens after storage at temperatures above +4°C. The same phenomenon was recorded after periodical thawing at +20°C of virus preparations stored at -20°C (30 cycles of freeze thawing in 2 yrs). These differences did not depend on a modified protective action of the irradiated medium, but the thermal stability of irradiated non infective particles was considerable in view of practical applications, as inferred by calculation of the thermodynamic parameters of inactivation. The energy of activation (ΔH) needed for the thermal inactivation of virus properties was very low and the entropy of activation (ΔS) had negative values for both the untreated and the irradiated virus samples.
Index Keywords: virus sialidase; gamma radiation; influenza virus a2; microorganism; theoretical study; thermostability; virus; virus hemagglutination; virus inactivation; virus infectivity; Antigens, Viral; Comparative Study; Freezing; Heat; Hemagglutinins, Viral; Human; Influenza; Neuraminidase; Orthomyxoviridae; Radiation Effects

Title: Laser gain characterization of near-atmospheric CO2:N 2:He glows in a planar electrode geometry
Affiliations: Westinghouse Research Laboratories, Pittsburgh, PA 15235, United States
Authors with affiliations: Denes, L.J., Westinghouse Research Laboratories, Pittsburgh, PA 15235, United States; Weaver, L.A., Westinghouse Research Laboratories, Pittsburgh, PA 15235, United States
Abstract: Temporally and spatially resolved gain measurements are reported for near-atmospheric CO2:N2:He glow discharges in a contoured planar electrode configuration. When suitably preionized by rows of electrically stressed dielectric interfaces, the entire interelectrode volume is filled with a uniform glow discharge for large ranges of capacitor energy, voltage, and gas pressure. The 10.59-μm gain reaches a peak value of 2.8% cm-1 in 2 μsec, and decays exponentially with a 20-μsec time constant in near-optimum laser mixtures of 60 Torr CO2, 180 Torr N2, and 60 Torr He. Peak gain is uniform over the transverse dimensions to within 5%. Mathematical expressions are developed which relate the small-signal gain to the P and R branch rotational quantum numbers in a linear fashion. This analysis shows that for optimized laser conditions the 00°1-10°0 population inversion is [inverted lazy s]1.8×1017 cm -3 with a rotational temperature of [inverted lazy s]400 °K. This corresponds to a maximum 10.6-μm optical storage density of [inverted lazy s]31 J/liter and represents [inverted lazy s]17% of the electrical energy input to the discharge. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: LASERS, GAS

Title: Semiautomated data-recording and control system for an electron energy analyzer
Affiliations: National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234
Authors with affiliations: Powell, C.J., National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234
Abstract: A description is given of a digital data-recording and control system that has been used with a high resolution low energy electron scattering apparatus for the measurement of characteristic electron energy-loss spectra and Auger-electron spectra of solids (at room and elevated temperatures) and liquids. This system is based on a multichannel analyzer and has the following features: (a) Specimens can be prepared many times with data accumulated in arbitrarily short times after preparation (prior to specimen contamination), and final spectra of high precision can be obtained by summation of individual runs; (b) the voltage sweep applied to the electron energy analyzer can be calibrated dynamically; and (c) data can be accumulated and the target heated by electron bombardment in a cyclic manner with variable accumulation and heating periods. Characteristic loss spectra of tungsten at 800°C and of liquid aluminum are presented as examples of operation of the system. © 1973 The American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS, DIGITAL; ELECTRONS - Velocity Analyzers; DATA RECORDING AND CONTROL SYSTEMS; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL

Authors: Shaw R.W., Hill D.E., Sandfort R.M., Moody J.W.
Title: Determination of magnetic bubble film parameters from strip domain measurements
Affiliations: Monsanto Company, St. Louis, MO 63166, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, R.W., Monsanto Company, St. Louis, MO 63166, United States; Hill, D.E., Monsanto Company, St. Louis, MO 63166, United States; Sandfort, R.M., Monsanto Company, St. Louis, MO 63166, United States; Moody, J.W., Monsanto Company, St. Louis, MO 63166, United States
Abstract: Magneto-optical methods involving only strip domain patterns are proposed for the measurement of characteristic length l, saturation magnetization 4πMs, and domain wall energy density σw, in thin uniaxial magnetic films. Determination of l requires measurement of film thickness and the spatial period of the strip domain pattern in zero applied field as previously proposed by Fowlis and Copeland, while 4πMs and σw follow from additional measurements of M/Ms vs H as a hysteresis loop. The results of calculations which are necessary to put the methods to use are presented in detail. Experimental results are included which indicate reasonable agreement with other methods currently in use. The present method is of greater accuracy and convenience in certain cases. The effects of finite uniaxial anisotropy are quantitatively considered and shown to change the results by 6% or less for materials of practical interest. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC; MAGNETIC BUBBLE FILM PARAMETERS; MAGNETIC MATERIALS

Title: Electromagnetic flight stability by model impedance simulation
Affiliations: Francis Bitter National Magnet Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Iwasa, Y., Francis Bitter National Magnet Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Abstract: Impedance measurements on scale models can be an extraordinarily simple and effective technique for comparing the lift and drag forces and the static and dynamic stabilities of various vehicle-guideway configurations for levitation by motion-induced eddy-current repulsion. The real and imaginary components of the input impedance of an inductive circuit are a measure of its power loss and magnetic energy storage, and the gradient of that energy is magnetic force. As a demonstration of the technique, we have applied it to variations of the magneplane system being developed by the MIT-Avco-Raytheon group. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: VEHICLES

Authors: Lubin M.J., Soures J.M., Goldman L.M.
Title: Large-aperture Nd-glass laser amplifier for high-peak-power application
Affiliations: Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States; Corporate Research and Development, General Electric Company, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lubin, M.J., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States; Soures, J.M., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States; Goldman, L.M., Corporate Research and Development, General Electric Company, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States
Abstract: A 110-mm-square aperture face pumped Nd-glass amplifier has been designed and tested under input beam energy density conditions of up to 5 J/cm 2. The measured gain of 120-psec pulses compares favorably with the calculated values based on a three-level model of the amplifying medium. Maximum storage efficiency of 2.3%, high repetition rate of 1/2 pulse/min, and minimum beam distortion combine to make this design attractive for high-peak-power applications. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: LASERS, SOLID STATE

Authors: Wellmann K.F., Adachi M., Volk B.W.
Title: Pancreatic and hepatic ultrastructure in offspring of rabbits with protein malnutrition
Source title: Virchows Archiv Abteilung A Pathologische Anatomie
Affiliations: Isaac Albert Research Institute of the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, Brooklyn, N.Y., United States
Authors with affiliations: Wellmann, K.F., Isaac Albert Research Institute of the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, Brooklyn, N.Y., United States; Adachi, M.; Volk, B.W.
Abstract: Pregnant New Zealand rabbits were fed on a low-protein, low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet during the second half of gestation and during the subsequent period of lactation. Baby rabbits born to these protein-restricted does and suckled by them for two or more weeks showed loss of fur, stunted growth, fatty metamorphosis and increased glycogen storage in the liver, and atrophy of pancreatic acinear cells associated with loss of zymogen granules as well as widespread cytoplasmic vacuolization. It is suggested that the changes observed are not merely the effect of caloric restriction but also reflect a more specific nutritional deficiency (protein deficiency) transmitted by the mother rabbit to her offspring. © 1973 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: glycogen; animal; article; atrophy; electron microscopy; female; fetomaternal transfusion; lactation; liver; pancreas; pathology; pregnancy; pregnancy complication; protein calorie malnutrition; protein deficiency; Animal; Atrophy; Female; Glycogen; Lactation; Liver; Maternal-Fetal Exchange; Microscopy, Electron; Pancreas; Pregnancy; Pregnancy Complications; Protein Deficiency; Protein-Energy Malnutrition

Title: New magneto-optic memory concept based on compensation wall domains
Affiliations: Philips Forschungslaboratorium Hamburg GmbH, 2 Hamburg 54, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Krumme, J.-P., Philips Forschungslaboratorium Hamburg GmbH, 2 Hamburg 54, Germany; Hansen, P., Philips Forschungslaboratorium Hamburg GmbH, 2 Hamburg 54, Germany
Abstract: A new concept of thermomagnetic localized reversible magneto-optic storage is proposed based on the application of compensation wall domains (CWD). Individual CWD's of 12 × 12-μm dimensions in an LPE film of composition Y2.34Gd0.52Yb0.14Fe3.74Ga 1.26 O12 with 3-μm thickness have been switched by laser flashes of 10-2 erg/μm2 energy in 5 μs at 5145-Å wavelength using a stationary field of 41 Oe normal to the film plane. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Gross B., Sessler G.M., West J.E.
Title: Charge diagnostics for electron-irradiated polymer foils
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gross, B., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Sessler, G.M., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; West, J.E., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Abstract: Polymer foils carrying thin vacuum-deposited electrodes on both surfaces are irradiated with nonpenetrating monoenergetic electron beams of various energies. Measurement of the currents and charges drawn from both electrodes and of the voltage buildup between the electrodes during and after irradiation allows one to determine charge storage parameters of such electrets. © 1973 American Institute of Physics.

Title: A stochastic model of crystal plasticity
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Brunei University, Middx, Uxbridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Feltham, P., Department of Physics, Brunei University, Middx, Uxbridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: The interpretation of creep as an evolutionary Markov process, involving a distribution of energy-barrier heights governing dislocation movement (Feltham 1968), is extended to encompass work-hardening under increasing stresses, by making explicit allowance for the operation of dislocation sources. The widely observed, linear, workhardening law, derivable from the model, is shown to imply the strain invariance of the normalized distribution of the energy-barrier levels. This invariance appears to be a consequence of a mode of ‘microdeformation’ in which the rate of storage of ‘elastic’ energy with respect to strain tends towards a minimum. © 1973 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Title: Počátek aktivního metabollsmu v časném stadiu bobtuání semen phaseolus aureus
Affiliations: Department of Botany, University of Calcutta, Caleutta-19, India
Authors with affiliations: Paul, A.K., Department of Botany, University of Calcutta, Caleutta-19, India; Mukherji, S., Department of Botany, University of Calcutta, Caleutta-19, India
Abstract: Metabolism of dry mungbean seeds (Phaseolus aureus) was compared with that of 3 h imbibed ones. Respiration rates sharply increased upon imbibition which was accompanied by large water uptake. Storage protein was degraded resulting in the rise in soluble nitrogen. RNA and water soluble protein content increased but DNA declined. It is suggested that some of the soluble nitrogen pools are diverted to RNA formation which in turn produce enzyme protein. In mungbean seeds imbibition of water thus triggers a series of metabolic changes within 3 h with the respiratory energy as the driving force. © 1973 Institute of Experimental Botany.

Title: Force-free magnetic fields and flares of August 1972
Affiliations: High Altitude Observatory, National Center for Atmospheric Research, Boulder, 80302, Colo., United States
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, K., High Altitude Observatory, National Center for Atmospheric Research, Boulder, 80302, Colo., United States; Nakagawa, Y., High Altitude Observatory, National Center for Atmospheric Research, Boulder, 80302, Colo., United States
Abstract: On the basis of observations (Zirin and Tanaka, 1973) inferring the presence of shear in magnetic fields, the amount of extractable energy stored in a class of force-free magnetic fields is evaluated for the flares of August 1972, using the formulations developed by Nakagawa and Raadu (1972). It is shown that the evaluated energy storage could be built up by the proper motions of sunspots in the active region McMath 11976 during July 31 and August 7. Then for the flare of August 7, a detailed analysis is made of the manner of energy release in the post maximum phases deduced from the configuration of flare loops. It is shown that the observed flare loops could be represented closely by the force-free magnetic fields and that the evaluated rate of energy release is consistent with observed rate given by the soft X-ray emission. The results of analysis suggest that the flare of August 1972 could be identified with the relaxation of an energetic force-free magnetic field towards lower energy states. The limitations and possible future extension of this type of analysis are discussed. © 1973 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Title: Blood flow and fatty acid release by cervical adipose tissue of rabbits
Authors with affiliations: Hardman, M.J.; Hull, D.
Abstract: 1. A direct technique was used to measure blood flow and exchange of metabolites by cervical adipose tissue in 3‐month‐old and adult rabbits. 2. The initial blood flow from adipose tissue of fed 3‐month‐old rabbits was 0·45 ml./g tissue.min and the tissue released fatty acids and glycerol. In similar rabbits unfed for 24 hr, fatty acid release increased fourfold. Both the rate of blood flow and the arterio‐venous difference of fatty acid increased. In fed adult rabbits blood flow was 0·16 ml./g tissue.min. 3. Noradrenaline infusion in both young and adult rabbits stimulated a rapid and large increase in cervical adipose tissue blood flow together with an increase in fatty acid and glycerol release. Glucose uptake remained small. No increase in local heat production in cervical adipose tissue was detected during noradrenaline infusion. 4. It is concluded that cervical adipose tissue in adult rabbits is actively concerned in energy storage and supply. © 1973 The Physiological Society
Index Keywords: noradrenalin; adipose tissue; blood flow; fatty acid release; in vitro study; theoretical study; Adipose Tissue; Animal; Animals, Newborn; Blood Flow Velocity; Blood Glucose; Body Temperature Regulation; Fatty Acids; Food; Glucose; Glycerol; Norepinephrine; Rabbits

Title: Is there a discrepancy in isodoublet Coulomb displacement energies?
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA 22901, United States
Authors with affiliations: Noble, J.V., Department of Physics, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA 22901, United States
Abstract: In mirror nuclei with one valence nucleon outside a doubly closed-shell core, there has been a long-standing discrepancy between experimental and theoretical values of their mass-splitting. If the matter distribution of the core protons in the neutron-rich storage is slightly larger in radius than that for the core protons in the proton-rich analogue, this discrepancy can be explained. © 1973.

Authors: Amendolia S.R., Bellettini G., Braccini P.L., Bradaschia C., Castaldi R., Cavasinni V., Cerri C., Del Prete T., Foà L., Giromini P., Laurelli P., Menzione A., Ristori L., Sanguinetti G., Valdata M., Finocchiaro G., Grannis P., Green D., Mustard R., Thun R.
Title: Total cross-section measurement at the ISR

Menzione, A., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Pisa, Pisa, Italy, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, Pisa, Italy, Scuola Normale Superiore, Pisa, Italy; Ristori, L., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Pisa, Pisa, Italy, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, Pisa, Italy, Scuola Normale Superiore, Pisa, Italy; Y., United States; Mustard, R., State University of New York, Stony Brook, N. Y., United States; Thun, R., State University of New York, Stony Brook, N. Y., United States
Abstract: We present the first results of an experiment at the CERN intersecting storage rings, which measures the total cross-section in proton-proton collisions. The equivalent laboratory momenta are 291, 496, 1068 and 1480 GeV/c. We have made a direct measurement of αT as the ratio between the total interaction rate and the machine luminosity. The present paper gives a detailed description of the experimental apparatus and of the analysis procedure. We find that αT increases by about 10% in the energy region studied. © 1973 Società Italiana di Fisica.

Authors: Engels J., Schilling K., Satz H.
Title: Statistical and thermodynamic descriptions of hadron production in e+e- annihilation
Affiliations: Department of Theoretical Physics, University of Bielefeld, Bielefeld, Germany; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Engels, J., Department of Theoretical Physics, University of Bielefeld, Bielefeld, Germany; Schilling, K., Department of Theoretical Physics, University of Bielefeld, Bielefeld, Germany; Satz, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The statistical model and the thermodynamic (statistical bootstrap) model are formulated for multihadron production in e+e- annihilation. Asymptotic results are derived for both approaches, with particular attention to critical features subject to experimental test. Quantitative predictions of multiplicities, average secondary energies and inclusive single-particle distributions are presented for storage ring centre-of-mass energies from 2 to 6 GeV. © 1973 Società Italiana di Fisica.

Authors: Hurych Z., Buczek D., Wood C., Lapeyre G.J., Baer A.D.
Title: Strong polarization dependence and selenium lone-pairs in the photoemission spectra of Sb2Se3
Affiliations: Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States; Physics Department, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59715, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hurych, Z., Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States; Buczek, D., Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States; Wood, C., Physics Department, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115, United States; Lapeyre, G.J., Physics Department, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59715, United States; Baer, A.D., Physics Department, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59715, United States
Abstract: The photoemission energy distribution curves (EDC's) of crystalline and amorphous Sb2Se3 were measured in the photon energy range hv=7 to 20 eV using polarized radiation from a synchroton storage ring. The EDC's show that the six electrons per Sb2Se3 molecule, attributed primarily to the selenium p-pairs, are clearly separated from the remaining part of the valence band of crystalline Sb2Se3. The optical transitions from these states occur with matrix elements strongly dependent on the orientation of the electrical vector of the polarized radiation as a result of crystal field effects. Model densities of states are constructed for both crystalline and amorphous Sb2Se3. © 1973.
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTING ANTIMONY COMPOUNDS

Title: Geothermal resources in the imperial valley of california
Affiliations: Republic Geothermal, Inc., 11848 E. Washington Blvd., Whittier, 90606, Calif, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rex, R.W., Republic Geothermal, Inc., 11848 E. Washington Blvd., Whittier, 90606, Calif, United States
Abstract: The Imperial Valley is a major rift valley characterized by unusually high heat flow and large quantities of water in storage in the thick fill of alluvium provided by the sediments of the delta of the Colorado River. The inventory of hot water appears to be sufliciently large that if used for water desalination it might add several million acreleet of new water to the resources of the lower Colorado River basin. This distilled water would serve to lower river salinity and provide extra water to help meet the U. S. - Mexico treaty commitments. A major fraction of water desalination costs lie in the cost of energy and are related to desalination technology which is directly related to water chemistry. The discovery of low salinity geothermal waters in the Imperial Valley opened th possibility for a major breakthrough in lowered water desalination costs. We have tried to develop a broad understanding of the origins of the waters of the Imperial Valley and how natural recharge occurs. The chemical composition of the waters of the central portion of Imperial Valley basin waters, while not that of present surface flow of the rivers, nevertheless does have a close affinity to Colorado River water. No sea water seems to be present in the valley although marine sediments appear to occur on basement on West Mesa and on basement to the east in Arizona south of Yuma. Low salinity waters dominate the basin hydrology and waters as saline or more saline than sea water appear to be restricted to the immediate area of the Salton Sea. The isotope work of T. Coplen makes it possible to determine the relative contribution of precipitation runoff from California watersheds and from Colorado River water. Both sources are significant. The Colorado River water in aquifers from 100-400 m appears to have been entrapped from a relatively homogeneous basin which was subject to substantial evaporation. Its original source was snow melt water from the Colorado River. Five types of waters, none of them sea water, were recognized by their salt geochemistry. Bromide/chloride data are particularly effective in resolving different types of water masses. The bromide/chloride data agree with the isotope data and identify rainfall and precipitation runoff from the high mountains to the west. Modern Colorado River water is easily recognized by its salts and two types of ancient Colorado River waters from previous lake stage are proposed on the basis of the bromide/chloride data. One old lake occurring during the pluvial stage associated with the last Ice Age is proposed to account for much of the water in artesian aquifers. Another younger lake stage, possibly with Lake Cahuilla affinities is also suggested. Mountain runoff waters can be distinguished in the subsurface by their relatively lower salinity and high bicarbonate concentration, and their heavy isotopic composition. Revised fluid reserve calculations based on additional porosity data continue to show that the low salinity water resources of the Imperial Valley may exceed two billion acre-feet. The oceanic plate tectonic model is modified in the Imperial Valley by the evidence of a series of complex blocks with the generation of both tensional and compressional features in the valley. Major strike slip faults dominate the tectonic fabric but conjugate features increase complexity by a large degree and a major amount of work will be needed before any geologically sound structural models can be generated. Xenoliths within the obsidians at the volcanoes at the south end of the Salton Sea provide samples of the basement under the Imperial Valley. These xenoliths include partially remelted granitic rocks, fragments of basalt, greenschist, and baked shale and sandstone. This is taken as evidence that the basement in the valley consists in part of partially remelted granite. This would render basement plastic and readily deformed. The source of the heat is suggested to be derived from basalt that comes into the basement and deeper sediments from below. This upward movement of basalt along a spreading zone is the continental equivalent to a sea floor spreading area. In the continental case the insulating blanket of wet sediment retains the heat and appears to produce a major geothermal resource. The geothermal resources of the Imperial Valley are the aggregate of the thermal energy of the large inventory of subsurface water heated by the complex mix of intrusive phenomena. The net result is to generate a polygenetic geothermal resource of very large dimensions. © 1973 Stabilimento Tipografico Francesco Gianni & Figli.

Authors: Faiman M.D., Myers M.B., Schowen R.L.
Title: Post-mortem degradation kinetics of brain norepinephrine
Affiliations: Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, School of Pharmacy, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States
Authors with affiliations: Faiman, M.D., Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, School of Pharmacy, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Myers, M.B., Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, School of Pharmacy, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Schowen, R.L., Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, School of Pharmacy, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States
Abstract: The post-mortem degradation kinetics of norepinephrine (NE) from brain stored at 25°, 15°, 0°, -5° and -10° have been determined. The first 20 per cent of NE was lost by zero-order kinetics, while degradation of the major part of the remaining NE followed two consecutive first-order processes. Both the zero- and first-order constants showed a temperature dependency and were used to construct Arrhenius temperature plots. The zero- and first-order rate constants yielded energies of activation of 17.2 and 16.3 kcal mole respectively. When stored at 25°, approximately 25 per cent of total NE remained in mouse brain 144 hr after death. The amount of NE remaining 144 hr postmortem increased as the storage temperature decreased. Post-mortem NE degradation kinetics also were studied in rats. The NE degradation kinetics in rat brain were similar to those observed in mice. Although the zero-order degradation rate constant for rats was about one-third that found for mice, no difference was found in the first-order rate constants. Oxidative metabolism of NE in rat brain stopped shortly after death and metabolism proceeded non-oxidatively via normetanephrine. Monoamine oxidase (MAO) activity in mouse brain post-mortem also was found to be temperature dependent. Approximately 75 per cent of MAO activity remained in mouse brain when stored for 144 hr at 25°, while approximately 90 per cent remained when stored at -10°. © 1973.

Authors: Dwyer M., Geue R.J., Snow M.R.
Title: Symmetry-Constrained Force Fields in the Prediction of Molecular Geometries of Metal Complexes. I
Affiliations: Department of Physical, Inorganic Chemistry, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, 5001, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Dwyer, M., Department of Physical, Inorganic Chemistry, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, 5001, Australia; Geue, R.J., Department of Physical, Inorganic Chemistry, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, 5001, Australia; Snow, M.R., Department of Physical, Inorganic Chemistry, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, 5001, Australia
Abstract: The theoretical and practical aspects of symmetry-dependent strain energy refinement of the structures of metal complexes are reported. Use of this procedure reduces computation per cycle to approximately one-fifth of that required by independent refinement and in addition requires substantially less core storage. The fixing of individual cartesian atomic coordinates in both independent and symmetry-dependent refinements is discussed and in particular it is shown how a symmetry trap may be avoided. For the symmetrical facial bis(diethylenetriamine)cobalt(III) ion, results of independent and symmetry-dependent refinements constrained to two symmetry point groups are presented and compared with X-ray crystal data. Calculations on the lowest strain energy isomer of carbonatobis(trimethylenediamine)cobalt(III) are also cited. © 1973, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Ahmad A., Bishayee S., Bachhawat B.K.
Title: A novel method for immobilization of chicken brain Arylsulfatase A using Concanavalin A
Affiliations: Neurochemistry Laboratory, Department of Neurological Sciences, Christian Medical College Hospital, Vallore, India
Authors with affiliations: Ahmad, A., Neurochemistry Laboratory, Department of Neurological Sciences, Christian Medical College Hospital, Vallore, India; Bishayee, S., Neurochemistry Laboratory, Department of Neurological Sciences, Christian Medical College Hospital, Vallore, India; Bachhawat, B.K., Neurochemistry Laboratory, Department of Neurological Sciences, Christian Medical College Hospital, Vallore, India
Abstract: Chicken brain Arylsulfatase A (E.C.3.1.6.1) was immobilized by interaction with Concanavalin A. The immobilized enzyme retained its catalytic activity and this enzyme can be reused without appreciable loss of activity. The storage stability of bound and soluble enzymes was comparable and binding of enzyme to Concanavalin A increases its thermal stability. Kinetic studies indicated that bound enzyme shows similar anomalous kinetics as that of free enzyme but slight change was observed in relation to pH optima, Km value and activation energy. © 1973.

Title: A model of solar flares and faculae
Affiliations: CSIRO Division of Physics, National Standards Laboratory, Sydney, 2008, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Piddington, J.H., CSIRO Division of Physics, National Standards Laboratory, Sydney, 2008, Australia
Abstract: Theories of solar flares based on the storage of energy (usually as magnetic energy) in the solar atmosphere are shown to be incompatible with observational data. The sunspot energy deficit and the photospheric faculae both involve energy fluxes comparable with the flare requirement ( {Mathematical expression} 3 × 1029 erg s-1). Both also require a subsurface system of waves or oscillations, perhaps those discussed by Danielson and Savage and by Wilson. The flare model proposed is based on a temporary diversion of this energy carried by Alfvén waves through spots and magnetic elements or micro-pores; the calculated plasma perturbation velocity in the umbra is about 6 km s-1 for a major flare. In the atmosphere the wave energy divides into two parts to produce the cool, stationary optical flare and the particle flare. The first part is dissipated around flux tubes which are mainly horizontal in the chromosphere and which tend to concentrate along the magnetic neutral line (B∥ = 0). Each tube vibrates individually as a taut wire in a viscous fluid, to excite the fluid just outside the tube. The second part of the energy emerges along tubes mainly vertical in the chromosphere and is converted to shock waves in the corona and then to particle energy for the radio and X-ray flare and the blast wave. The model includes white-light faculae, quasi-permanent X-ray and fast-particle emissions, sympathetic flares and surges. An unambiguous test would be provided by observations of plasma motions of a few kilometres per second in spots and micro-pores. © 1973 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Title: Energy conservation capacity and morphological integrity of mitochondria in hypotonically treated rabbit epididymal spermatozoa
Affiliations: Johnson Research Foundation, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19174, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keyhani, E., Johnson Research Foundation, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19174, United States; Storey, B.T., Johnson Research Foundation, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19174, United States
Abstract: Hypotonic treatment of rabbit epididymal spermatozoa in 10 mM phosphate buffer disrupts the plasma membrane and removes the cytoplasmic droplet from those cells to which it is still attached. There is, however, no effect on the mitochondria, which retain their helical configuration around the axial filament complex, have intact inner and outer membranes, and show the same cristal morphology as do the mitochondria in untreated cells. Hypotonically treated spermatozoa respire with added malate-pyruvate, succinate, and ascorbate plus N,N′-tetramethyl-p-phenylenediamine, but not with added fructose or NADH. Respiration is inhibited by oligomycin and stimulated by uncoupler, showing that the mitochondria have retained their capacity for energy conservation. The uncoupled respiration rate is not further stimulated by added cytochrome c. Reduced-minus-oxidized difference spectra obtained at -196 °C of the hypotonically treated cells show a full complement of cytochromes, including cytochrome c. This result implies that the cytochrome c lost from mammalian spermatozoa on storage or chilling [Mann, T. (1951) Biochem. J. 48, 386-388] is cytoplasmic cytochrome c not yet incorporated into the mitochondria. The mitochondrial cytochrome c remains firmly held inside the intact outer membrane. © 1973.
Index Keywords: cytochrome c; energy; epididymis; mitochondrion; spermatozoon; theoretical study; Animal; Cell Fractionation; Cell Membrane; Cytochrome c; Cytochromes; Epididymis; Hypotonic Solutions; Malates; Male; Microscopy, Electron; Mitochondria; Oligomycins; Oxidation-Reduction; Oxygen Consumption; Pyruvates; Rabbits; Spectrophotometry; Spermatozoa; Succinates; Uncoupling Agents

Authors: Boehm C.F., Jr., Allan J.J., III
Title: Parameter sensitivity studies for internal combustion engine control and design purposes
Affiliations: Slumberger Well Services, P.O. Box 2175, Houston, TX  77001, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX  78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boehm, C.F., Jr., Slumberger Well Services, P.O. Box 2175, Houston, TX  77001, United States; Allan, J.J., III, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX  78712, United States
Abstract: The computer simulation of internal combustion engines is a task that numerous researchers have contributed to in recent years, primarily because of the advent of digital computers with large storage and fast processing capabilities. Engine simulation is particularly important today as we try to solve the problems of air pollution and energy depletion. Many aspects of engine operation are poorly understood because of the problems encountered when attempting to measure the variables that describe the engine's operation. This fact complicates both the control and design of engines. Parameter sensitivity studies could very well lead to improved performance measures that will enhance both the control and design of internal combustion engines in the years to come. These studies are discussed here in terms of what they could contribute for control and also for design purposes. © 1973 Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc..
Index Keywords: Combustion; Combustion equipment; Computer aided design; Digital computers; Energy depletion; Engine operations; Engine simulation; Fast Processing; Parameter sensitivities; Performance measure; Internal combustion engines

Thun, R., State University of New York, Stony Brook, NY, United States
Abstract: We present direct tests of the hypothesis of limiting fragmentation from an experiment at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings at centre-of-mass energies between 31 and 53 GeV. Single-particle inclusive distributions and partial multiplicity distributions are observed for the case in which the energy of one beam is fixed while varying the energy of the other beam. Within cones around the beam, limiting fragmentation is shown to be valid. © 1973.

Title: Multihadronic cross sections from e+ e- annihilation up to 3 GeV c.m. energy
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Italy; Laboratori Nazionali, CNEN, Frascati, Italy

Abstract: With an apparatus slightly improved with respect to a previous one we have studied multihadronic production at the Adone e+ e- storage ring up to a maximum center of mass energy of 3 GeV. © 1973.

Authors: Banner M., Hamel J.L., Pansart J.P., Stirling A.V., Teiger J., Zaccone H., Zsembery J., Bassompierre G., Croissiaux M., Greeser J., Morand R., Riedinger M., Schneegans M.
Title: Large transverse momentum particle production at 90° in proton-proton collisions at the ISR
Affiliations: Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Centre de Recherches Nucléaires de Strasbourg, France
Authors with affiliations: Banner, M., Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Hamel, J.L., Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Pansart, J.P., Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Stirling, A.V., Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Teiger, J., Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Zaccone, H., Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Zsembery, J., Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Saclay, France; Bassompierre, G., Centre de Recherches Nucléaires de Strasbourg, France; Croissiaux, M., Centre de Recherches Nucléaires de Strasbourg, France; Greeser, J., Centre de Recherches Nucléaires de Strasbourg, France; Morand, R., Centre de Recherches Nucléaires de Strasbourg, France; Riedinger, M., Centre de Recherches Nucléaires de Strasbourg, France; Schneegans, M., Centre de Recherches Nucléaires de Strasbourg, France
Abstract: Total charged particle fluxes above 1.2 GeV/c transverse momentum at 90° have been measured at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings for c.m. energies between 23.2 and 52.7 GeV. In addition, charged pion spectra above 3 GeV/c have been obtained at 44.4 and 52.7 GeV, as well as gamma-ray spectra at the same energies. The upper limit to produce a single electron above 3 GeV/c at 90° is less than 1.2 × 10-33 cm2/sr at 90% confidence level. © 1973.

Authors: van de Kamer J.C., Wilschut I.J.C., Heussen A.M.A.
Title: On the presence and localization of glycogen accumulations inside coronet cells of the saccus vasculosus of the dogfish (Scylliorhinus caniculus)
Source title: Zeitschrift für Zellforschung und Mikroskopische Anatomie
Affiliations: Zoological Laboratory, Section of Histology and Cell Biology, State University of Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: van de Kamer, J.C., Zoological Laboratory, Section of Histology and Cell Biology, State University of Utrecht, Netherlands; Wilschut, I.J.C., Zoological Laboratory, Section of Histology and Cell Biology, State University of Utrecht, Netherlands; Heussen, A.M.A., Zoological Laboratory, Section of Histology and Cell Biology, State University of Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: In several coronet cells of the saccus vasculosus of Scylliorhinus large quantities of glycogen occur, as shown by light and electron microscopy. The significance of glycogen as an energy storage necessary for a transcellular ion transport process taking place in the coronet cells is discussed. © 1973 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Simultaneous storage of spectra and additional signals by a multichannel spectrometer
Affiliations: Central Institute of Nuclear Research Rossendorf, Department of Nuclear Chemistry, P.O. Box 19, 8051 Dresden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Görner, W., Central Institute of Nuclear Research Rossendorf, Department of Nuclear Chemistry, P.O. Box 19, 8051 Dresden, Germany; Rost, A., Central Institute of Nuclear Research Rossendorf, Department of Nuclear Chemistry, P.O. Box 19, 8051 Dresden, Germany
Abstract: A special translator feeds several rates of additional (clock-time, life-time, control or monitor) pulses into reserved channels of the corresponding energy spectrum. Two versions of the device are dealt with. Their counting losses are studied by the help of a Monte Carlo program. Among the possible cases of application a combined correction of irradiation dose, cooling, and dead-time affected measurement in activation analysis is regarded more closely. © 1973.
