Sette, G., III.Physikalisches Institut der Technischen Hochschule, Aachen, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, United States, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Genova, Genova, Italy, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Torino, Torino, Italy; Staude, A., III.Physikalisches Institut der Technischen Hochschule, Aachen, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, United States, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Genova, Genova, Italy, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Torino, Torino, Italy; Strolin, P., III.Physikalisches Institut der Technischen Hochschule, Aachen, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, United States, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Genova, Genova, Italy, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Torino, Torino, Italy; Tittel, K., III.Physikalisches Institut der Technischen Hochschule, Aachen, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Department of Physics, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, United States, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Genova, Genova, Italy, Istituto di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Sezione di Torino, Torino, Italy
Abstract: The angular distribution of charged particles emitted between 47° and 90° in the centre of mass has been measured at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings with a hodoscope of scintillation counters and for centre-of-mass energies Ecm = 30.2, 44.7 and 52.7 GeV. Data are compatible with distributions of the type 1/σinel × dσ/dΩ(θcm) = A(Ecm) sin-2 θcm. The values of A(Ecm) are about a factor of two greater than the predictions of scaling from data at Ecm=6.0 GeV. The shape of the angular distribution provides evidence for a flat distribution in the "rapidity" variable y = artanh(pL/E). © 1972.

Authors: Benaksas D., Cosme G., Jean-Marie B., Jullian S., Laplanche F., Lefrançois J., Liberman A.D., Parrour G., Repellin J.P., Sauvage G.
Title: π+π- production by e+e- annihilation in the ϱ energy range with the Orsay storage ring
Affiliations: Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Benaksas, D., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Cosme, G., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Jean-Marie, B., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Jullian, S., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Laplanche, F., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Lefrançois, J., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Liberman, A.D., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Parrour, G., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Repellin, J.P., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France; Sauvage, G., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Université Paris-Sud, 91-Orsay, France
Abstract: A large solid angle detector has been used to observe two body events produced by electron-positron collisions in the Orsay storage ring. From the π+π- excitation curve in the ρ{variant} region we have deduced the amplitude and the phase of the ω-ρ{variant} interference, and the ρ{variant} resonance paramaters: Mρ{variant} = (775.4±7.3) MeV, Γρ{variant} = (149.6 ± 23.2) MeV, √B(ω→π+π-) = 0.19 ± 0.05, φ = (85.7 ± 15.3)0, σ(e+e-→ρ{variant}) = (1.00 ± 0.13) μb at S = Mρ{variant}2, B(ρ{variant}→e+e- = (4.1 ± 0.5) × 10-5, Γ(ρ{variant}→e+e-) = (6.1 ± 0.7) keV, (gρ{variant}2/4π) = 2.26 ± 0.25, (gρ{variant}ππ2/4π) = 2.84 ± 0.50. © 1972.

Authors: Bacci C., Penso G., Salvini G., Stella B., Baldini-Celio R., Capon G., Mencuccini C., Murtas G.P., Reale A., Spinetti M.
Title: Multihadronic cross sections from e+e- annihilation at C.M. energies between 1.4 and 2.4 GeV
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Italy; Laboratori Nazionali, CNEN, Frascati, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bacci, C., Istituto di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Italy; Penso, G., Istituto di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Italy; Salvini, G., Istituto di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Italy; Stella, B., Istituto di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Italy; Baldini-Celio, R., Laboratori Nazionali, CNEN, Frascati, Italy; Capon, G., Laboratori Nazionali, CNEN, Frascati, Italy; Mencuccini, C., Laboratori Nazionali, CNEN, Frascati, Italy; Murtas, G.P., Laboratori Nazionali, CNEN, Frascati, Italy; Reale, A., Laboratori Nazionali, CNEN, Frascati, Italy; Spinetti, M., Laboratori Nazionali, CNEN, Frascati, Italy
Abstract: Multihadronic production has been observed at the Adone e+e- storage ring, in the c.m. energy range 1.4 - 2.4 GeV. The cross sections for the reactions e+ + e- → 2π± + nπo (1 ≤ n ≤ 4) and e+ + e- → (4π± + nπ±) (0 ≤ n ≤ 2) have been measured, assuming that the produced particles are only pions with a pure phase space momentum distribution. © 1972.

Authors: Heinrich P., Da Prada M., Pletscher A.
Title: Magnesium-dependent ATP-ase in membranes of 5-hydroxytryptamine storage organelles
Affiliations: Research Department, F. Hoffmann-La Roche and Co. Ltd, Basel, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Heinrich, P., Research Department, F. Hoffmann-La Roche and Co. Ltd, Basel, Switzerland; Da Prada, M., Research Department, F. Hoffmann-La Roche and Co. Ltd, Basel, Switzerland; Pletscher, A., Research Department, F. Hoffmann-La Roche and Co. Ltd, Basel, Switzerland
Abstract: Isolated membranes from subcellular organelles storing 5-hydroxytryptamine and ATP in rabbit blood platelets contain an ATP-ase which is specifically stimulated by Mg. The Km values for ATP and Mg are 0.3 × 10-3 M and 0.6 × 10-3 M respectively. The activation energy amounts to 5.1 kcal/mole. N-Ethylmaleimide, Na+ and Ca++, but not ouabain, inhibit the Mg++ activated enzyme. The ATP-ase of the membranes of platelet organelles differs from that of the cytoplasmatic platelet membrane and of catecholamine storage organelles. © 1972.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphatase; calcium; magnesium; n ethylmaleimide; ouabain; serotonin; sodium; animal; article; cytology; cytoplasm; density gradient centrifugation; drug effect; enzyme activation; enzymology; kinetics; membrane; physical chemistry; rabbit; thrombocyte; Adenosinetriphosphatase; Animal; Blood Platelets; Calcium; Centrifugation, Density Gradient; Chemistry, Physical; Enzyme Activation; Ethylmaleimide; Kinetics; Magnesium; Membranes; Organoids; Ouabain; Rabbits; Serotonin; Sodium

Title: Energy storage in ceramic dielectrics
Affiliations: Sprague Electric Company, North Adams, 01247, Massachusetts, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burn, I., Sprague Electric Company, North Adams, 01247, Massachusetts, United States; Smyth, D.M., Sprague Electric Company, North Adams, 01247, Massachusetts, United States
Abstract: An evaluation has been made of the energy storage capabilities of ceramic dielectrics that were considered likely to provide high energy/volume efficiency on the basis of their expected permittivity-field characteristics. Data for fields up to 400 kV/cm are presented for a strontium titanate, and for a barium titanate ceramic. The materials were in thick-film form and bonded with a small amount of glass. At the maximum fields, energy storage in the barium titanate ceramic was close to that reported earlier for glass-bonded lead zirconate (approx. 2.0 J/cm3), but was about 30% lower in the strontium titanate material. © 1972 Chapman and Hall Ltd.

Title: Component Testing of hvdc Circuit Breakers. [UNTERSUCHUNGEN ZUR KOMPONENTENPRUEFUNG VON HGU-SCHALTERN.]
Authors with affiliations: Brumshagen, Harald
Abstract: Component testing of dc circuit breakers with inductive energy storage at low test voltage is described showing that the effect of the missing high test voltage can be compensated by a variable storage inductance and an additional parallel voltage source of low energy.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON DEVICE TESTING; ELECTRIC CIRCUIT BREAKERS

Authors: Bertin A., Capiluppi P., Cristallini A., D'Agostino-Bruno M., Ellis R.J., Giacomelli G., Maroni C., Mercatali F., Rossi A.M., Vannini G.
Title: Negative particle production at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy; Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bertin, A., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Capiluppi, P., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Cristallini, A., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; D'Agostino-Bruno, M., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Ellis, R.J., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Giacomelli, G., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Maroni, C., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Mercatali, F., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Rossi, A.M., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Vannini, G., Istituto di Fisica dell Università di Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale, Fisica Nucleare - Sezione di Bologna, Italy
Abstract: Preliminary results on the production of negative particles in inclusive reactions at intermediate angles (80-200 mrad) at the CERN ISR are reported. Pion production is still the dominant process; within our experimental errors, scaling holds for negative pions or alternatively a limiting distribution is reached at relatively low energies. However the antiproton production cross-sections are apparently larger than smaller energies. © 1972.

Authors: Grasser R., May A., Scharmann A.
Title: Thermoluminescence of ZnS
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section A Journal of Physical Sciences
Affiliations: I. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Gießen, D-6300 Gießen, Leihgesternerweg 104-108, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Grasser, R., I. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Gießen, D-6300 Gießen, Leihgesternerweg 104-108, Germany; May, A., I. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Gießen, D-6300 Gießen, Leihgesternerweg 104-108, Germany; Scharmann, A., I. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Gießen, D-6300 Gießen, Leihgesternerweg 104-108, Germany
Abstract: A number of zinc sulphide phosphors containing cobalt was prepared with various concentrations of additional impurities. Co++-ions in both copper and silver activated phosphors produce a characteristic glowcurve, showing three distinct peaks above liquid nitrogen temperature. It was established that the first and probably the second glowpeak is connected with distinct traps, while the third peak is caused by a continuous distribution of traps. Measurements of thermoluminescence spectra as well as investigations of energy storage capacity and temperature dependence of electron capture in traps pointed to a local association of traps and luminescence centres in the case of the first two glowpeaks, whereas electron transfer via the conduction band from traps to separated luminescence centers was assumed for the third peak. An already existing model was used for discussing the experimental results obtained. © 1972 Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.

Title: Three application areas for srti03 glass-ceramics
Affiliations: Research and Development Laboratory, Corning Glass Works, Corning, New York 14830, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lawless, W.N., Research and Development Laboratory, Corning Glass Works, Corning, New York 14830, United States
Abstract: The perovskite SrTiO, can be controllably crystallized in situ in a glass matrix and the resulting glass-ceramic displays a large peak in the dielectric constant at about 75 K (shifted from 35 K by doping and glass-chemistry techniques) and a T-'in crease in the dielectric constant below 0.1 K. This high degree of dielectric activity at cryogenic temperatures makes possible three potential applications: (1) A capacitance thermometer with a range from 0.1 to 70K which is unaffected by magnetic fields: (2) A 77 K capacitance energy-storage device; and (3) An adiabatic-depolarization cooling device below 0.1 K. © 1972, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Title: Suppression of the kink instability for magnetic flux ropes in the chromosphere
Affiliations: High Altitude Observatory, National Center for Atmospheric Research, Boulder, Colo., United States
Authors with affiliations: Raadu, M.A., High Altitude Observatory, National Center for Atmospheric Research, Boulder, Colo., United States
Abstract: Energy storage in chromospheric flux ropes is discussed, in the context of solar flares. The structure is represented by a cylindrically symmetric magnetic field of finite length. The field is assumed to be approximately force-free. The stability of the field to a kink perturbation is investigated. Flux ropes are rooted in dense photospheric material. So the ends of the field lines are taken to be fixed on rigid boundaries for all perturbations. An energy perturbation method is used and the boundary conditions give a stabilizing effect. It is shown that for a moderate degree of twisting the fields are stable to a kink perturbation. Thus energy can be stored in cylindrical fields prior to release in a solar flare. © 1972 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Title: An analytic method for closed orbit correction in high energy synchrotrons
Affiliations: Rutherford High Energy Laboratory, Chilton, Didcot, Berkshire England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Maidment, J.R., Rutherford High Energy Laboratory, Chilton, Didcot, Berkshire England, United Kingdom; Planner, C.W., Rutherford High Energy Laboratory, Chilton, Didcot, Berkshire England, United Kingdom
Abstract: An analytic method is presented, which allows minimisation of the closed orbit at a number of specified points around the orbit by means of special correcting dipoles or by transverse displacement of the lattice quadrupoles. The method may be applied to any number of sensor/correcting element combinations and is therefore particularly suitable for synchrotrons greater than 100 GeV. The magnitude of computation and computer storage required for the application of the method is comparatively small. © 1972.

Authors: Neuhofer G., Niebergall F., Penzias J., Regler M., Schmidt-Parzefall W., Schubert K.R., Schumacher P.E., Steuer M., Winter K.
Title: Single γ-ray spectra from proton-proton collisions at centre-of-mass energies from 30 to 50 GeV
Authors with affiliations: Neuhofer, G.; Niebergall, F.; Penzias, J.; Regler, M.; Schmidt-Parzefall, W.; Schubert, K.R.; Schumacher, P.E.; Steuer, M.; Winter, K.
Abstract: The energy spectra of single γ-rays produced in proton-proton collisions at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings have been measured at three primary energies and four production angles: ECM = 30.2 GeV, 44.7 GeV and 52.7 GeV,θCM = 10.2°, 6.4°, 23.5° and 90°.The results are shown to be compatible with the conjecture of limiting distributions. A simple interpolation formula is presented. © 1972.

Title: Recent development in LNG transportation & storage
Affiliations: Norther and Central Gas Corporation, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Orbach, J.L.L., Norther and Central Gas Corporation, Canada
Abstract: The paper seeks to outline the probable pattern of development over the decade and first looks at progress made so far, projects approaching maturity and published plans. In section 2 attention is given to the international energy market and to its need for natural gas; to possible sources and future capital needs. Section 3 pinpoints Canadas position and potential participation in these developments. © Annual Technical Meeting, PETSOC ATM 1972. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Energy markets; First look; Pattern of development; Natural gas transportation

Authors: Hamilton B.K., Young C., Talley C.P., Chakravarti K., Finlow D.E., Wright W.H.
Title: Energy requirements - Correlation between occupant, bag and inflator
Affiliations: Allied Chemical Co., United States
Authors with affiliations: Hamilton, B.K., Allied Chemical Co., United States; Young, C., Allied Chemical Co., United States; Talley, C.P., Allied Chemical Co., United States; Chakravarti, K., Allied Chemical Co., United States; Finlow, D.E., Allied Chemical Co., United States; Wright, W.H., Allied Chemical Co., United States
Abstract: Part I of this paper discusses a computer model of a hybrid air cushion inflator which models existing systems to a high degree of accuracy. Gas generator size and ballistic properties, stored gas composition, storage pressure, volume, temperature, and receiving tank parameters can be varied to accurately predict the effects of system changes on inflator performance. In Part II, an approach for analytically obtaining equations of motion for torsos during contact with gas cushions in frontal collisions and subsequent ride-down characteristics is developed. From these equations, calculations of torso "g" forces, cushion pressures and other system parameters can be made. It is then possible to optimize these parameters in terms of desired torso response under a variety of design criteria as a guide to system design and experimental verification.
Index Keywords: Gas generators; Ballistic properties; Computer modeling; Energy requirements; Experimental verification; Frontal collision; Gas compositions; High degree of accuracy; Storage pressures; Equations of motion

Title: Volute spring bumper system
Affiliations: Automotive Products Div., North American Rockwell Corp., United States
Authors with affiliations: Golze, R.R., Automotive Products Div., North American Rockwell Corp., United States
Abstract: There are numerous engineering solutions to the energy management problem in low-speed vehicle bumper impact situations. This paper covers a North American Rockwell volute spring energy storage assembly. Selection of a system involves price, performance, installation, weatherability, reliability, etc. Extensive tests-pendulum corner impact, barrier, and pendulum-were carried out and showed that the volute spring assembly on a test vehicle withstood more than 100 impacts without evidence of failure.
Index Keywords: Automotive engineering; Pendulums; Bumper systems; Engineering solutions; Low speed vehicle; Management problems; North American; Rockwell; Test vehicle; Weatherability; Automobiles

Title: Application engineering of a maintenance-free capacitor discharge ignition system
Affiliations: Prestolite Co., United States
Authors with affiliations: Hardin, J.T., Prestolite Co., United States; Sieja, N.F., Prestolite Co., United States
Abstract: An ignition system with a 3500 h life capability has been developed for tactical military vehicles. An extensive test program was used to develop a capacitor discharge ignition system, composed of a capacitor energy storage system, a noncontacting metal detector timing system, a special coil, shielded ignition cable, and surface gap spark plugs. It provides ignition performance advantages, a single spark plug heat range, and is compatible with 4-, 6-, and 8-cyl military engines. The characteristics of various ignition systems were studied on the bench and on the dynamometer over a wide range of engine operation. The final design's capability to provide engine performance equivalent to the standard system was verified. The advantages and disadvantages of each ignition type is discussed.
Index Keywords: Automotive engineering; Military vehicles; Software testing; Spark plugs; Application engineering; Capacitor discharge; Capacitor energy; Engine operations; Engine performance; Maintenance free; Military engines; Single spark plugs; Ignition systems

Authors: Mole C.J., Parker J.H., Lowry L.R., Carpetis C., Gayte M., Girard B., Malandain A., Stumpf O., Loeser H., Genevey P., Prost G., Sole J., Girard B.

Title: Silver zinc batteries in pressure proof containers for high density energy storage in deep submersibles
Affiliations: University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Heronemus, W., University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States; Birtcher, W., University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Abstract: A concept for storing energy in small silver-zinc cells enclosed in pressure proof glass instrument housings is presented. These Energy Spheres can be configured to cover a large range of weight to displacement ratios. The resulting energy storage systems are shown to be highly competitive with the popular pressure balanced systems used in many submersibles. © 1972 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Oceanography; Silver; Submersibles; Zinc; Balanced systems; Displacement ratios; Energy storage systems; High density energy; Silver-zinc; Secondary batteries

Title: The use of hydraulic cushioning in the docking of super tankers
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Offshore Technology Conference
Affiliations: W-K-F Valve Div. of ACF Industries, United States
Authors with affiliations: Powell, R.G., W-K-F Valve Div. of ACF Industries, United States; Carle, R.G., W-K-F Valve Div. of ACF Industries, United States
Abstract: The docking of super tankers at unprotected offshore loading facilities can present major problems of energy dissipation during impact. Hydraulic fender units offer several distinct advantages over conventional resilient fender units, namely: nearly complete dissipation of energy as opposed to energy storage, more efficient dissipation of this energy resulting in less fender travel or lower force levels, velocity sensitive force control, and more positive control by tugboats because of the lack of rebound. Actual impact and computer studies have validated the advantages of hydraulic fendering. © 1972 Proceedings of the Annual Offshore Technology Conference.
Index Keywords: Energy dissipation; Offshore oil well production; Force level; Offshore loading; Offshore technology

Title: An energy basis for the design of open-ocean single-point moorings
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Offshore Technology Conference
Affiliations: Esso Production Research Co., United States
Authors with affiliations: Maddox, N.R., Esso Production Research Co., United States
Abstract: The use of tankers or large barges for permanent crude oil storage at offshore oilfield locations in deepwater, open-ocean environments will require the design of single-point moorings for conditions substantially more severe than existing single-point mooring installations. Three types of single-point moorings, conventional catenary-moored SPM buoys, the newly developed single anchor-leg mooring and turret mooring, have been model tested with directional irregular waves simulating limited fetch, open ocean sea conditions. Model tests simulated loaded and ballasted tankers in the range of 28-190 Mdwt, water depths up to 600 feet, and significant wave heights up to 40 feet. A correlation of the potential energy stored by the mooring when the vessel was offset by wave action suggests that this energy is primarily a function of significant wave height and loaded storage vessel displacement and is independent of water depth and the type of single-point mooring system used. A procedure based on the energy correlation has been developed for the design of open-ocean, all-weather single-point moorings. © 1972 Proceedings of the Annual Offshore Technology Conference.
Index Keywords: Oceanography; Offshore oil well production; Oil tankers; Potential energy; Single point mooring; Water waves; Crude oil storage; Energy correlation; Irregular waves; Offshore oilfield; Significant wave height; Single-point mooring systems; Storage vessel; Wave actions; Offshore technology

Title: Environmental statement. U.S. Atomic Energy Commission power burst facility at the National Reactor Testing Station, April 1972
Abstract: This environmental statement has been prepared in compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act, for the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission's (AEC) proposed administrative action of operation of the Power Burst Facility (PBF). Construction of the PBF has been essentially completed at the AEC's National Reactor Testing Station (NRTS) in southeastern Idaho. The PBF is a unique test reactor for use in the AEC nuclear safety program. It is designed to study the behavior of reactor fuels under a variety of conditions considerably more severe than those to which fuels would normally be exposed in commercial power reactors. The experimental program and related testing approach concentrates on the postulated fuel rod failure sequence and seeks to define the thresholds for failure, and the mode of failure in fuel rod clusters. This facility was designed to meet the radiographical guidelines of the Federal Radiation Council with respect to personnel working at the NRTS and individuals and population groups living beyond the NRTS site boundary. The radioactive waste systems of the facility are being modified to provide greater control over effluent releases. As a result of these modifications, the doses due to releases are expected to be within the newly proposed radiological guidelines and will produce exposures that will be less than one percent of background radiation doses. No adverse short or long term effects on plant, animal or human populations are anticipated as a consequence of either normal operation of the facility or transportation of fuel to and from the facility. Liquid radioactive wastes will be shipped to an onsite processing plant for treatment. All solid radioactive wastes will be packaged for shipment to a controlled storage area. No adverse short or long term environmental effects are anticipated as a consequence of transportation of these wastes. In assessing and balancing the environmental and technical benefits to be gained from the operation of this facility and completion of the experimental program and the environmental and monetary costs associated with its operation and after considering the foregoing range of alternatives and their environmental impacts, it is concluded that the proposed action should be accomplished.
Index Keywords: environmental health

Title: POWER FROM THE OFFSHORE WINDS.
Authors with affiliations: HERONEMUS, W.E.
Abstract: IT HAS BEEN ESTIMATED THAT THE TOTAL RATE OF CONVERSION BETWEEN AVAILABLE POTENTIAL ENERGY AND KINETIC ENERGY IN THE ATMOSPHERE OF THE WHOLE NORTHERN HEMISPHERE IN WINTER IS ABOUT 10/SUP 14/ KILOWATTS REDUCING TO ABOUT SIXTY PERCENT OF THAT VALUE IN SUMMER.MUCH OF THAT ENERGY IS FELT AS 'THE WESTERLIES,' WINDS ON WHICH THE SEAFARING MAN OF BYGONE YEARS PLACED GREAT DEPENDENCE.THE WESTERLIES ARE OF PARTICULAR SIGNIFICANCE TO THE UNITED STATES BECAUSE IN A SENSE THEY ARE A BONUS OF SOLAR ENERGY BESTOWED UPON US.THE ATMOSPHERIC AND OCEANIC PROCESSES WHICH CREATE THEIR ENERGY OCCUR OVER THE ADJACENT AND DISTANT OCEANS AS WELL AS OVER OUR LAND MASS: THE RESULT IS FELT PARTICULARLY ALONG OUR LAND-TO-WATER BOUNDARIES.IT IS SUGGESTED THAT MAN MIGHT ONCE AGAIN TURN TO THOSE MIGHTY WINDS AND TO THE OCEAN CURRENTS WHICH THEY HELP TO SUSTAIN TO HELP SATISFY HIS NEED FOR ENERGY.IF SUCH ENERGY WERE USED, IT WOULD BE ESSENTIALLY POLLUTION-FREE AND WOULD HAVE A NEUTRAL EFFECT ON GLOBAL HEATING.A NUMBER OF CONCEPTS FOR OFFSHORE WIND POWER SYSTEMS ARE PROPOSED.(A)
Index Keywords: Aerodynamics; Availability; Costs; DEEP WATER STORAGE; Economics; OCEANS; OFFSHORE; U.S.A; Wind power; WIND POWER - AVAILABILITY; Wind turbines

Title: Practical two phase DC chopper motor drive
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Electrical Equipment Division, Electrotechnology Department, USAMERDC, Fort Belvoir, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reimers, E., Electrical Equipment Division, Electrotechnology Department, USAMERDC, Fort Belvoir, VA, United States
Abstract: During the past ten years the Army has invested a sizable effort into new systems configurations and development programs to improve ground vehicle mobility. USAMERDC, Fort Belvoir, Virginia, has been particularly interested in an improved vehicle mobility for off-highway vehicles, amphibians and engineer equipment through electrical propulsion. Because electrical propulsion drive systems feature individual wheel controls, the supply logistic and construction of such vehicles can be justified in terms of an improved mobility over all types of terrain. Past experience in industry and in the Government has shown that the dc motor propulsion drive is inherently simple to install and to maintain. The dc motor is somewhat heavier than comparable ac motors due to motor speed limitations; however, the dc machine, particularly the series field motor, requires only a simple solid state power processor since the power is processed by the motor's own commutator. Commercial dc traction motors have an excellent high torque starting characteristic which is mandatory for engineer type vehicle propulsion applications. In the mid-speed range, however, presently available dc motor propulsion drives under consideration for the Army have an unsatisfactory acceleration performance when compared to conventional mechanical drive systems which typically comprise a spark or compression ignition engine and a multispeed transmission. In this context the paper discusses this Center s experimental solid state controller and the method employed to improve the acceleration or peak power propulsion profile of an electric vehicle drive using dc series field motors. A power processor for shunt field motors is also described, also able to provide identical propulsion characteristics through storage of kinetic energy in a high speed flywheel. © 1972 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Choppers (circuits); Commercial vehicles; DC machinery; DC motors; Diesel engines; Electric drives; Electric propulsion; Ground vehicles; Highway engineering; Ignition systems; Kinetic energy; Kinetics; Mechanical drives; Off road vehicles; Propulsion; Traction motors; Vehicles; Acceleration performance; Compression ignition engine; Ground vehicle mobilities; Mechanical drive system; Multi-speed transmissions; Propulsion characteristics; Solid state controllers; Starting characteristic; Electric machine control

Authors: Chen D.Y., Owen H.A., Wilson T.G.
Title: Computer-Aided design and graphics applied to the study of inductor-energy-storage DC-To-DC electronic power converters
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering Duke University, Durham, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, D.Y., Department of Electrical Engineering Duke University, Durham, NC, United States; Owen, H.A., Department of Electrical Engineering Duke University, Durham, NC, United States; Wilson, T.G., Department of Electrical Engineering Duke University, Durham, NC, United States
Abstract: The power handling portion of most regulated dc-To-dc electronic power conditioning circuits using a single self inductor for energy storage and transfer can usually be represented by one of three basic or canonical circuit forms. The circuit elements, consisting of an inductor, a transistor switch, a diode, and a filter capacitor may be arranged with appropriate topology to yield a voltage step-up converter, a current step-up converter, or a voltage step-up/current step-up converter. The design of a power converter requires making a number of decisions relating to the parameters of the circuit, including choice of semiconductor elements, filter capacitor, magnetic core material, magnetic path configuration and winding wire size. In the past, converter designs generally have required that several trial combinations of core size and permeability be tested by hand calculations. Experience and intuition were relied on to narrow the range of core size and permeability before starting the trial design computations. Recently, several computer-Aided procedures have been described for use in the design. of the inductor for a single type of converter) This paper presents the results of the development of a series of nine programs which may be used to design the inductor in each of three basic converter forms in which the transistor switch is cont rolled by a regulator employing a constant frequency, constant on-Time, or constant off-Time pulse-width modulator. These nine programs, which contain the design algorithms and evaluation segments, are augmented by three additional programs which generate displays on a storage oscilloscope driven by the computer. These displays have proved to be extremely useful in evaluating the characteristics of the various converter-regulator combinations from an overall or global point of view. © 1972 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Coremaking; Electric inductors; Energy storage; Power converters; Pulse width modulation; Storage (materials); Transistors; Appropriate topology; Constant frequency; Electronic power converters; Filter capacitors; Power conditioning; Pulse width modulators; Semiconductor element; Transistor switch; DC-DC converters

Title: Uninterrupted DC power supplies
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Control and Power Equipment Department, TRW Inc., TRW Systems Group, Redondo Beach, CA, United States; Power Source Systems Team, U. S. Army Electronics Technology and Devices Laboratory (ECOM), Ft. Monmouth, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schoenfeld, A.D., Control and Power Equipment Department, TRW Inc., TRW Systems Group, Redondo Beach, CA, United States; Wrublewski, F.J., Power Source Systems Team, U. S. Army Electronics Technology and Devices Laboratory (ECOM), Ft. Monmouth, NJ, United States
Abstract: Primary power source dropouts can cause voltage transients or loss of conditioned power to critical or essential electric power-using equipment. Some of the power loads require controlled transient power, that is , conditioned power which at all times is contained within specified voltage regulation limits. Critical loads which can tolerate a temporary loss of power can be satisfied by the availability of a standby power source. Essential loads which require controlled transient power supply voltage must include in the system configuration of the uninterrupted power supply, an active energy storage element. There are three basic ways in which the controlled transient uninterrupted DC power supply can be configured. The special features of the three systems are compared and the most suitable application for each system is indicated. To illustrate the reduction to practice of one of the controlled transient uninterrupted power supply configurations, a 3KW uninterrupted DC power supply developed for the U. S. Army ECOM by TRW Systems is described indetail. © 1972 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric losses; Electric power system control; Electric power systems; Power quality; Transients; Uninterruptible power systems; Voltage regulators; DC power supplies; Electric power; Primary power sources; Storage elements; System configurations; Transient power supply; Uninterrupted power supply; Voltage transients; Power control

Title: Possibility of dismantling a nuclear power station
Source title: Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan / Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: Japan At. Energy Res. Inst., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Suguri, S., Japan At. Energy Res. Inst., Japan
Abstract: The Japan Power Demonstration Reactor (JPDR) of the Japan Atomic Energy Research lnstitute has been modified to double the thermal output. During the modification, several high radiation operations were performed. A section of the biological shield concrete was removed to lay down a canal between the reactor pool and the fuel storage pool, and concrete had to be removed close to the flange of the pressure vessel. Portions of the core internals, such as the control brade and poison curtains, had to be removed and disposed of into the groveyard, and to do this an electro discharge machine was employed. By analyzing radiation levels, contamination and exposed doses during these operations, the dismantling of a nuclear powerstation was considered feasible. © 1972, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: biological shield concretes; canal; core internals; dismantling; electro discharge machine; high radiation work; JPDR reactor; modification; nuclear Power station; personnel; pressure vessels; radiation protection; safety

Title: Plutonium fuel development laboratory of power reactor and nuclear fuel development corporation
Source title: Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan / Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: Power Reactor & Nucl. Fuel Develop. Corp., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Suzuki, S., Power Reactor & Nucl. Fuel Develop. Corp., Japan
Abstract: The Second Plutonium Fuel Development Laboratory of the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation, which had been under construction since 1969, has now been completed, and production of Pu fuels for both FBR and ATR commenced in Feb. 1972. The total floor space is about 9, 000mm2 in which are housed separate production lines for FBR and ATR (pellet preparation, pin fabrication, assembling and recovery), as well as facilities for quality control fuel storage, air conditioning and management office. The annual production capacity is 5t and 3t for ATR and FBR, respectively. Some of the production facilities were equipped to operate automatically in order to reduce the risk of human radiation exposure. Systems for criticality control and material balance are described together with an outline of the arrangement of the facilities with fully equipped alarm system. © 1972, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Yoshida M., Hoshii H., Matsui M.
Title: Evaluation of Nutritive Value of Glycol Esters as Energy Source for Growing Chicks and Rats
Affiliations: National Institute of Animal Industry, Chiba-shi, Japan; Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshida, M., National Institute of Animal Industry, Chiba-shi, Japan; Hoshii, H., National Institute of Animal Industry, Chiba-shi, Japan; Matsui, M., Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Nutritive value of 4 glycol esters, i.e. ethanediol diacetate, 1,2-propanediol diacetate, 1,3-butanediol diacetate and 1,3-butanediol dioctylate, was estimated biologically by feeding the esters to growing chicks and rats. Energy in the esters taken by both chicks and rats was well utilized, though feed intake of the diets containing the esters at high level tended to decrease. Bitter taste of the esters was suspected to be related to low appetite. The acetates were somewhat volatile and released free acetic acid in the diet during storage. These properties of the acetates makes their use for dietary energy source difficult in practical condition. © 1972, Japan Society for Bioscience, Biotechnology, and Agrochemistry. All rights reserved.

Title: polar magnetic substorms
Authors with affiliations: Rostoker, G.
Abstract: The mechanisms by which substorms are generated are still a subject of considerable controversy. A brief review of the historical development of some of the concepts of substorm generation, and the relative merits of these concepts, are discussed against the background of the large number of observational data now available. Polar magnetic substorms are generated through the intensification of the ionospheric current in a localized region of the westward electrojet. At this time field‐aligned currents flow, linking the ionospheric electrojet and magnetospheric current systems near the inner edge of the plasma sheet. It is now apparent that the north‐south component of the interplanetary magnetic field regulates the flow of energy from the interplanetary medium into the magnetosphere. The magnetotail acts as a temporary storage reservoir for this energy, which is eventually released in substorms. Convection is the physical mechanism that dominates in the distribution of energy in the nightside magnetosphere. The over‐all picture presented suggests that substorms are a drastic mechanism by which energy stored in the nightside magnetosphere is dissipated. Copyright © 1972 by the American Geophysical Union.

Authors: DAVÍDEK J., VELÍšEK J., JANÍČEK G.
Title: STABILITY OF INOSINIC ACID, INOSINE AND HYPOXANTHINE IN AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS
Affiliations: Dept. of Food Chemistry & Analysis, Chemical Technical University, Prague
Authors with affiliations: DAVÍDEK, J., Dept. of Food Chemistry & Analysis, Chemical Technical University, Prague; VELÍšEK, J., Dept. of Food Chemistry & Analysis, Chemical Technical University, Prague; JANÍČEK, G., Dept. of Food Chemistry & Analysis, Chemical Technical University, Prague
Abstract: The stability of inosinic acid. inosine and hypoxanthine in aqueous solutions at 90°C was studied. Inosinic acid, inosine and hypoxanthine were separated by ion exchange chromatography and spectrometrically estimated. Reaction rates in the region pH 2–12 were calculated. The activation energy at pH 3, 4 and 5 were 34.0, 30.4 and 28.1 kca1/mol, respectively. Results show that inosinic acid contents of heat‐preserved meat products and enzyme‐free systems would stay practically unchanged during normal storage conditions. Copyright © 1972, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Kinetics of the thermal degradation of poly(1,4‐cyclohexylenedimethylene terephthalate)
Affiliations: Tennessee Eastman Company, Division of Eastman Kodak Company Kingsport, Tennessee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gregory, D.R., Tennessee Eastman Company, Division of Eastman Kodak Company Kingsport, Tennessee, United States; Watson, M.T., Tennessee Eastman Company, Division of Eastman Kodak Company Kingsport, Tennessee, United States
Abstract: The kinetics for the thermal degradation of poly (1,4‐cyclohexylenedimethylene terephthalate) (PCHDT) were evaluated by means of a melt extruder. The effects of temperature, residence time, and oxygen content of the gas blanketing the polymer during storage on degradation of PCHDT were determined. The rate of thermal degradation was measured in terms of the rate of decrease of inherent viscosity and the rate of increase of carboxyl end group concentration. Residence time, temperature, and their interaction all contributed significantly to the degradation. For the conditions investigated, the oxygen content of the blanketing gas had no measurable effect on degradation. Analysis of the kinetic data yielded equations based on a random chain scission mechanism. These equations enabled the prediction of inherent viscosity and carboxyl end group concentration as functions of temperature and residence time and the inherent viscosity and carboxyl end group concentration of the original polymer. The activation energies for decrease in inherent viscosity and increase in carboxyl end group concentration of poly (1,4‐cyclohexylenedimethylene terephthalate) were determined as 38.7 kcal/mole, respectively. Copyright © 1972 Society of Plastics Engineers, Inc.

Title: Purity and stability of radiochemical tracers in autoradiography
Affiliations: Radiochemical Centre, Ltd, Searle Corporation, Amersham, United Kingdom; Amersham/Searle Corporation, Arlington Heights, Illinois, United States
Authors with affiliations: Evans, E.A., Radiochemical Centre, Ltd, Searle Corporation, Amersham, United Kingdom, Amersham/Searle Corporation, Arlington Heights, Illinois, United States
Abstract: Autoradiography is used as a means of ‘visualizing’ the results of tracer investigations; it gives a measure of ‘events’ which have already occurred. This paper discusses some of the problems peculiar to radiochemicals which should be clearly recognized prior to the application of autoradiographic techniques and the interpretation of the data obtained. Many of the problems described in this paper are concerned with tritium compounds which are particularly valuable and widely used for studies involving high resolution autoradiography. The physical (nuclear) properties of tritium, the low maximum beta energy (18 keV) of the radiation and the high maximum specific activity (29 Ci/mg atom of hydrogen), makes tritium the ideal isotope for determining the precise localization of compounds, drugs and hormones for example, in biological specimens. Refinements in autoradiographic techniques which have been developed in recent years have permitted high sensitivity in the detection of the tracer. While the importance of using compounds of known radiochemical purity for any tracer investigation is widely recognized, it is necessary to ensure that the data obtained is related to the radiochemical tracer compound and is not a consequence of the presence of radiochemical impurities. In this paper are therefore described some of the problems which can arise using impure tracer compounds and their effects on the interpretation of autoradiographs. The methods for the determination of purity, for example chromatographic, isotope dilution analysis, autoradiographic and spectroscopic methods are discussed together with some of the difficulties associated with these analytical techniques. The instability of radiochemicals on storage prior to their use is now a well documented phenomenon; it is a particularly severe problem with compounds used in high resolution autoradiographic studies because of the high molar specific activities which are necessary. Factors which determine the rate of self‐decomposition are discussed, such as the molar specific activity of the compounds, the energy of the radiation and the storage conditions selected for the compound. Current methods for minimizing self‐decomposition of radiochemicals are discussed and illustrated by examples. When using tritium compounds, the integrity of the tritium label is often related to the position of the tritium atom(s) in the tracer compound. However, many of the methods used for the preparation of tritium compounds can yield products in which the specificity of the labelling is uncertain. The importance of the specificity of labelling in such tracers in relation to the interpretation of autoradiographic data is therefore also discussed. 1972 Blackwell Science Ltd
